saluta pluso - I was beginning to wonder where everyone had dissappeared to.

there have been many interesting comments and ideas on glosalist and I fancy 
experimenting with some of them in "Sti Glosa". Having a poor memory, I find 
learning languages difficult generally and wish to sympathise with people 
like myself.

The dictionary first:
We shall make use of "ne(g)" - nega=negative or opposite, "ze(r)" - zero=zero 
or neither extreme and the notion of optimism.
good, bad and indifferent (boni is optimistic) could be boni, ne boni and ze 
boni.
ana, neg ana and zer ana could be up , down, horizontal/along etc
supra, ne supra and ze supra would be above, below and level
a, neg a, zer a         to, from and ??
facile, ne facile and ze facile       easy, difficult and (perhaps) 
straightforward

so:- 
a=to 
boni=good
facile=easy
ana=up
supra=above
ne(g)=negative/opposite
ze(r)= nothing.....

A dictionary of 7 items instead of 12, much less of a burden on one's memory 
for beginners (and it's beginners we need)
 to . good . easy . up . above . opposite . nothing .
Zu. gut. leicht. auf. ober. Gegenteil. nichts 
A. bon. facile. en haut. au-dessus. le contraire. rien 
Non niente a. buono. facile. su. sopra. il contrario.
A. bom. fácil. para cima. acima. oposto. nada.  
A. bueno. fácil. arriba. arriba. el contrario. nada. 
 syd

Subject: Re: [glosalist] ne no nuli ze zero and origami
From: Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com

A little origami.....
This paper is folded. It is unfolded. (....... positive number of folds 
..........   zero folds)
fold this paper! Leave it folded! Unfold it! .... positive folding actions 
(........... zero folding actions ........ negative folding actions)
"Un" = zero or negative/opposite   
ne akti*refrain      .......... zero act
ne foto*dull (not clear/bright) ......... little light
no-face*demolish .......... negative make
no-facili*difficult  ........ negative make
no-kine*motionless .......... zero action
no-kine*not moving
no-kine*stationary
zero*nought
nuli*nil
nuli*no
nuli*nothing
nuli*repeal
We have "ne", "no", "nuli" "zero" for much the same meaning.
Both "un" in Eng and "ne/no" in Glosa are rather ambiguous in these examples. 
It has been suggested ( by Ron Clark, I think) that "no" should be used for 
zero meaning and "ne" for negative. I agree but as there is the confusion in 
the core dictionary, I prefer to use "ne(g)" and "ze(r)" in Sti Glosa as they 
are clearer. For the moment I shall stick to these while I experiment.
To encourage new-comers the dictionary should be kept as short and clear as 
possible.
syd

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] ne no nuli ze zero and origami
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 07 Jan 2001 10:21:31 -0800


> We have "ne", "no", "nuli" "zero" for much the same meaning.
> Both "un" in Eng and "ne/no" in Glosa are rather ambiguous

It is similar in all the eurolangs and maybe all languages;
common particles attach themselves to verbs or nouns,
without logical rigor. We must live with it. In math we have
two simple inverse operations, one additive and one multiplicative;
they can be seen as resembling negation (non-) and opposition (un-).

Wouldn't it be nice to have two such corresponding prefix particles
in an auxlang? We need them both as adverbs and determiners.
Word order in Glosa is fixed, lessening possible adverb confusion.
But to do this systematically exposes a further problem:

There are many (perhaps 100) common particles that form subsets
of similar syntactic usage, e.g. "none one some all",
"not very more most less least", "with without", "and or else but".
Translating to Greco-Latin, there are problems like "sin = without"
versus "syn = with", or "in = within" versus "in- = not".

Since they are so frequent in usage, they must be easily
distinguishable phonetically, and work well as prefixes.
I think it all adds up to a choice of whether to perpetuate
the eurolang confusion, or not. Loglan/Lojban is the only
auxlang to choose the latter option.

For recognizability, "ne" and "no" are clear winners for negation.
But for opposition there is only confusion: de- des- dis- a- ab- ap-
an- in- un- anti- contra- etc. (I am considering adverbial forms
because they are most productive. Adjectives like "none, null"
are combinations of adverb+adjective, "not one", etc.)

If I were designing a conlang (again), I'd want to use bisyllabic
roots like "nega, anti, mono" and free compounding for everything.
With primary stress it sounds good, with hyphens it's easy to read.
But then I want to have all the "de- con- re-" prefixes too,
and some suffixes like -t and -nd and -s ... so it's non-possible.

A piece about horticulture in SG trying to keep the dictionary down to as few 
words as poss. Format of dictionaries temporary -  my translator coped with 
spanish except for "it". not sure what I think about hyphens.....
they and the "ne"s etc cut by about a fifth
-----------------------------------------------
U HDRA du cerka de plu boni mode de horti e id du qestio plu-id grega-pe de 
face plu examina de plu varia tema.

ze-exakti 30 alo 40 anua neg-avanti, plu mode pa gene cerka de ne-sti u 
ne-boni ex u brasika radi diptera ne-ko nece du ne-kolekti plu toxi epi plu 
fito alo solu. 
-------------------------------------------------------
PLU LEXIKO
 alo. anua. avanti. boni. brasika: cerka. de. diptera. du. e:: epi. ex. 
exakti. examina. face: fito. gene. grega. HDRA. horti:: id. ko. kolekti. 
mode. ne: nece. neg. pa. pe. plu:: qestio. radi. skope. solu. sti: tema. 
toxi. u. varia. ze::

 or . year . forward . good . brassica : search . fly (insect) . verb 
continuous tense . and :: on . by (from) . exact . examine . make : get . 
group . HDRA . garden :: it . with . collect . method . negative : need . 
negative . past tense . person . plural :: question . root . look . soil : 
start . poison . a . vary . zero :: 

SPANISH
O. año. delantero. bueno. brassica: la búsqueda. mosca (insecto). el verbo 
continuo tenso. y:: en. por (de). exacto. la prueba. la marca: obtiene. el 
grupo. HDRA. el jardín:: ?. con. reunir. el método. negativo: la necesidad. 
negativo. pasado tenso. persona. el plural:: la pregunta. raíz. la mirada. 
tierra. el comienzo: veneno. un. varía. cero:: 
---------------------------
CHANGE OF MIND?
perhaps "no" instead of "ze" but "no" means zero - last paragraph again:-
---------------------------------------------------
[no]-exakti 30 alo 40 anua neg-avanti, plu mode pa gene cerka de ne-sti u 
ne-boni ex u brasika radi diptera ne-ko nece du ne-kolekti plu toxi epi plu 
fito alo solu.

mo grega pe pa vide ma e ma de plu-an fito du ne-aqa e ne-vive a tem an pa 
ne-detekti pan de mu. An pa decide akti bi de plu gru examina. U numero mo 
uti u odoro de tena plu insekti ne-a.

 a=to,  akti=act/do, an=he/him/his  aqa=water, bi=two de=of etc  
decide=decide detekti=find du=present tense.... examina=examine  e=and 
fita=plant gru=suitable grega=crowd/group insekti=insect  ma=more mo=one 
mu=they/them ne=negative/opposite numero=number  odoro=smell pa=past tense 
pan=all pe=person plu=the(plural)  tem=time tena=hold u=a/the uti=use 
vide=see vive=alive

At 23:27 04/01/2001 +0300, Alexander wrote:

>Saluta, karo plu Glosa-pe!

>Mi kupidi a vi u bon neo anua!

>Mi spe habe plu interesti diskursi e disputa in 2001 in u na lista!

>Mi habe plu neo qestio:

>1. Qo es "DETRITU"? (mi ne pote komprende)

>2. Qo es "DISOLVE"? (Mi ne pote trovi u verba in plu verbi-bibli)

>3. In "Glosa Internet Dic." DISKURSI es "discussion", sed id ne habe u-ci

>semani in "G-E.all". Que u-ci semani es de u-ci verba?

>

>Saluta,

>Alexander.

>

*Prima, mi nece dice .. U Boni Nova a Holo Nu!


   Alexander, tu posi habe dificili ko u mode de krea plu Glosa verbi.

   Ki retro, ad u prima loka de plu Glosa verb, na nece refere a plu paleo Latino e Greko.  Pluso, kron Ron Clark pa krea u lexikon de Glosa, an pa uti plu idea de plu origi krea-pe de plu-ci lingua.

   An pa dice a mi ke plu Greko-pe pa habe un eklekti lingua; in qi singo verbi pote habe plu pusi verbi intra id.  Plu-ci pusi verbi, posi de bi, alo tri, litera, dona u mero de u toto koncepa de u ma mega kompleti verbi. U-ci abili, te tekto plu komplexi verbi ex poli pusi mero, pa do plu Greko-pe u flex-abili ko pli idea, e plu verbi; in qi te expresi mu. 

  Alterno, plu Latino-dice-pe pa uti mu plu verbi iso ma solidi ra, e ne developo plu filosofi-pe, ke na ski ex Greko kultura.  Intra u Latino lingua na vide u kombina de plu existe verbi te face plu komplexi verbi, pluso un uti de plu pre-fixa e post-fixa.

  E so, kron plu Glosa autori-pe pa kre mu neo lingu, mu pa uti holo de plu-ci metodi te forma plu ge-nece moderni verbi.


  U ~dis~ intra ~disolve~ e ~diskursi~ eqa `de -` alo `in id plu mero` alo `ex u -`.  Ko ~disolve~ na vide u solve de u solidi objekti in id plu mero, usuali intra hidro.

  Ko ~diskursi~ na habe u meta-fora uti de u verbi ~kursi~: vice puta de u persona; qi kursi peri u loka, na habe u pikto de u menta; qi kursi peri holo de u regio de u subjekti.  Posto kine dia u subjekti, u persona pote grafo de an menta viagio, dia u-ci subjekti: an publiko an plu idea iso u ~diskursi~ (ex u - kursi).  Na pote uti u homo verbi te deskribe u ge-dice `kursi` de mo, alo ma, persona dia u subjekti. [discourse; discussion]

  #tritus#, ex u Latino verbi-bibli, habe u semani de uno-ra; qi gene lase ex u surfacia po frika.  ~detritus~ eqa qod gene ge-lase po un objekti pa gene ge-frika (de - trite) [from the .. wearing].  

  Intra _Glosa 6000_ na detekti      TRITE   old, worn.


  Te detekti plu-ci semani de plu Glosa verbi, mi pa merka pusi verbi-bibli de Latino-lingua e Greko-lingua.  Mi pa duce plu pedi-kadu de Ron Clark, te logi plu raisona pro Glosa verbi selekti.


Viagia Ko Kura, U-ci Anua,


Robin Gaskell

    Loka uno-ra, intra id solve liqi, eqa un akti de magika.
    So, kron u solidi ki apo, e tu ne ski a qo-lo id pa ki, tu dice ke u

    Sed, kron tu ski; u solidi habe existe intra u liqi, anti tu ne pote

Karo Marcerl e Plu Hetero-pe,
   Ci, iso Marcel pa demanda, es mi foto-grafi.
   Id pa gene ge-face to u licetia-oficia de u Strada Viagia Autori-ra
[Road Traffic Authority], e mi pa kopi id ex u gona de mi vagona-argo
licentia.
   Tem mu pa face id, mu pa uti u neo teknologi de digitali-foto-grafi, e
mi pa kontinu atende, seque u procesa gene ge-kompleti.  Il es nuli brila
foto, e nuli klik; u-ci foto-grafi monstra mi in atende-mode.

   Qe, u fila habe 27 Kb e uti JPEG format, u tali fila habe gru pro tu
Reti-lo, Marcel?

   Pa seti-mana, mi pa merca u skano-me pro mi puta-me, e per u-ci mode pa
itera uti plu elektroni te gene u pikto de mi facia a tu.

   So, mi pa dona hemi u logi de u nima de u supra ge-pende-ra.  U ma-rubi
sektio de u nima veni ex u faktu ke mi vo kausa un origi pikto te gaino u
ma rubi feno.  E so, seqe fixa u rubi-fa te dona u kromo; mi pa vo habe, mi
pa dona nima de "LicencePinker" (LicentiaMa-rubi) ad u fila.

   E, nova de Afrika: per kambio plu grama ko Banobi Herbert de u Monta
Gorila Parka, intra Uganda, mi habe u sekuri adrese, banobi NGO numera. Ko
plu-ci mi fu posta u pusi puta-me e tipo-me ad an; holo-co sine pago un
excesi alti importa imposto .. ka Banobi habe un oficiali ge-registra NGO
statu pro an Gorila Parka. 
   Recento, mi pa merca u paleo punkta-matrix tipo-me te ergo ko u puta-me.
 Pluso, mi pa gene u neo carboni tape pro u tipo-me.  Nu mi fu posta u
tipo-me ad Uganda; te bali id per aero, fu habe preci de proxi A$80.

   Si u tipo-me gene a Benobi, sine gene ge-klepto, so, finali, mi fu posta
u puta-me; qi mi pa merca te bali ad Afrika, tri anua pre nu.
   U-ci _Toshiba 1200_ puta-me pa habe preci de A$80, sed posta per aero fu
habe preci de ma de mo cento dolari.  Anti-co, mi ne nece bali u pluso
qantita de valuta (proxi US$400) iso importa imposto - ka Banobi
ge-registra NGO statu.

Pusi e Pusi Na Gene La,

Robin Gaskell
  P.S.  Banobi Herbert habe multi aktivi, e recento, pa gene ge-dona un
ergo de Auxi Komunita Developo Oficia pro an regio, sed si tu vo grafo ko
an, uti Glosa, mi fu posta an adrese epi u-ci Lista.   R.G.

At 13:59 28/01/2001 EST, Syd Pidd grafo:
>mi detekti qui "mo" = "one" et "furniture" et "ma" = "more" and "material". 
>U-ci es anti u buta de Glosa, mi puta qi "mo" =1 e "mobile" alo "mobi" debi 
>=furniture, ma=more sed materia alo mate=material..................
*   Il es u difere inter ~mo~ e ~-mo~
    U toto separa verbi ~mo~ habe u semani de "1"
    Kron na, alo u verbi-procesa puta-me, detekti u ~-mo~ ge-fixa ad u
hetero verbi ko u jugo-signi, na, alo u puta-me, pa gene ge-informa de id
semani; qi eqa ~mobili~.  U puta-me pa habe id instruo, e u persona gene
sko de id, e nuli-tem no-memo id. 

    U voka dice ~Ma ligni-ma!~ sembla indika ke uno-pe vo habe plura mero
de u ligni; mu du uti.

>sugesti pluso :- 
>+volu*impulse          pulsa [push]; te akti per volu
>+volu*need             vo habe; nece
>+volu*require          nece habe 
>+volu*voluntary        an volu ergo; an es u volu-ergo-pe
>+volu*want             vo habe; nece habe  (qod es u dina de tu desira?)
>+volu*will             id es mi volu te akti id; te habe dina volu
>+volu*willing          an es u volu participa-pe
>+volu*willingness      place monstra tu volu-ra te akti u-ci
>+volu*wish             mi volu es pro paca
>"impulse,need,require...............wish" pan  gene kolekte in English ad 
>"require" ante translate a glosa. 9 coredictionary verba nu equ 1.
>  
*   Il es u problema, sed nuli u serioso mo.  Te striktu u verbi lista, Ron
Clark pa *seka plu gona*.  Ko u-ci kaso, an pa decide ke plu koncepa de
"wish" e "will" es ta proxi mu pote habe mo Glosa verbi.  
    Po plu nece, de uno-pe, sio kreske ma de u basi 6000 verbi, an fu
detekti plu hetero verbi te lice an monstra u difere inter "willing" e
"wishing".

    U dificili; qi Ron Clark pa kausa ko u 'verbi translati' diktionari, es
un idea ke singu verbi intra mo lingua fu nece habe un eqivalu verbi intra
u hetero lingua.  Pro multi basi, Ron pa produce u simpli verbi a verbi
diktionari, sed te korekti uti u lingua, mi logi ke na nece skope plu
semani de plu koncepa intra plu verbi, ne simpli uti singu verbi iso u nima
bileta.
    Te cerka u ~volu~ mi sugere ke tu klude tu oku, e fixa tu menta
koncerne qod tu fu akti.  Kron tu detekti qod tu nece akti, tu pa detekti
tu ~volu.~
    U tristi faktu es ke plura-pe habe forti resolve, e so habe dina
~volu~; tem hetero-pe tenta akti no-reali ra, alo habe pusi resolve, e mu
~volu~ habe no-dina.  U-ci difere posi don explika pro "will" e "wish".  Ka
u limita; ge-uti kron forma u Glosa verbi lista, tem na komence uti Glosa,
na nece uti deskribe in na uti de pu verbi. EG,
  An vo asura akti id, sed an amika pa habe nuli volu te akti u projekti.
[he willed certainly to do it, but his friend had no wish to do the project]
 He would certainly do it, but his friend had no wish to do the project.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

an ne pa proto u-ci ergo. Mega gratia de auxi difusi Glosa. Mi fo amo u-ci
lingua e doxo; id fu tako gene ma-uti in futura.
Mi ne es sura a-nu de mi plu fu-aktivi difusi Glosa; kron mi este u klari
direkti mi fu seqe id e avanti fo zelo. Mi fo grafo tu nima epi na lista e
bali a tu ali Glosa info kron na habe id. Mi ne habe e-posta nu, sed hedo
distribu info de plu e-post e www eko-lo; place don a mi info de ali eko-lo
tu volu plu Glosa-ami de visita. Mi doxo; Marcel pa loka plu fotografi de
Ron e mi kon an lexi-list; qe an pa sucede kon u-ci?
Panto Glosa publikatio/aktivi nu es per eko-lo epi u-ci grama; place nota na
neo eko-lo.
Mega gratia itera.
Hedo neo anua a tu.
ex
Wendy."

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] anglo-greco-latin cognates and final vowels
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 18 Feb 2001 16:55:03 -0800

Here is a list of Greek and Latin roots (column 1)
that have cognates in English (column 2),
reduced to a bi-syllabic CVCV pattern (column 3).

The reductions are straightforward, except the final vowel.
This is -u or -i for Latin, -o or -e for Greek; -a could
be used for Latin feminines or reserved for Germanic/other.

There is nearly a 4-to-1 ratio of Latin to Greek roots.
This simple heuristic enables unambiguous mixing of
both word stocks, avoiding problems such as the
Greek "syn = with" vs. Latin "sin = without".

scurra    buffoon   scuri
scutum    shield    scutu
sebum     fat       sebu
sectus    cut       sectu
saeculum  secular   saecu
sedere    sit       sedi
sedulus   diligent  sedu
selene    moon      sele
semen     seed      semni
senex     old       seni
sensus    feel      sensu

titillare tickle    titi
titulus   title     titu
tolerare  tolerate  toli
temnein   cut       tome
tumbos    tomb      tumbo
tonos     tone      tono
tonsus    clipped   tonsu
tonsa     oar       tonsi
topos     place     topo
tornus    turn      tornu
torpere   numb      torpi
torrere   hot       tori

I think approximately 2000 such roots would and should constitute
the true core vocabulary of any IAL designed to be easiest for
European and American people to learn and use. I'm undecided
whether adding Germanic roots would help more than hurt.

"catty" wrote:

>Good to see you are still interested in these interlanguages.
Yes. I was very busy, but now I want to be more active in IAL-world.
(To my regret I will not be able to do it after the 1st of April, because my
computer will be under repair).
>> Mi habe u qestio a tu: Qe-ka tu ne uti plu fini vokala ab Glosa 6000?
>
>This whole thing about final vowels, is a big confusion
>about something that should be very minor. Final vowels
>are unstressed and not so clearly pronounced or heard.
>In a real language they would not be reliable carriers
>of semantic (or grammatical) distinctions. It is so easy
>for artificial language designers to overuse/abuse them.
>
>Glosa rejected use of final vowels for grammar, and
>I've slowly come to accept and admire that decision.
>But some words are only distinguished by the final vowel.
>This is confusing and should be minimized, I think
>everybody agrees. They are difficult to remember, which
>is an unnecessary impediment to learners.
But using of "better for memorisation" rule can make from Glosa Espo or Ido.
Charles, you know that many people don't like Novial only because it uses
a-priori finals!
So, I don't see what is ideal way for Glosa: New final vowels sytem or old.
I'm torn between these ways...

From: "Alexander E. Kirpichev" <brickswall{at}mtu-net.ru>

Saluta!
Mi nupa grafo u artikla; qi mi fo vo bali id ad Wendy.

Plu mi puta de u na lingua e u id fututri.
Nu na eko in u mundo; qi debe habe u auxi lingua. Poli homi pa stude un
England-lingua in plu mu sko-do, e nu mu debe uti u lingua in plu mu eko.
Sed  un Engalnd-lingua habe u no-facili verba e u no-boni gramatika. Tali
homi ne pote boni stude u lingua, sed mu pote stude u verba ordina de u
Glosa-lingua;qi (vo) ne es u fo no-facili e es simila ad u verba ordina de
un Engalnd-lingua. Il es solo un problema de id: id es facili, sed u id
deskriptio es no-facili. Mi puta; na (plu Glosa-pe) debe sempre dece; u
Glosa verba oridna es simila ad norma (simpli) verba ordina de plu lingua.
Poli Glosa-pe nu puta de problema de u fini vokali de plu Glosa verba. Mi
puta id habe u simpli solutio: Kron u verba ne kambia u semani ko hetero
fini vokali id pote es ge-uti ko ali fini vokali.
Mi puta in futuri u lingua fu es fo ge-amo de poli homi e mu fu uti id.

Saluta,
Alex.

Id posi feno hom divide plu kapila sed u-mi pusi murmuro de "mo", "ma" es 
valu puta de. 
"mo" habe bi semani e bi regula
1 "mo" ="one" si id es solo
2 "mo" ="furniture" si ge-seqe per u hifen nexi ad u verba ante id.
Si mi es neo sti ge-sko Glosa e veni a plu-ci regula, mi pta se " iso 
ge-komplexi de plu hetera lingua". Posi mi gene ge-fascina de sto ge-sko G e 
cerka de u ma simpli lingua. Mi sio prefere plu pan verba habe mo semani e mo 
regula
3 "mo"= "one", "mobile"= "furniture" ........

U hifen habe qo soni a u dice/audi-pe?
"stora-mo/stora mo/storamo/stora-mobile/stora mobile/storamobile" =(?) 
"stOramo/StoramO/storAmo/stOramobile/storamObile/storamobIle"
U-co kausa mi es englisc
"storamO/storAmo/storamO/storamobilE/........."
si mi es francais  (???)
" stOramo/storAmo/..." si mi es de Kroatika(???????)
Qe il es u Glosa regula?

U "." habe qo soni a u dice/audi-pe? U ","? U ";"?

Si vi volu uti regula 2, es no mali sed u pe posi gene konfusi. Mi fu uti 
regula 3
syd

glosa words can be put in 2 groups using their final vowels - those where the 
word without its final occurs only once and those where it occurs more than 
once and the missing vowel alters the meaning. fini volu vola
I suggest that in the first group the final vowel is the same as the vowel in 
the syllable before and in the second group, it does not.
fini volu vola voro rode rodu( of rodo) lenti lento libi  haba cerke........
the reader will know that the repeated vowel is not important and that the 
different one affects the meaning 
plu glosa verbe poso in bi grupu seqe plu-mu fini vokala - (1) plu-la in qi 
plu verbe ko no fini vokala acidi solo mo kron e (2) plu-la in qi id acidi ma 
de mo kron e u ge-loso vokala mutu u semana de u-id verbe. :- fini vola volu
mi sugeste qi in grupu (1) u fini vokala eqe u vokala in u silaba ante id e 
in grupu (2), u bi vokala no es eqe.     fini volu vola voro rode rodu( de 
rodo) lenti lento libi  haba cerke ante anti ........
U lekte/grafa-pe fu nu ma facili ski u ma bono fini de u verbe de ante kron 
il pa es e klara regulu. 
syd

--part1_3e.8dc0539.27e3cefd_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

It is difficult for me to read these messages,
they are not plain text. Perhaps the AOL mail program
you are using can be set to post in plain ASCII text?

> glosa words can be put in 2 groups using their final vowels - those where the 
> word without its final occurs only once and those where it occurs more than 
> once and the missing vowel alters the meaning. fini volu vola
> I suggest that in the first group the final vowel is the same as the vowel in 
> the syllable before and in the second group, it does not.
> fini volu vola voro rode rodu( of rodo) lenti lento libi  haba cerke........
> the reader will know that the repeated vowel is not important and that the 
> different one affects the meaning 

Interesting idea. Clearly some improvement is possible
over the current utter mess. Some more ideas:

Drop all final vowels and just let the homonyms fight
for survival. Anybody can supply a euphonic unstressed
final vowel of their choice in speech; no need to write it!

Or, always repeat the previous vowel as you suggested,
but even for the troublesome ones. It might sound OK.

Another way is that of Interlingua (de Peano),
but it works only for Latin (not Greek) roots.

Another idea is to use -o and -e for Greek roots,
-a -i -u for Latin. That would keep e.g.
"bal=throw" separate from "bal=dance".

A letter:


                                                      "12 Mars 2001
Karo Marcel,

Mi grafo te dice mi nu-pa proto grafo PGN 84.  Qe tu sio amo grafo
ali-ra pro id?  Me qestio-se si tu volu invita plu lekto-pe visita tu
www pagina alo e-posta.  Mi posi fu grafo id A5 format (148 mm x
210 mm) vice A4.  Qe tu habe ali doxo de u-ci?  Mi pa grafo plu
artikla de Hogben e Clark.  Fu-setimana mi gene ergo-mo pro puta-me;
mi nece fo re-organisa mi somni-ka te detekti space!  Po-co, mi fu
gene puta-me ex stora-lo e spe; id dura funktio boni.  Place pardo
brevi-grama; mi matri ne es sani e mi habe fo pusi tem nu-di.

Poli kardia saluta ex

Wendy"


As you read above, Wendy tries a revival of her Glosa-newspaper 'Plu
Glosa Nota'.  I think, this is an important step for Glosa, and I
feel, she would be glad, if someone would write her, send comments and
encourage her.  Articles are welcome! - maybe you feel like writing a
bit?  Or you want to buy, subscribe or support the new edition?  Price
of the last issue was 1 £ (GBP), 1.20 £ for non-UK.  Thanks for your
help.

Again her address:

  Glosa Education Organisation
  PO Box 18
  Richmond Surrey
  TW9 2GE
  ENGLAND

<BR>&gt; "bal=throw" separate from "bal=dance".
<BR>
<BR>At the moment, I feel that Glosa still feels itself as half mature 
<BR>offspring of Greek, Latin and English (word order, grammar etc) and has not 
<BR>become a really independant language in its own right. It is interesting to 
<BR>know about its antecedents but not really essential - English people don't 
<BR>think about Anglo-Saxon, Norman French, Latin, Greek, Hindi.............. 
<BR>when they talk</FONT><FONT  COLOR="#000000" SIZE=3 FAMILY="SANSSERIF" FACE="Arial" LANG="0"></BLOCKQUOTE>
<BR></FONT><FONT  COLOR="#000000" SIZE=2 FAMILY="SERIF" FACE="Times New Roman" LANG="0">On the other hand I would know how to spell " independant/ent" correctly if I 
<BR>knew more Latin but it wouldn,t make a lot of difference to my use of English 
<BR>...... "indipendnt".......
<BR>my scheme could change "bal" to "bale" for dance and "bali" for throw, 
<BR>ballet/ballistics. the fact that it is not "bala" would alert me to the 2 
<BR>different meanings. 
<BR></FONT></HTML>

Subject: Re: [glosalist] Using of international words in Glosa
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sat, 17 Mar 2001 13:32:42 -0800


> I think that there is one very important question for Glosa:
> How we can use international words in Glosa?
> Can we use them when we write in Central Glosa?

I agree, that is a key point, maybe the most important.

Although the Glosa syntax is easy enough, derivation of
words is difficult and arbitrary (I mean the 2-letter
suffixes, which are a-priori rather than "natural").
International words become mangled by the "phonetic"
spelling, so are not very recognizable in writing.

Other interlanguages aim for more euro-naturalism,
but are not so easy outside euro-speaking countries.
Glosa seems to want to be more "global" than "international.
It has a nice phonology for globalism. I'm not convinced
that the vocabulary is adequate, or well-designed.

But go ahead and try using it, see if people follow.
It would be nice if one of these interlanguages were
successful in the mass market (real world). Or if
some qualified linguists reformed it one last time.
Or maybe it's a lost cause. Or I could be wrong.

"Alexander E. Kirpichev" wrote:
> 
> Saluta, Syd e Charles!

Good to see you are still interested in these interlanguages.

> Mi habe u qestio a tu: Qe-ka tu ne uti plu fini vokala ab Glosa 6000?

This whole thing about final vowels, is a big confusion
about something that should be very minor. Final vowels
are unstressed and not so clearly pronounced or heard.
In a real language they would not be reliable carriers
of semantic (or grammatical) distinctions. It is so easy
for artificial language designers to overuse/abuse them.

Glosa rejected use of final vowels for grammar, and
I've slowly come to accept and admire that decision.
But some words are only distinguished by the final vowel.
This is confusing and should be minimized, I think
everybody agrees. They are difficult to remember, which
is an unnecessary impediment to learners. They follow
no discernible etymological or other pattern.

So, I think they should be "devalued" somehow.
Syd's idea and others have been mentioned already.

All the sounds of Glosa should be carefully, clearly and completely made. 
This includes the final vowel or consonant. The final consonant protects the 
final consonant from being dropped or mumbled, drop the vowel and the 
consonant eventually goes followed be what is now a final vowel........... In 
a natural language much of what is said is a sort of shorthand, the head 
words may be at the beginning and the following gubbins is hurried over of at 
the end and the leading syllables skimped. The listener is able to decode 
this if  s/he knows the rules for the particular language. If the language is 
international, this can't easily be done so that all of it has to have the 
same care expended on it.
However the final vowels in Glosa tend to appear randomly chosen make 
remembering difficult. This is why I suggest making this vowel the same as 
the one in the accented syllable. The final will probably be less clear but 
that would not matter much so long as it is clear that is a repeat. In the 
case of finals that affect the meaning, this vowel will be slightly accented 
and more deliberately produced. So leave the final vowel to ensure the 
consonant is distinct or alter the meaning.
ALPHABETS
Glosa has 23 sounds:- abcdefghij klmnoprstu vz and sc
but its alphabet has 41 signs!
41?!!!!!!
abcdefghij klmnopqrst uvxz ABDEFG HIJKLMNPQRT Y.....
we must be crackers!
I shall refuse to use 41 in my glosa.
syd
ps when my emails appear on glosalist, they don't seem to have any strange 
odds nor ends on them - still puzzled

--part1_d2.3e1df86.27e662f0_boundary

3 or 4 years ago, my granddaughter  R had difficulty saying "pink" .The "k" 
was missing or almost so. We tried to help her,
say "pink"
"ping' " 
"pinKH"
"pinnts"
and so on
I promised to treat her to a ride on the miniature railway, but no it was 
always "ping' "
We thought of problems with her throat, deafness and so on.
One day she said perfectly distinctly "thinking" - the "k" was crystal clear.
We tried again, mother said "pink"
father said "pink"
older brother said "pink", 
grandmother said "pink",
Granddad said "pink"
R said "ping' "
We tried again and this time grandad listened carefully
mother actually said "ping' "
father actually said "ping' "
grandad was mortified that he had been saying "ping' " and almost everyone in 
this part of the world except the most fastidious say "ping' "!
R was correct
later when no-one was trying anymore, out popped the word "pink" and she got 
her ride on the railway.

The moral? there is no final vowel after "pink" and the final consonant had 
faded away
We dont want to be talking a language called "Glo" do we?
syd 
 

--part1_a5.131fdf73.27e906b5_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:


> Granddad said "pink"

> grandad was mortified that he had been saying "ping' "

Funny story! Yes, people thin' they are sayin' one thin',
but it comes out otherwise. Looking at my own witness
transcript for a court case, it appears my eastern accent
has such softened terminals that entire syllables drop out,
as far as these-here westerners can determine.

> The moral? there is no final vowel after "pink"
> and the final consonant had faded away
> We dont want to be talking a language called "Glo" do we?

Well, I think all English speakers will say "Glow-suh".
And half will not pronounce R at all in any words.
Spanish speakers cannot pronounce initial SP.
French will constantly drop final E.
I can't think of any difficulties for Germans.

I agree, some final vowel should be pronounced, but it must
be more predictable and mnemonic than what Glosa has now.
Maybe each person should try a paragraph or two
using their own solution, just to test it out.
But I think the answer is to *ignore* the damned things,
I mean who cares if somebody uses the "wrong" one?

>

> But using of "better for memorisation" rule can make from Glosa Espo or Ido.

I once liked Ido's final-vowels, and Interglossa used -e for verbs,
but Glosa uses just word order and particles for grammar.
That leaves the finals as completely useless now.
So why force the learner to memorize something useless?
There is a precedent for repeating the penultimate vowel
as in Syd's proposal: Tolkien's Quenya roots are like that!

Just for fun, I'll take a fair sample of actual Glosa:

> Mi grafo te dice mi nu-pa proto grafo PGN 84.  Qe tu sio amo grafo
> ali-ra pro id?  Me qestio-se si tu volu invita plu lekto-pe visita tu
> www pagina alo e-posta.  Mi posi fu grafo id A5 format (148 mm x
> 210 mm) vice A4.  Qe tu habe ali doxo de u-ci?  Mi pa grafo plu
> artikla de Hogben e Clark.  Fu-setimana mi gene ergo-mo pro puta-me;
> mi nece fo re-organisa mi somni-ka te detekti space!  Po-co, mi fu
> gene puta-me ex stora-lo e spe; id dura funktio boni.

... and transform it using Syd's idea, as I understand it:

: Mi grafa te dici mi nu-pa proto grafa PGN 84.  Qe tu sio ama grafa
: ali-ra pro id?  Me qestio-se si tu volo inviti plu lekte-pe visiti tu
: www pagini alo e-posto.  Mi poso fu grafa id A5 format (148 mm x
: 210 mm) vici A4.  Qe tu haba ali doxo de u-ci?  Mi pa grafa plu
: artikli de Hogben e Clark.  Fu-setimana mi gene erge-mo pro putu-me;
: mi nece fo re-organisi mi somno-ka te detekte spaca!  Po-co, mi fu
: gene putu-me ex storo-lo e spe; id duru funktio bono.

The -u and -i words are awful (IMO), but changing them
to -o and -e looks (as if it would sound) more acceptable.
A sort of "vowel harmony" feature, similar to Turkish.

Subject: [glosalist] Glosa in universita
From: "Marcel Springer" <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>
Date: Sat, 24 Mar 2001 01:35:37 +0100

Glosa in Universita
===================     (English seqe Glosa.)


Mi pa gene e-posta ex Dr. Rudolf Fischer.  An pa lekto mi internet
pagina.  An es lingua-skience-pe ad universita in Münster,
Deutsch-landa.  Fu semi-anua an dona u seminar de plu
mundo-auxi-lingua.  E la an volu dice pusi ra de Glosa.

Mi pa visita an internet-pagina
( http://medweb.uni-muenster.de/~fischru ).  La mi pa pote lekto; an
es presidenti de Münster Esperanto-club.  So an habe maxi amo pro
Esperanto e sura an fu dice u-ci ad plu an stude-pe.  Anti-co, posi
oligo stude-pe sti interese de plu boni idea in Glosa.  Mi spe; plu
Glosa-ami gene ma ex u-ci seminar.  Id sio es boni; si Glosa gene ma
atende ex lingua-skience; mi puta.



I got an email from Dr. Rudolf Fischer.  He has read my internet page.
He is linguist at the university of Münster, Germany.  Next semester
he will give a seminar about interlinguistics.  And there he wants to
present Glosa shortly.

When I visited his website ( http://medweb.uni-muenster.de/~fischru ),
I could see, that he is the president of the local Esperanto
club.  So, of course, he loves Esperanto most, and of course he will
not be very objective to his students.  But nevertheless, perhaps some
students will see the good ideas in Glosa.  I hope, the number of
Glosa-friends will grow by this seminar a bit.  And it would be good,
if Glosa gets a bit more attention of scientists, I think.

Subject: [glosalist] the dreaded vowel,a different approach
From: Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com
Date: Sat, 24 Mar 2001 10:37:36 EST

--part1_5a.12e9df4e.27ee1940_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

We are told that the FV is unimportant and that we can do what we want with 
it, "verba/verbe/verbi" etc and people have in glosalist. Except of course 
when theFV is in fact really important, "vola/volu". How are beginners to 
know? They could check up all possibilities "verba/e/i/o/u" or 
$vola*flight
$vola*fly(to)
$vola*fly_to
 $volatili*evaporating
 $volt*volt_electricity
 $volta*jump_over
 $volta*to-vault
 $volta*volt
$volu*want
$volu*will
$volu*willing
$volu*willingness
$volu*wish
!
The essential parts(EP) of "fini......" are "FIN VERB VOLA VOLU" I suggest 
that we add any free vowel we wish to the ends of any word that will become 
longer than 3 letters. "fini verba volai volue"
The essential letters will be spoken carefully, clearly and completely, the 
FV can be quieter and less clear but firmly enough to support the last EL. 
This will signal the end of a word and add some variety to the sound.

mi volue kontinu u grafoe de kroma seqe u-ci e fu tentai uti u-ci hetera 
metodi de fini vokali. 
(volue/volai grafoe/grafai tentai/tenteo hetera=hetero)
syd

"boreo-ocide". 

.......
austra=south, boreo=north, busola=compass(navigating), de=of, e=and, es=is, 
facia=face, ge-get(passive), habe=have, kiklo=circle, naviga,navigate, 
ocide=west, orienta=east, signi=sign, u=a/the.

--------
plu-na kroma undu longi pande ab 680(?)nm a 750nm(?) in u banda, u-co banda 
poteo ge-flexi a d u kiklo homoa u busola e plu kroma, iso plu busola-punkta, 
posi ge-signi epi u fi.
boreo=leuko
b-orienta=orange
or=rubi
austra-or=purpura
a=blu
a-oc=blu-kloro
oc=kloro
b-oc=leuko-kloro 

.........
a=to, ab=from, banda=strip, blu=blue, d=(separates vowel "a" from "u" - 
easier to say), epi=on, flexi=bend, homoa=similar, in=in, iso=same, 
kloro=green, kroma=colour, leuko=yellow, longi=length, orange=orange, 
pande=spread, plu=the(plural), plu-na=our, poteo=able, punkta=point/dot, 
purpura=purple, rubi=red, u-co=the latter, undu=wave.

-----------
plu-na akridi kroma skema pa es rubi e kloro  e mu es kontra alelo homoa or e 
oc. si na uti bi kroma para-do, mu fu es harmoni ko alelo. na posi uti u 
purpura fonda ko plu rubi litera "saluta" e pupura pro "na dice glosa". 
pluso, si na mixai melani ko alba, na sio gene polio e si na adi u pupura, na 
fu gene u hedo paci gentili kroma. nu, na adi sati melani a "saluta", id fu 
es skoto e ne-kompara ex u fonda. a u hetera litera na adi sati alba e id fu 
ne-kompara ko u fonda.

...............
adi=add, alba=white, alelo=each-other, akridi=acid, bi=two, dice=speak, 
fu=future, gene=get, gentili=gentle, harmoni=harmony, hedo=pleasant, 
hetera=other, id=it, ko=with, kontra=opposite, melani=black, mixai=mix, 
mu=they, ne-kompara=contrast, nu=now, pa=past-tense, paci=peace, 
para-do=next-door, pluso=also polio=grey, posi=perhaps, saluta=greetings, 
sati=enough/satisfy, si=if, sio=would, skema=scheme/plan, uti=use.  

----------------
pan es paci. qe na fu habe u pusi salia e piperi? face u verba "glosa" fo 
foto leuko-kloro - adi mega alba.  

.................
face=make, pan=all, piperi=pepper, pusi=small, salia=salt, qe=question,

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: [glosalist] Final vowels
From: "Marcel Springer" <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>
Date: Sat, 31 Mar 2001 23:58:23 +0200

Alexander pa grafo 01-03-27:
 > Poli Glosa-pe nu puta de problema de u fini vokali de plu Glosa 
 > verba.  Mi puta id habe u simpli solutio: Kron u verba ne kambia u 
 > semani ko hetero fini vokali id pote es ge-uti ko ali fini vokali. 

That is possible and not even wrong.  Wendy once wrote: "Ron ne pa 
pensi id es fo gravi-ra; ..." (see my glosalist-mail of 00-09-30).  
I personally do not like total freedom. 

I would like to have more words with -e.  They would be better to 
speak than -o, -i and -u. 

I like Syd's <ultima=penultima>-experiments.  They are half 
systematical and half aesthetical, as I understood.  I fear, in the 
end he will have more problems than before. 

The way, we SHOULD handle the final vowel problem, is clear and 
unspectacular: 
 1) Look in the Glosa books and use the words as they are! 
 2) If there are different ending vowels in different books, ask 
    Wendy, which is to prefer! 

I made a list of these cases ( www.glosa.org/en/gsimsyn.htm ) and sent 
it to Wendy.  She answered all on several papers.  So nearly all 
problems are solved.  Please be patient till I have put it all into 
our Glosa dictionary  (At the moment I am busy comparing the internet 
data with the book 'Glosa 6000'.). 

Who desired a systematical or even scientific method and words that 
are easier to learn, may be disappointed by this. 

A way that is WITHOUT WENDY and SCIENTIFIC, though in the SPIRIT of 
Glosa would look like this: 
Glosa uses international words.  It claims that there is to EVERY 
Glosa word at least ONE cognate in EACH of the following five 
languages: English, Spanish, French, German and Russian.  So we have 
to find all these cognates in these five languages and take the 
average vowel of them.  That is the way, Glosa wants to be. 


... Of course, this "average" vowel is not a trivial thing.  

Saluta - Marcel

Marcel Springer wrote:

> The way, we SHOULD handle the final vowel problem, is clear and
> unspectacular:
>  1) Look in the Glosa books and use the words as they are!
>  2) If there are different ending vowels in different books, ask
>     Wendy, which is to prefer!

Arbitrary and inextensible. Also anti-mnemonic for Europeans.
No system, therefore no justification for it.
I don't find the authors of Glosa credible as linguists
of either the scientific or polyglot sort; in other words,
no degree in linguistics, not much knowledge of the source langs.

What I like about Glosa is just the syntactic approach,
lack of morphology, and its approximation to Lingua Franca.
I consider it far from finished, needing an overhaul;
but the people qualified to fix it aren't interested, alas.

> Who desired a systematical or even scientific method and words that
> are easier to learn, may be disappointed by this.

How can this project, as-is, hope to succeed in the real world?
Even plain Esperanto is easier, because it has some system.

> A way that is WITHOUT WENDY and SCIENTIFIC, though in the SPIRIT of
> Glosa would look like this:
> Glosa uses international words.  It claims that there is to EVERY
> Glosa word at least ONE cognate in EACH of the following five
> languages: English, Spanish, French, German and Russian.  So we have
> to find all these cognates in these five languages and take the
> average vowel of them.  That is the way, Glosa wants to be.

IMO it should be sorta like that, and could evolve that way.
1950 Interglossa, 1980 Glosa, 2010 ???

Yes, I think there is an awkward self-overestimation in this point, 
that damages Glosa's reputation and so the spread of the language.  

Look what Wendy wrote to Alexander (see his email 01-02-11):  "Ron pa 
dice Ruso-lingua fo boni e fo amo tu lingua.  Mali-fortuna an ne pa 
habe pote de grafo tu alfabeta per an puta-me; seqe-co an ne pa proto 
u-ci [the translation of 'Glosa 6000'] ergo." - and she feels 
thoroughly convinced of it.  Their "Deutsch-Glosa 1000"-book is nearly 
unreadable and so I cannot believe, that Ron's Russian would have 
satisfied to write a whole book in it. 

But I do think, they were NOT totally stupid, they have more knowledge 
than me and they did put a lot of work into the Glosa words, more than 
there can be seen in their printed word lists.  Certainly a lot of 
errors in the vocabulary are redactional (language development faster 
than new editions of books) and so perhaps a problem of computer 
usage.  And finally do not forget, more problems are caused than 
solved by the science.  That makes non-scientific inventions likable. 


 > Arbitrary and inextensible. Also anti-mnemonic for Europeans.

Marcel Springer wrote:

> But I do think, they were NOT totally stupid

No, I don't think that either. They dropped morphology,
and that proved both revolutionary and workable.
Their work was as valuable as that of Hogben.

> they did put a lot of work into the Glosa words, more than
> there can be seen in their printed word lists.

Only someone who has tried to make a conlang knows
how difficult the task is, even using a computer.

> > No system, therefore no justification for it.
> 
> Can you please write a comment to this:

Interlingua of Peano had a word selection system
(and it determined final vowels nicely).
Interlingua of Gode has an algorithm to determine
international words. It is almost the same as
that of the earlier Occidental.

Esperanto began with a set of roots and affixes.
It was arbitrary but artistic and consistent. It proved
that less (rules and vocabulary) is more (learnable).

Interglossa had some guidelines for selecting vocabulary,
but it wasn't thorough. Glosa used the Roget's Thesaurus
plus whatever fill-in words occured to the authors.
Compared to other systems, it isn't adequate for use,
but *could* be revised using more modern techniques.

The EuroWordnet project compared vocabularies of several
European languages and identified their most important
shared concepts, much better than Roget:
http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/corebcs/topont.htm

As for English, a huge corpus of data was analyzed
to produce a word-frequency list by part-of-speech:
http://www.itri.bton.ac.uk/~Adam.Kilgarriff/bnc-readme.html
Notice especially his "lemmatized list" which generates
90% of all English vocabulary in actual usage.

I have come to believe, provisionally, that it is necessary
for a useful artificial language to have a base set of
approximately 3000 to 6000 *productive* words. It would
include "cat" but not "lion", because there are too many
specific names of things to give them all primary roots.
Glosa has no morphology, but every lang must have derivation.
So, "big cat", etc.

Interglossa originally had another good idea which has
been lost in Glosa: We don't need more than a very limited
number of verbs, perhaps only 20 to 100. This is valid
because most verbs (approximately 5000 in European languages)
are composed of a "light verb" that incorporates a noun
and/or direction. So factor them out, and things get simple
fast. Asian langs do this and work very efficiently.

But how to choose which base words are really needed?
I think it is necessary to rely on linguistic science today,
not personal artistic inspiration. Some weighted formula
involving EuroWordnet, BNC, even Roget, and/or other sources
can be tried out by computer and tested and adjusted.
Then it can be published and maintained in the future,
by some committee that will perpetuate Glosa.

It is also possible to design an algorithm matching
equivalent roots in many languages to the chosen concepts.
One could include ancient and modern languages and dialects.
Then maximize recognizability, pronounceability, etc,
by another open (public) algorithm.

This could be done, and should be, by trained linguists.
There are probably 10 available in the world, I even
know of 1 or 2. It has to adhere to the highest possible
standards of science and openness. I think the world
would welcome such an effort, and even use the language.
If a sufficient enthusiastic group of supporters were
to "demand" such a thing, I think it could happen.
(Until then, I prefer a different interlingue.)

Dear Charles,

Thank you for your interesting answer about word-derivation.


You wrote about Interglossa:

 > Interglossa originally had another good idea which has
 > been lost in Glosa: We don't need more than a very limited
 > number of verbs, perhaps only 20 to 100.  ...

Glosa has not lost it.  You can form lovely easy sentences with akti,
es, este, face, habe.  And this method is also good for longer
sentences to make clearer what is the verb.

But Glosa has also the possibility of strong verbs.  And therefore
you do not need a vocabulary extension because of the
no-part-of-speech-concept.  Stronger verbs give better style.  More
life comes in.  Interglossa was poison for poets.

So with Glosa you have both, and I like this hybrid.  But I am angry,
that Ashby and Clark refused to write a grammar.  So the older
Interglossa with its sentence-formulas seems to be clearer, easier and
more scientific than its follower.


------------
(Exempla de Reiners, Ludwig: Stilkunst [Art of Style], Munich 1943,
p. 139):
    Nach Aushebung einer Vertiefung liegt auch für den Urheber ein
    Stürzen im Bereich der Möglichkeit.
(Mi tenta translati):
    After out-lifting of a deepening there is also for the creator a
    falling in the area of possibility.
(The original: bible, Proverbs of Solomon 26, 27):
    Wer andern eine Grube gräbt, fällt selbst hinein.
    Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein.

From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>

>  > Interglossa originally had another good idea which has
>  > been lost in Glosa: We don't need more than a very limited
>  > number of verbs, perhaps only 20 to 100.  ...

> Glosa has not lost it.  You can form lovely easy sentences with akti,
> es, este, face, habe.  And this method is also good for longer
> sentences to make clearer what is the verb.

But that feature eliminated all confusion that results
from using vague verbs such as "to hammer"; one is forced
to say "use hammer" etc, which is clear and easy to read.

> But Glosa has also the possibility of strong verbs.  And therefore
> you do not need a vocabulary extension because of the
> no-part-of-speech-concept.

Well, there are always names and particles at a minimum.
Glosa uses "pa/nu/fu" etc excessively just to mark where the
subject ends and the verb begins. But I agree (now) that
eliminating Esperantish a/e/o POS was an improvement.

>  Stronger verbs give better style.  More
> life comes in.  Interglossa was poison for poets.

Poetry is certainly attested in natural pidgin/creoles.
When I try to write in Glosa the particles are awkward.
Strong verbs are an ambiguity-causing problem, IMO,
so I much prefer light verbs without tense particles.

> I am angry, that Ashby and Clark refused to write a grammar.

That problem is most easily remedied, because nobody would try
to stop you from writing one; but it's a bit of work ...

For instance, in English and Chinese the sentence is based on
the SV(O) pattern, but SV can be either transitive or intrans.,
as in "I dropped it, and it dropped (like a stone)".
I don't know which is correct in Glosa, but would guess
it's *different*, therefore English/Chinese speakers must
be taught the rule, or they will mangle it in practice.

Urdu/Hindi, Bengla looked very briefly at Welsh etc. I find learning other 
languages difficult and have tried to put myself into the shoes of a similar 
person without english and from India. Glosa so far is about the easiest lang 
 I've come across but partly because it is more or less english with 
different words used (and why not?) however my virtual indian other self 
would not find it so easy

so - pa fu and I suggest du for the present ( dura for continuous)
same with noun - u/plu - it has been suggested that we beg borrow steal em 
for beginning of direct object - I suggest per to introduce subject. some 
months ago, I loaded you all with something like that.
(per) un andro du dona (em) plu-r avi ad u gina.
(em) plu-r avi ad u gina per un andro du dona (like Hindi) .

At 15:53 02/04/2001 EDT, you wrote: 

>>>>

<excerpt><fontfamily><param>Times New
Roman</param><smaller>http://members.aol.com/sydpidd/eeee.htm 

http://members.aol.com/sydpidd/glosa-gramatika.htm 

sorry I don't use all this <<<<<<<<<< business - will learn sometime 

I've been thinking about glosa grammar for some time having done some 

Urdu/Hindi, Bengla looked very briefly at Welsh etc. I find learning
other 

languages difficult and have tried to put myself into the shoes of a
similar 

person without english and from India. Glosa so far is about the easiest
lang 

 I've come across but partly because it is more or less english with 

different words used (and why not?) however my virtual indian other self 

would not find it so easy 

I seem to need know where the verb phrase starts and ends and the head
word 

so - pa fu and I suggest du for the present ( dura for continuous) 

same with noun - u/plu - it has been suggested that we beg borrow steal
em 

for beginning of direct object - I suggest per to introduce subject. some 

months ago, I loaded you all with something like that. 

(per) un andro du dona (em) plu-r avi ad u gina. 

(em) plu-r avi ad u gina per un andro du dona (like Hindi) .
</smaller></fontfamily><fontfamily><param>arial</param> 

</fontfamily></excerpt><fontfamily><param>arial</param><<<<<<<<

Karo Amika,

    I did a beautiful reply all in Glosa ... but it was late and I must
have moused the wrong option,

because that reply has disappeared up some untraceable mouse-hole.

   In brief, I suggested that the designers of the mail program Syd uses
did a serious dis-service to the Net by bringing in numbers of vertical
stripes instead of continuing with the clear ">", ">>" etc, system.

   On grammar I tried to say there was a "signpost" system for both Noun
Phrases and Verb Phrases: a N.P. starts with a 'determinant' (u/plu) or a
numerator e.g. ~tri~, ~poli~, ~nuli,  and then fills in with more
substantial words leading to the final substantive "noun"; the V.P.
starting with a tense particle is clearly visible ... ending with the
substantive "verb."

   Trouble comes when there is NO tense particle needed (Simple Present
Tense), and there are no modifiers to indicate that we have a new phrase:
then the V.P. comprises only one word. 


  e.g.   Jon gresi in u parka.

           Jon, gresi in u parka, skope un avi.

           Jon, puta id fu habe gluko flavoro, pa bali u sagita ad un
avi.


  The "descriptive grammar" for Glosa, that I wrote from observation of
Ron and Wendy's prose, combined with my subjective ponderings, may have
got lost.  I think I put it on my website, but will send it to the
Glosalist as an attachment - next post - not as a definitive statement,
but as a point of continuation of the discussion.  

  The question proper formation of sentences in Glosa got the treatment
in my "Seminars" #1 and #2.  These seminars were prepared as a result of
a request, from Africa, for more guidance on the matter of sentence
formation; these were written at a time when Ron was opposed to the
writing of a "Grammar Book", stating that such a thing was unnecessary,
and would only serve to rigidify Glosa, and cause unwanted confusion to
its users.  

  My attempt to "describe" Glosa's grammar came as a result of subjective
frustration, and from taunts out of the Conlang Mailing List, that Glosa
had '''no grammar'''.  As it worked out, I made extensive use of
discussion, with the Conlangers, to refine the descriptive grammar
offered.


  Perhaps I should mention here my one significant addition to the
Linguists' lexicon.  Following much trial and error - with emphasis on
the latter - I finally coined a phrase to describe the style of grammar
found in Glosa: Glosa has 'syntax-based' grammar.  Needless to say such a
phrase is not (as yet) found in the Linguistic literature; however,
something like it will have to be 're-invented' if Glosa is ever to be
recognised by the Linguists, because it does not fit their pre-existing
categories.   Needless to say, well-written Chinese is syntax-based, and
so is 50% of English.


  While I'm at it, perhaps I should say that if Glosa's "grammar" does
depend on syntax, and that people with a better understanding of syntax
would write better Glosa than those who do not have this understanding,
then ... the "Rules of Syntax" will need to be 'taught' to
school-children learning Glosa!  There is only one problem, such syntax
rules do not seem to be available in the general alinguistic literature. 
This is only a small oversight, considering that Simon Pinker and others
researching children's learning of language, have strongly stated that
the one principle running through the learning of all languages is the
brain's hard-wired syntax system.  Some languages are closer to it, while
others are quite sophisticated, and a long way from 'natural syntax.'  If
Ron Clark had not been tapping into something fundamental to human
thinking, how could he have possible stated that Glosa could be used
without first ' ' learning' ' its grammar?

   The closest I have seen, in print, to the 'syntax-based' idea, is the
fairly recent definition of the grammar of English - under the heading,
Functional Grammar.  Of course, grammarians of English have to run two
sets of rule, in parallel, to cover both Latino/Germanic synthetic
grammar and the much simpler uninflected Early British forms.  Am I
unkind, or simply technically correct, in describing English as having a
"bastard grammar"?

   Nedless to say, the simple, uninflected strand of English grammar is
the one perpetuated through Glosa, and this can be observed in academic
fashion in the two "Seminars", the Glosa descriptive grammar and in the
attempt to record observed syntax, non-verbally,  in the GAS (gASCII
Analysed Syntax) system.


   Were we living in "Peace-time" I would spend much of my non-working
time in writing in, and about, Glosa.  However, living in a situation
where, like Columbus' sailors, we feel we are about to drop off the edge,
it is hard to ignore the possibility that soon there could be no
civilisation into which Glosa  might be introduced.  Sadly, I cannot turn
my back on the world, and say I'm doing my bit by perfecting Glosa for a
time when the world is ready for it.  If the right actions are not taken
now, the world might drop back into a New Dark Age, and never be ready
for Glosa.  I don't really know when I'll be back into full promotional
mode: it depends on the international situation.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

Robin Gaskell wrote:

> On grammar I tried to say there was a "signpost" system for both Noun Phrases and Verb Phrases: a N.P. starts with a 'determinant' (u/plu) or a numerator e.g. ~tri~, ~poli~, ~nuli, and then fills in with more substantial words leading to the final substantive "noun"; the V.P. starting with a tense particle is clearly visible ... ending with the substantive "verb."

nounphrases: (preposition) determiner (adjectives) noun
verbphrase: (auxiliaries) verb
sentence: nounphrase verbphrase (nounphrases)

> Trouble comes when there is NO tense particle needed (Simple Present Tense), and there are no modifiers to indicate that we have a new phrase: then the V.P. comprises only one word.

Those are simply ambiguous or awkward sentences.
There's no way to prevent "language abuse";
that's just part of learning.

> My attempt to "describe" Glosa's grammar came as a result of subjective frustration, and from taunts out of the Conlang Mailing List, that Glosa had '''no grammar'''.

Glosa has no inflectional grammar, which is the nastiest kind.

> Glosa has 'syntax-based' grammar. Needless to say such a phrase is not (as yet) found in the Linguistic literature;

Oh it is; they say that some language grammars rely more on morphology,
others on syntax. They'll never convict you; go ahead and use the phrase.

Not only that, but recently the linguists on sci.lang have admitted
that some languages are really truly 2 to 6 times easier than others.

> people with a better understanding of syntax would write better Glosa than those who do not have this understanding, then ... the "Rules of Syntax" will need to be 'taught' to school-children learning Glosa!

I think the best way is by example, after all. But not just easy
trivial ones. The longer sentences demonstrate more and better.
(However ... I still say Glosa's semicolons suck very badly!)

> Am I unkind, or simply technically correct, in describing English as having a "bastard grammar"?

I don't know, but most of Europe switched from SOV or VSO to basic SVO
since the year 1000 give or take a few centuries. The funny thing
about English is adjective-noun order instead of the reverse.
But it works, so Glosa hasn't chosen badly; especially since
compounds naturally follow the Greek order (e.g. "tele-phone").

> Were we living in "Peace-time"

I think we were, and that golden age (1992-2000) is past.
It's time to get working on the most important tasks.
I think that would be the development of machine intelligence;
language is a huge part of that problem. Maybe you should
reconsider whether Glosa might be part of your solution,
since it needs only a few people's help, but they are of
a very rare type, whereas political demonstrations are
mindless mass-mob things. Just my opinion, of course.

Written in .spg (g for glosa...), a heretical variant of glosa brutally 
simplified or being so done to make the variant easy for a beginner.

there are no caps, "q" of normali glosa becomes "ku", "x" becomes "ks" and 
"sc" becomes "x" - a little confusing for us old lags but easier for 
newcomers. 

verb phrases are introduced by "pa", "fu" and "du" (present tense) - noun 
phrases  by "u", "plu" or a number - the subject may be introduced by "per" 
and the object by "em"

Henry Doubleday Research Association is shortened to HDRA and, in, .spg, to 
.hdra - at the end is some info for Robin who might find HDRA interesting and 
thinking along similar lines to his own.

The pronunciation of .spg follows the that of .ita (international phonetic 
alphabet). the word stress is on the vowel just before the last consonant, 
any vowels in words of less than 4 letters are given their full value, 
otherwise the final vowel is free to be changed, smudged or glossed over etc 
but it is recomended that it heard.
 where the vowel at the end of a word is difficult to pronounce easily before 
the vowel at the beginning of some of the following words, a very brief flap 
of "r" can be inserted. instead of "u"/"un", "a"/"ad" etc we have "u (r) 
unda", "plu (r) unda", "a (r) unda" The .spg dictionary has been adjusted a 
little to allow for these recomendationa. 
The dictionary has been assembled by amalgamating G1000, and G6000 with 
Marcel and company's pretty comprehensive core dic. for beginners it is being 
rather ruthlessly  pruned.

a contribution about the cabbage root fly:-
 -----------------------------------------------------
  u .hdra du cerka de plu boni metodi de horti e id du kuestio plu-id 
grega-pe de face plu eksamina de plu varia tema.
-------------------------------------------------
The HDRA does search for the good methods of gardening and does ask its 
members to make investigations on various themes 
==============================================

to shorten the dictionaries, we use "ne " and "no" so "approximate" becomes 
"opposite"+"exact" = ne-eksakti, "ago"  "opp." + "to come" = "ne-avante"
we can have a scale from fo-boni, meso-boni, boni, pusi-boni, no-boni, 
pusi-ne-boni, ne-boni, meso-ne-boni, fo-ne-boni
very good,moderately good, good, slightly good, indifferent, slightly 
opposite to good=bad, etc

---------------------------------------
  ne-exakti 30 alo 40 anua ne-avanti, em plu mode pa cerka de ne-sti u 
ne-boni ex delia brasika (u bi ptera insekti kui agresi plu radi de u 
vora-fito, brasika ) ne-ko nece du ne-kolekti plu toxi epi plu fito alo solu. 
----------------------------------------
(not exact)=about 30 or 40 years (not in front)=ago a method was sought to 
(opposite of start)=stop the bad from cabbage root fly ( a 2 wing insect that 
attack the roots of the eat-plant, cabbage) not with= without need not 
collect=spread poison on plants and soil
======================================
here we have passive mood - (they) sought a method = a method was sought. the 
active mood object noun is brought to the front and the verb adjusted. glosa 
has a similar construction (ge-cerki) that has been criticised rather. The 
use of "em" obviated the need for it 

  **************************************
more heresies to follow

dear robin
you might be interested in HDRA (www.hdra.org.uk), I've been in it for many 
years as an organic gardener. They investigate environment friendly plant 
growing in England and other parts of the world (glosa could be useful to 
them perhaps), there are or were australian members. I had a letter from an 
australian member called Pidd asking whether I was a relation. At that time 
from what I could gather, I was not. They came fromm Fleet and later I 
learned that my forefathers also came from there.
syd 


--part1_25.138c9b01.28032faa_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] heresy corner
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> there are no caps

I like caps, but only for proper names and acronymns,
not for beginning sentences. But then sentences must be
separated by something more substantial than period-space.
Also I want something to show intonation, but I suppose
that's too difficult to systematize well.

> "q" of normali glosa becomes "ku", "x" becomes "ks" and 
> "sc" becomes "x" - a little confusing for us old lags but easier for 
> newcomers. 

Why not break up all consonant clusters, force all words
to 4 letters and have a pure CVCV root pattern? Once we decide
to phoneticize, there is no longer much recognize-ability
for eurolang speakers anyway, but it's easier for the world.

> verb phrases are introduced by "pa", "fu" and "du" (present tense) - noun 
> phrases  by "u", "plu" or a number - the subject may be introduced by "per" 
> and the object by "em"

Yes, make a full set of 10 or so prepositions, maybe 10 determiners,
auxiliaries, etc. Then set up a simple word menu to pick options
to build sample sentences. Looks good in HTML forms.

> the final vowel is free to be changed, smudged or glossed over etc 
> but it is recomended that it heard.

That's good if we can't restructure the whole vocab to eliminate
the problem by design. But there are projects that deliberately
designed all words to differ by more than the unstressed vowel.
But even better is the idea of repeating the previous vowel,
e.g. "fele, kana, musu".

Of course, making such radical changes really makes a new language.
I have a feeling this isn't going to happen.

> where the vowel at the end of a word is difficult to pronounce easily before 
> the vowel at the beginning of some of the following words, a very brief flap 
> of "r" can be inserted.

I prefer to eliminate roots beginning with vowels altogether.
If there were only 20 consonants and 5 vowels, that allows for
2000 CVCV roots. Adding 5 more consonants via digraphs
e.g. CH SH TH ND ST or some such, gives 3125. Adding a vowel
gives 2400. Both, 3750. Why shouldn't 2000 roots be enough?
Tunu (my linguist friend's conlang) needs only 1400.

> to shorten the dictionaries, we use "ne " and "no" so "approximate" becomes 
> "opposite"+"exact" = ne-eksakti, "ago"  "opp." + "to come" = "ne-avante"
> we can have a scale from fo-boni, meso-boni, boni, pusi-boni, no-boni, 
> pusi-ne-boni, ne-boni, meso-ne-boni, fo-ne-boni
> very good,moderately good, good, slightly good, indifferent, slightly 
> opposite to good=bad, etc

I agree, polarity affixes or roots are very good; you multiply
effective vocabulary at minimal cost. But there are other affixes
equally productive and necessary, e.g. English -ing -ed -ly -ish.
But how to apply these affixes, at the beginning or end?
Maybe it's best to use actual roots and simply compound them.
Then, "non-" becomes "nulu", and "un-" becomes "nege", etc.
And BTW, please give me a word for "e.g."!

> here we have passive mood - (they) sought a method = a method was sought. the 
> active mood object noun is brought to the front and the verb adjusted. glosa 
> has a similar construction (ge-cerki) that has been criticised rather. The 
> use of "em" obviated the need for it 

We could have true verbal voices such as passive and middle,
which are very productive. The verb phrase goes:
tense + aspect + mood + voice + mainverb. Most IALs fail
to distinguish tense from aspect (finished vs. continuing),
which is absolutely fatal in Asian countries.

> more heresies to follow

Excellent beginning!

Saluta, karo plu Glosa-pe
Mi nufu grafo in u English-Glosa mixa; ka mi ne pote grafo "linguistical
terms" in na lingua.
Mi pa lekto u boni libro de English gramatika, e mi pa trovi u skema de
"English syntax".
Mi pa kompara id kon u Glosa "word order" de "18 steps".
English    Glosa
SUBJECT    SUBJECT
VERB    VERB
INDIRECT OBJECT   DIRECT OBJECT
DIRECT OBJECT    INDIRECT OBJEKT
PREPOSITIONAL OBJECT

So, vi pote vide; in Glosa "indirect object" sempre habe"preposition", e
"indirect object" de Glosa es u "prepositional object" de English-lingua.

Saluta,
Alexander.

Syd, PLEASE don't post any more using that horrible
broken email reader ... It is difficult to read
and difficulter to reply to your posts!!!!
Use anything else. Ask somebody to go through
the config params -- life is too short to decrypt
these every time, even though they are interesting:

> it seems to me that most if not all of the major languages have the 4 parts, 
> subject NP, verb P, object P and indirect O.  some of these may not be used 
> i.e. subject NP, VP " they went" the NP I've called the O/IO may be 
> substituted by something else such as an adjectP "they sang beautifully". Is 
> this true?  answers from the most erudite of you will be welcome.
> Where things get difficult is how the parts are marked, suffixes word order 
> etc, are there any variations?
> syd

All the eurolangs were once heavily suffixing ("synthetic"
and "inflectional"), but gradually they replaced the suffixes
with prepositions to become more "analytic" and "isolating".
Germanic languages have evolved furthest in that direction.

Glosa was intended as a purely analytic/isolating language,
more so than all the other auxlangs. So there are *no* more
case suffixes, just prepositions like "de, ad, ...".

As you mentioned, there is no suffix defined for accusative case
(nominative = "per") but something like "em" could work; otherwise
there is nothing but word order defining those "core cases";
and most of the time, word order is perfectly sufficient.

nominative, ablative      ... first noun phrase, or "per"
accusative, direct object ... second NP, or maybe "em"
dative, indirect object   ... "ad"
genitive, possessive      ... "de"

Those are the core cases; other important cases are "oblique".

Then there are a bunch of other prepositions, too many!
In a truly simple global auxlang, these would be reduced
by composing them out of in/ex/ad/de and just a few more,
e.g. "intra xxx = in middle of xxx".

All languages are similar after all, they just vary in a
relatively few "parameters" such as whether to use mostly
suffixes or prepositions. To make 2nd language learning easy,
an auxlang must be highly regular with few exceptions,
and express many different shades of meaning with the fewest
"pieces", whether words or grammar rules. Ido and Glosa use
nearly opposite approaches, Occidental combines both ...

For a true global interlanguage, no currently existing project
really works, IMO. The ideal would have a much more productive
but smaller vocabulary than Glosa, and an even easier syntax.
I see Glosa as unfinished, and use Occ effectively with Europeans.
The ideal interlanguage would be highly analytical/isolating,
abandoning all suffixes, a further development of Glosa perhaps.
But it would look more like Indonesian or Tahitian. IMHO!

Stating that capitals are purely cosmetic might be OK.
There are some important discourse functions to consider though:
Proper names like Henry, China; acronyms like NATO, UN.
Emphasis like I can't *believe* they *eat* that.
The miniscules are generally more readable but you could
use small caps instead, to minimize learning effort.

Reducing the unneeded letters is also a very good idea.
Q W X Y should disappear. Also, H J Z are candidates.
Any reform of Glosa should carefully consider Frater:
http://www.smart.net/~bartlett/frater2.html

>      B : bilabial stop, voiced
>      D : dental or alveolar stop, voiced
>      F : labio-dental or bilabial fricative, unvoiced
>      G : velar stop, voiced
>      J : linguo-alveolar fricative, voiced (sibilant)
>      K : velar stop, unvoiced
>      L : linguo-alveolar lateral
>      M : bilabial nasal, voiced
>      N : dental or alveolar nasal, voiced
>      P : bilabial stop, unvoiced
>      R : linguo-palatal retroflex glide or trill
>      S : linguo-alveolar fricative, unvoiced (sibilant)
>      T : dental or alveolar stop, unvoiced

For a global IAL, *much* thought should be given to
ease of pronunciation. The easiest of all is Tunu:
http://members.aol.com/manishtusu/tunu.html

Consider that French/Spanish/Portuguese/etc never
will pronounce an H. Orientals will mix L with R.
Right now without thinking, say "Rosa says so" ...
you said 2 Z's and 2 S's. The choice is to make just
another european greco-latin mix, or a global IAL.

A reasonable phonology *can* please the vast majority.
To see just how common the various consonants are:
http://www.srv.net/~ram/phonology.html

At 15:59 30/04/2001 +0400, Alexander grafo:

>Saluta, karo plu Glosa-pe

>Mi nufu grafo in u English-Glosa mixa; ka mi ne pote grafo "linguistical

>terms" in na lingua.

>Mi pa lekto u boni libro de English gramatika, e mi pa trovi u skema de

>"English syntax".

>Mi pa kompara id kon u Glosa "word order" de "18 steps".

>English    Glosa

>SUBJECT    SUBJECT

>VERB    VERB

>INDIRECT OBJECT   DIRECT OBJECT

>DIRECT OBJECT    INDIRECT OBJEKT

>PREPOSITIONAL OBJECT

>

>So, vi pote vide; in Glosa "indirect object" sempre habe"preposition", e

>"indirect object" de Glosa es u "prepositional object" de English-lingua.

>

>Saluta,

>Alexander.

>

*Plu Amika,

   Ci Alexander ski u semani de an plu verbi, sed mi nece vide plu exempla de plu-ci abstrakti termi, pre mi pa logi u situa.


   Per skope plu pagina de u _Collins Cobuild English Grammar_ mi nu logi qod Alexander dice.


EG

  Tom pa don a Jon tri dolari te merca an sito.

 (Tom did give to Jon three dollar in order to buy his food]

  Tom   gave     Jon  three dollars     to buy     his food.

           

          no-direkti  direkti objekti   pre-positi minor verbi grega   

            objekti  


   So, per elipsi, u pre-positi de u England-lingua No-direkti Objekti gene ge-lose.


   E koncerne u relatio positi de plu bi objekti, mi skope un alterno seqe es pluso posi in plu bi lingua.


EG

  Tom pa don tri dolari a Jon so an pote merca an sito.

 (Tom did give three dollar to Jon so he can buy his food]

  Tom   gave  three dollars to Jon (with which) to buy his food.


U-ci sekunda forma dona ma dificili tem uti bi intra Glosa e England linga.  Pluso, pro boni expresi, mi pa este u nece de uti plu alterna verbi intra bi un England-lingua e u Glosa versio.


  Posi, il es u generali regula, iso Alexander sugere, sed mi vo vide ma exempla pre forma u decide.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sat, 19 May 2001 14:04:40 -0700

Marcel Springer wrote:

> The dictionary files on my website have been uploaded again

Cool! Now I'm looking through this page:
http://www.glosa.org/gid/gwds.htm

: All you have to do to form your own MegaGlosa
: is to be able to recognize a Latin and Greek root.
: Most of the common ones will be listed in Glosa 1000,
: the others will be in Glosa 6000.

:        Prefix - root - suffix.
:   Eg.  SUPER     FLU     OUS
:
: Remember Glosa has no parts of speech;
: and any Glosa word can act as any part of speech.
: Because the suffix is usually concerned with
: this kind of information, whether the word is verb,
: noun, adjective or adverb it is usually superfluous
: for Glosa and can be removed. 

OK, so all the Latin super-productives are *in*,
officially: RE-FLU-x, Ef-FLU-ent, IN-FLU-ence, etc.

Moreover, all "classical" roots are included. Wow!
The authors were more liberal than I ever dreamed.

: If the Prefix is one with a distinct meaning
: i. e. one of the 35 listed in PGN 36
: this must be retained as it contributes to meaning,
: to information. So generalizing; 
:
:    Word minus suffix = Prefix + root.
:
: the word you want. In the above example the root is FLU,
: to flow, SUPER over; therefore SUPERFLU, overflow. In a way
: forming a Mega Glosa Vocabulary involves 'tail-chopping'. 

So all my arguing way-back-when was "superflu" because
Glosa already accepted these things. We are still left
with the minor but annoying problem of final vowels:

: Many verbs of Latin origin end in -ate. All you have to do
: here is knock off the -te. confiscate becomes KONFISKA. 

: Some words ending -age are of French origin.
: These can be kept giving MESAGE, FOLIAGE. 

What I learn from this is that the authors don't care
much about the final vowels, they just aren't important;
any d**ned thing is good enough.

There are collisions between e.g. Latin BAL=dance and
Greek BAL=throw, but life is too short to worry about it;
natural languages all have homonyms but don't fail to work.

On that basis, half the reforms I thought necessary
for Glosa to work as an IAL, are already done.

Saluta!

>it seems to me that most if not all of the major languages have the 4
parts,
>subject NP, verb P, object P and indirect O.  some of these may not be used
>i.e. subject NP, VP " they went" the NP I've called the O/IO may be
>substituted by something else such as an adjectP "they sang beautifully".
Is
>this true?  answers from the most erudite of you will be welcome.
This is really difficult question, and I'm not the most erudite:)
But I think we cannot use in Glosa postverb adjective in order to make
pseudo-adverb.
We must use preverb adjective for this reason: I cannot say in Glosa: Mi ski
id boni. for "I know it goodly" (It seems to be not-correct in English too),
but Mi boni ski id is much better variant. They sang beautifully = mu pa
beli soni, isn't it?
> Where things get difficult is how the parts are marked, suffixes word
order
>etc, are there any variations?
In Russian the parts marked by suffixes and endings, in English by the place
in sentence and by suffixes and endings, in Glosa by the place in sentence.

Alex.

Syd wrote:

> > i.e. subject NP, VP " they went" the NP I've called the O/IO may be
> > substituted by something else such as an adjectP "they sang beautifully".

Alexander E. Kirpichev wrote:

> But I think we cannot use in Glosa postverb adjective in order to make pseudo-adverb.
> We must use preverb adjective for this reason: I cannot say in Glosa: Mi ski
> id boni. for "I know it goodly" (It seems to be not-correct in English too),
> but Mi boni ski id is much better variant. They sang beautifully = mu pa
> beli soni, isn't it?

> In Russian the parts marked by suffixes and endings, in English by the place
> in sentence and by suffixes and endings, in Glosa by the place in sentence.

The obsolete English grammars use the term "adverb" for some
very different purposes. I think we must distinguish at least 2:

1st "adverb", as an adjective modifier: "a VERY big mistake".
2nd "adverb", as a sentence modifier: "she walked SLOWLY".

>From the glosaref I only found one example, showing that
the authors followed the English pattern as usual:

:: They spoke at the same moment = My pa dice iso-kron.

But "auxiliaries" (fu, pa, etc) precede the verb.
This us the usual pattern in most languages, i.e.
aux on one side of the verb, manner-adverbs on the other.

To disambiguate manner adverbs from objects, add prepositions:
"slowly = in a slow way = at slow speed = with slowness".

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> Hindi/Urdu doesn't have caps and they use proper names ......
> how about "pe henry", "landa china",  " .nato .un ",  ".b.e.l.i.e.v.e  .e.a.t 

> sorry, small caps would need learning just as large ones also small cap "c" 
> would look like lc "c" 

I think a certain amount of typographical prettyiness is justified
by its making text much more readable, justifying increased time
of learning the alphabet. Time of learning vocabulary is 100 times
more, so I'd prefer to optimize learning time *there*.

> is there any reason why you use * where  I use " ? 

I use the asterisks in the conventional usenet manner,
like *this*, only to indicate emphasis like boldface type.
Quote marks and some other punctuation are indispensible.
Too much ambiguity in speech otherwise, or else painful
attempts to include too many particles and qualifiers.

> Shall get visual basic to adjust my .nng dic to one without "h,j,q,w,y etc" 

Eliminating troublesome letters entirely is very good.

> also a .lrg "lip-reading G"

What's that?

>Tom gave Jon three dollars to buy his food.

>objekti

Mu es posi, sed ne fo boni pro mi.
>EG
>Tom pa don tri dolari a Jon so an pote merca an sito.
>(Tom did give three dollar to Jon so he can buy his food]
>Tom gave three dollars to Jon (with which) to buy his food.
