I've made a glosa dictionary for nng
it omits h,j,q,w,x,y,z -h is ignored, j becomes i, q =ku,w and y were not in 
glosa anyway, x=ks and z becomes s. Final vowels are simplified where 
possible. There are some other bits of pruning and there are more in the 
pipeline. I've been trying to get it as a web page but AOL or something won't 
play ball - shall keep trying 
however I shall include the dictionaries as attachments ! !!!!!!!!!!!!!
WARNING............ they are about 5500 lines long so they may be slow 
getting to you    don't download them if you don't want a long wait - if you 
do, let me know how long they take so that I can see whether it's worthwhile 
using the method
 
working on a grammar at the moment as I think that, in spite of what our 
revered leadres say, it is needed
syd

At 09:21 11/06/2001 -0700, you wrote:

>

>Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

>

>> Hindi/Urdu doesn't have caps and they use proper names ......

>> how about "pe henry", "landa china",  " .nato .un ",  ".b.e.l.i.e.v.e  .e.a.t 

>

>> sorry, small caps would need learning just as large ones also small cap "c" 

>> would look like lc "c" 

>

>I think a certain amount of typographical prettyiness is justified

>by its making text much more readable, justifying increased time

>of learning the alphabet. Time of learning vocabulary is 100 times

>more, so I'd prefer to optimize learning time *there*.

>

*   Must add that the reason I got so deeply into Glosa was because it was basically recognisable to those with a knowlege of the Roman alphabet and the Classical vocabularies of literature and science.

    So, I am not really a minimalist when it comes to letters.  And, for example, I was a little perplexed that a satisfying sound like the 'j' of "John" was angled out of Glosa.


>Eliminating troublesome letters entirely is very good.

>

*   I did not think of letters as being a trouble.  The fact that Glosa's pronunciation was to be with Italianate vowels, and generally Middle European consonants did limit the sound range a little, but just about all of the letters seemed necessary, when the Glosa authors started scraping to find ways of allowing a width of vocabulary into the language, while maintaining, as well as possible, the ideal of brevity in the spelling.


>> also a .lrg "lip-reading G"

>

>What's that?

>

*   Sounds interesting, and should be significant for the deaf, but I suspect that a serious research schedule, for Glosa, could be worked out, so that the development work was done in a sequential fashion, each part building on the foundation of past research.  However, since Glosa has had to use the particular skills and qualities of individual enthusiasts, there has been little scheduled research ... apart from that of the authors. 


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

dear robin
as a linguist I'd make a tolerable bricklayer! 
memory like a seive worse confounded by irregular spelling/grammar and so on 
- how I ever managed english I don't know - being born here must have helped. 
Went back to French, tried German and  Greek but lost patience - tried 
Esperanto and got on better but not happy with the vocabulary tried 
Urdu/Hindi found these much easier apart from the Urdu spelling where they 
left out vowels wholesale - found Glosa - Heaven!
Easy, regular you know the rest.
However, why was it so easy for me? its words were familiar to the posher 
ones in English - pote-potential, posi-possible, facili-facility, 
grafo-graphics etc, its grammar (we are told absent) was in fact English 
grammar and its pronunciation Italian. This is fine for Europeans most of 
whom seem to be quite at home in my mother tongue - to learn Glosa, first 
learn English, a bit of Italian opera and  a botany text book but if you are 
from far away in asia it is rather different

For my experiments in .nng and they are only experimental, I imagined I was 
asian, knew no language but my own and had a dictionary in it and english. I 
incorporated suggestions from rather more expert members of glosalist than I 
am. I don't know that I agree completely with them but one can't find out 
things without trying. It is not intended to rival Glosa or anything else.

.lrg for the deaf and lip readers crossed my mind as I have some hearing 
difficulties and find lip reading very very hard. The vowels should be easy 
enough and it is not too trying to decipher b,c,th, f,l,m,p, v.
my alphabet could be like this:-
b=b> (> means lips forward), d=dh>, f=f<(lips drawn in), g=cc(long c), 
k=dhdh, l=l>, m=mm, n=[w],p=p<, r=l<,s=vv,t=th<, v=v>     just a little 
passing curiosity but might turn out helpful one day

syd






--part1_97.16dbf44e.285bb1dc_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 from Robin:-
<   I have not dropped out of Language Research, but am just taking a detour 
through details of the democratic process.


<    Before we can get people to think of talking to one another, we need a 
world that is receptive to sensible ideas: there's a long way to go, yet.

(.nng)
na sio spe, u-la-teme il fu es u sufici de plu ko-sense putu pa-evolvo te 
cepte mu e glosa fu es mo de mu. il du sio es u ma bono si na du sio probo, 
eksperimente, arga e, su pana, utu plu-co putu omo u glosa vici te atende 
a-krono plu putu du es nece e du disipi u erge u-la-tem.
 kue tu du akordo?

(mng = ma norma glosa)
Na sio spe, u-la kron il fu es mega de plu sensi idea ge-developo de es cepti 
e Glosa fu es mo de mu. Il sio ma-boni de examina, experimenta, disputa e, 
supra pan, uti plu idea homo Glosa de atende a kron mu es nece e disipa tem 
ergo epi mu u-la kron. 
Qe tu akorda?
        
(E)
hopefully, by then there will be plenty of sensible ideas developed to be 
receptive to and glosa will be one of them. it would be better to be testing, 
experimenting, arguing and above all using ideas like glosa than waiting 
until they are needed and wasting time working on them then.
Do you agree?

First, Robin said:

> Before we can get people to think of talking to one another,
> we need a  world that is receptive to sensible ideas:
> there's a long way to go, yet.

Then, Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> hopefully, by then there will be plenty of sensible ideas developed to be 
> receptive to and glosa will be one of them. it would be better to be testing, 
> experimenting, arguing and above all using ideas like glosa than waiting 
> until they are needed and wasting time working on them then.
> Do you agree?

As I see this world, it is a place where people, often disagreeing
or disagreeable, all work simultaneously on problems great and small.
Waiting for some to be solved before starting work on the others is
sometimes advisable but more often not. A more organized approach might
seem more reasonable but really just encourages fascist centralized
control. Americans know one thing above all others: that democracy and

As you know, I don't look unkindly on
tinkering with languages, even if these
are published and copyrighted. After all,

that is almost an off-shoot of Latino
sine flexione, in theory. I would say that
it is a good thing for glosa to see it
being discussed and tinkered with, it
gives it life. Natural languages are
tinkered with in teenagers' mouths
every generation.

most of the following could apply to mormal glosa
u[j] undu gets rid of "un"
a[j] undu gets rid of "ad"
plu[j] undu fits the rule and is more regular and simple than mormal glosa
u kremna/un undu/a kremna/ad undu/plu undu!/plu kremna


plu vokala du poto aranga in u spektru ome plu kromo de u lumu. si "a" du es 
in u mese, plu "e" e "i" du es a mo latu e plu "o" e "u" du es a u etero. 
 
The vowels can be arranged in a spectrum like the colours of light. If "a" is 
in the middle, "e" and "i" would be on one side and "o" and "u" on the other

i e a o u

"i", "e" and "a" are spoken with wide apart mouth corners and "o" and "u" 
with rounded and narrow mouth.
"a" has a mouth opened widely vertically, "i" and "u" have a mouth more 
closed vertically. Also, as we move from "a" to "i", the tongue moves closer 
to the roof of the mouth. We can extend the spectrum beyond "i" and the flow 
of air between the tongue and roof becomes more restricted to make the sound 
[j], further, the tongue and roof press together to stop the flow altogether 
and the sound "c" is started. At the other end of this spectrum, as the mouth 
closes we get the sounds [w] and [b]

[c j i e a o u w b]

  difficult sound combinations

Although [j] and [w] are not in the nenege  set of sounds we can make use of 
them. If there are two vowels next to each other that are not easy to speak 
they can be separated by [j] and [w], [aj-], [ej-], [ij-], [ow] and [uw-]
In the similar case of two consonants we could use a vowel that is mid way 
between [i] and [a] or [u] and [a] and also mid way between [e] and [o]. The 
vowel is called "schwa" and is represented by an upside-down small "e". This 
is not on my keyboard so I cannot display it "ekte" might sound like "ek[]te" 
by some speakers. "adverte ekte" might sound like "ad[]verte j 
ek[]te"........

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] saluta encore
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> glosalist seems very quiet!

Yup.

> I have changes my PC from W95 to W98 and hope to have left the gobbledygook 
> behind!

Nope.

> I should like to know how common the English's passive mood is in 
> other languages. Someone in the New Scientist was asking students to avoid PM 
> and use active mood more. To avoid much use of "I" and "we", the two pronouns 
> could be ommitted - "I mixed acid..." could become "mixed acid...." similarly 
> Glosa could do without "ge-" ..........

That is a classic problem for auxlangs. As I understand it, the cause
is a conflict between two desires: to put the most important thing first
in the sentence, versus the semantic agent or cause of the action:

The MOUSE fell.        <---- nominative case, non-agentive, active voice
The mouse WAS droppED. <---- same semantically, but passive voice
The mouse was dropped BY the cat. <---- passive, with oblique agent
The cat dropped the MOUSE.        <---- active, with accusative patient
The cat dropped the mouse TO the floor. <---- now add an oblique location

In each instance, the subject is the thing of most importance.
Where the voice is active, the subject is formally an agent;
where passive, a "patient" (which I won't even try to define).
It is a great simplification to always use a preposition for
oblique cases, even the English "indirect object". But we still
must distinguish whether the subject is agent or patient.

You suggest eliminating the fronted "nominative" case, which would be
quite radical in Glosa; then the pre-verbal noun is automatically
an agent/ergative and the post-verbal is a patient/accusative.
Another alternative would be to add explicit prepositions for the
ergative ("per"?) and accusative ("em"?) cases, leaving none unmarked.

All of these methods have been used successfully in natural languages.
But the boring nominative/accusative style (with "ge-") is most common,
especially in Europe, so I think we're stuck with it.

sent a mail to my son who had no problems, shall join freeserve and send 
stuff to myself there and also from there ..........
here is some stuff in .nng :-

nenege libele mo;

per-u .edra du cerke de plu ma bono e ma naturu metodo te orti .

bono=good (adjective -metodo)
cerke=search (head of VP)
de= of etc
du starts VP present tense
e=and
.edra= HDRA= Henry Doubleday Research Association
ma=more (adverb with adj bono/naturu)
metodo=method (head of NP)
naturu=nature/natural
orti=garden (head VP)
per-u=a/the, starts subject NP
plu=a/the plural
te starts VP no tense

nenege libele bi;
u .edra du cerke de plu ma bono e ma naturu metodo te orti .
u=a/the singular
the NP before the VP is the subject unless otherwise signalled, the object 
will usually follow the VP.

Glosa when written by me......
U H.D.R.A. du cerke de plu ma bono e ma naturu metodo te horti.
Cosmetic capitals are used, I keep the NNG final vowels as many of them are 
free anyway in Glosa (I've seen "verba" and "verbe" for instance) and I use 
"du" to mark the VP as I've quite often found Glosa hard to decypher without 
the marker. Recently "ergo" could have been N or V in one sentence and the 
sentence needed a certain amount of thought to clarify. "pa cerke" or "fu 
cerke" would have been quick and easy.

English;
HDRA is searching for better and more natural methods of gardening.


passive will come up ere long........

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] New home for glosalist archives
From: William W Patterson <ailanto{at}neosplice{dot}com>
Date: Thu, 02 Aug 2001 19:28:59 -0400
Cc: m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de


NBCi, which took over Xoom some time back, has decided not to provide
webspace anymore. Of course, they didn't bother to inform their members;
I just had so much trouble, even more than usual, uploading the latest
files, that I decided to browse around their pages to see if I could
find out why I had been getting the message "Try again in an hour"
for the last 24 hours. Finally clicking on the link advertising their
website services to prospective members, I learned that they *don't*
provide website services anymore, as of a couple of weeks ago. And that
uploads are now prohibited, so what's there is all that will ever be
there, until they wipe the directories... and I can't even put up a
redirect page!

Oh well, I guess I saw this coming. Xoom/NBCi has been pretty flaky for
a long time (if I had used them regularly I would have dropped them a
long time ago, but the only thing I had there was the glosalist archives
and I only update those once a month), and I'd read rumors a few months
ago that they were considering such a move, and that's why I created
a mirror of the archives back then. Now the mirror will become *the*
archive site. (The old site still exists, but can't be updated, and will
disappear.)

The new link for the archive is:

   http://www.kafejo.com/lingvoj/auxlangs/glosa/archives

By the way, the Exercise program is here now (the old page points to
this one):

   http://www.kafejo.com/lingvoj/auxlangs/glosa/exercise

- Saluta!, Bill


-- 
William W. Patterson
http://ttt.kafejo.com

Iste message esseva reinviate al Glosalist.
Ci grama pa ge-re-mite ad u Glosalista.
Per favor, reinvia lo al AUXLANG.
Place re-mite id ad AUXLANG.

Io respondera in le lingua del question.
Mi fu responde in u lingua de u qestio.

Car Kjell,
> Pote un persona explicar me, le ration pro -a in
> parolas (verbos) como "na" = nos; urba = urbe,
> citate?
>
> Exemplo: Lase na ki ad urba.
> Lassa nos ir al urbe!
Io pensa, que on usa -a in "na", nam isto es radice Indo-Europee (r. nas,
nash, esp. nosotros. fr nous(?)), e si on usava "o", e post elemination de
"s" nos haberea le parola "no".
Re "urba" nos sape, que in multe parolas international on usa urbA, ma 'a'
es un parte de sfx. pro ex.: urban, urbanization, sed tamen gratias al sfx.
es le plus bon littera pro memorization.

Amicalmente,
Alexander.

Esperanto "kaf-ej-o" = Glosa "kafa-lo" (usually "cafe" or
"coffeehouse" or "coffeeshop", but generally speaking could
be any place that has something to do with coffee, according
to context I suppose.)

> "gossip". Qe es ka-ra de u-ci ra?
Qe tu ski; Glosa habe 2 diktionaria? Il es Mega-Glosa e Centra-Glosa. CG
habe plu qotdia verba, qi pote face plu nova verba. MG habe ma verba de CG,
qi pote ge-uti in literatura, politika etc. Si tu ski, Lomonossov pa face
tal sistema pro (MG) ruso-lingua (o CG Russkij-lingua).

Saluta,
Alexander.

> Gratia de tu explika. Mi ne es certa; mi logi ultima-ra de ruso-lingua. Mi
> ski; Lomonossov pa-inventi u-grazhdanka-alfa-beta-ra.
Mi grafo de sistema de uti de u ruso-lingua in literatura. U sistema habe
nomina "3 shtilja" (shtilj in antiqi ruso pa semani stilo, nu u verba es
"stilj"). Lomonossov pa dice; u qotdia ruso-lingua es u baso (nizkij) stilo
pro plu burleska literatura, u serioso ruso-lingua es u meso stilo pro ma
serioso literatura, e u ruso-lingua kon un eklesia-(slavika?) lingua es alti
stilo pro fo serioso literatura.
> U-ci-pe pa fo remarki-digni pe.
JA.

Saluta,
Alexander.

To: Glosalist <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: [glosalist] Sending Posts As Attachments
From: "Paul O. Bartlett" <bartlett{at}smart{dot}net>
Date: Wed, 8 Aug 2001 10:23:50 -0400 (EDT)

    (Sorry that this is not in Glosa)

    May I make a suggestion?  Please do not send a post as nothing but
attachments rather than as part of the message itself.  For some mail
agents, this becomes a bother.  Also, if a post is sent as both plain
text and HTML, it is needlessly sent twice, taking up resources.  It
risks causing some people to incur extra expense if they have to pay
by quantity.  Plain text will do just fine.

to a list like this.

a link to it.

Subject: Re: [glosalist] Sending Posts As Attachments
From: "Paul O. Bartlett" <bartlett{at}smart{dot}net>
Date: Sun, 12 Aug 2001 19:11:28 -0400 (EDT)

On Sun, 12 Aug 2001, Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> could you tell me the maximum length in words, approx, would an simple 
> message be - no fancy type, no attachments, no pretty pictures - before it 
> would become expensive to read etc?
> I seem to be finding the most inconvenient ways of emailing - i shall learn 
> eventually
> syd   

    It is not only a matter of length.  It is *how* the message is
sent.  Because a sender has no control over what sort of mail agents
other people have, and because dfferent mail agents have different
capabilities, the very safest method is simply to send a message as
plain text -- no attachments, no HTML, no pictures, etc.  That way just
about everyone can read it.  Even if people have HTML-enabled mail
agents, sending a message as both plain text and as HTML is wasteful,
because the message in effect is sent twice, consuming resources
needlessly.  If you have something in a special format, it is best to
post a notice and send it to those who request it or to put it on an
ftp or www site and post the URL.

-- 
Regards,
Paul Bartlett

    Incidentally, sid, your posts are coming across, at least to my mail
server, as nothing but attachments in two forms (text and HTML), which
make them harder to read, at least for me.  (Perhaps others do not have
the same difficulty.)

On Wed, 15 Aug 2001, Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> [...]
>    There are one or two small things I should like to see changed. On the 
> whole, I think that if G could get itself more widely known, with a larger 
> body of works and a little more streamlined, it would compare favourably with 
> any of the others.

    There is always the issue of "reformitis."  One person's necessary
feature is another person's fatal flaw.  For those who have not read
it, I will blow my own horn and refer to my essay, "Thoughts on IAL
Success" at http://www.smart.net/~bartlett/thoughts.html
One of the points I make is the necessity for a stable base if any IAL
is to go anywhere.  Of tinkering there is no end.  I can see, after
some time of trial use, perhaps one major reform, as with Ido and
Esperanto -- or with Interglossa and Glosa (and I am sorry that
Interglossa never got a real trial; I just acquired a copy) -- but
otherwise eventually the tinkering has to stop.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

New to Glosa.  
For an auxilliary language to really work shouldn't the vocabulary be 
streamlined?
6000 seems like too much.


   I thought I would lurk a bit to see if anything was going on in


Glosa-land.  I wasn't sure whether I was having trouble with my email,
so I sent a test message.  According to "Glosa 6000," 'proba' means
"test, trial."  Lack of consistent vocabulary lists has always been a
problem for would-be Glosa-pe and others.

    Recently I acquired a copy of "Interglossa," and I realize how 
much A&C "pulled" the language in the direction of merely almost a
relexified English, in which case just teach people real English.  (I
see this especially in the use of Glosa by native anglophones.)  I am
beginning to think that Hogben had a better idea all along.  It's too
bad that Interglossa never got a serious trial.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

On Fri, 17 Aug 2001, Robin Gaskell wrote:

> At 21:06 31/07/2001 -0400, Paul Bartlett wrote:
> >Proba

> *   Thanks Paul,
>     But it is more of a puzzle than a message!?

    I thought I would lurk a bit to see if anything was going on in
Glosa-land.  I wasn't sure whether I was having trouble with my email,
so I sent a test message.  According to "Glosa 6000," 'proba' means
"test, trial."  Lack of consistent vocabulary lists has always been a
problem for would-be Glosa-pe and others.

    Recently I acquired a copy of "Interglossa," and I realize how 
much A&C "pulled" the language in the direction of merely almost a
relexified English, in which case just teach people real English.  (I
see this especially in the use of Glosa by native anglophones.)  I am
beginning to think that Hogben had a better idea all along.  It's too
bad that Interglossa never got a serious trial.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

On Sat, 18 Aug 2001, MGxcr{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> 
> New to Glosa.  
> For an auxilliary language to really work shouldn't the vocabulary be 
> streamlined?
> 6000 seems like too much.
> 
> [my original remarks omitted]

    This has been a matter of some disagreement among proponents of
Glosa.  Hogben's original Interglossa had a vocabulary of approximately
880 words (I would have to refresh the exact number) which were
operated, so to speak, in a manner rather different from current Glosa. 
Originally there were lists of "Glosa 1000" by which it was claimed
that, apart for specific names of specific things (such as local flora
and fauna), one could say whatever needed to be said.  (My
characterization.)  Unfortunately, there were various lists of "Glosa
1000" which were not entirely consistent among themselves.  However,
there are those who think that a vocabulary of 1000 is too limiting. 
Clark and Ashby did publish a list of "Glosa 6000," and in recent times
there has been some discussion about an appropriate size for the Glosa
vocabulary.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

I'm not a linguist either and don't pretend to understand a lot of what you 
said, but it sounds to me that Interglosa is a superior conlang. Why doesn't 
someone revive it?

In a message dated 8/19/2001 6:26:52 PM Eastern Daylight Time, 
bartlett{at}smart{dot}net writes:


> Subj: Re: [glosalist] Proba
> Date: 8/19/2001 6:26:52 PM Eastern Daylight Time
> From:    bartlett{at}smart{dot}net (Paul O. Bartlett)
> Reply-to: <A HREF="mailto:glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au">glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au</A>
> To:    glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au, kbs{at}qualitycode{dot}com
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Sat, 18 Aug 2001, Kevin Smith wrote:
> 
> > > [I wrote:]
> > >     Recently I acquired a copy of "Interglossa," and I realize how
> > > much A&C "pulled" the language in the direction of merely almost a
> > > relexified English, in which case just teach people real
> >
> > I'm not a linguist. Can you elaborate on your statement? I'm fairly
> > familiar with Glosa, but not with interglossa, so if you can frame it in
> > terms of English and Glosa it would be most helpful.
> 
>     A relexification of a language is simply a one-for-one substitution of
> vocabulary items while keeping the overall structure of the language the
> same.  In this regard, Glosa is not strictly a relexification of English,
> although it comes close.
> 
>     For instance, English has kept a few residual inflections, whereas
> Glosa has none, the relationships shown by Indo-European inflections
> being shown in Glosa by particles.  However, some Glosa-pe whose native
> language is English seem to be unable to break themselves of their
> native English habits, so that allowing for simple particles to
> substitute one-for-one for residual inflections, their Glosa comes close
> to a relexification of English.
> 
>     In the Indo-European languages, for the most part, including
> English, nouns are always marked for number. (There are minor
> exceptions, such as "sheep" in English, but even then number tends to be
> marked in other ways, if nothing else by context.)  There is no inherent
> logical necessity for this, and some languages allow nouns *not* to be
> singular, dual, plural, or whatever.  But some Glosa-pe persist in
> marking nouns for number whether they need to be or not.
> 
>     This is one shortcoming which Glosa did inherit from Interglossa,
> in that in both the particles 'u(n)' and 'plu' mark nouns (and do not
> serve as "a(n)" or "the," despite the confusing statements in some of
> the Glosa literature) when nothing else makes it clear that words are
> nouns, but unfortunately the IG/Gl particles *do* mark for number.  This
> is unnecessary.  Sometimes number is unknown or simply irrelevant, so
> why mark it?  Learners of Glosa whose native tongues do not insist on
> number marking may think the habits of anglophone Glosa-pe simply to be
> strange, and if the anglophones cannot break themselves of their native
> habit, they might conceivably have trouble understanding the usages of
> others.
> 
>     Another such habit is verb marking.  Indo-European languages mark
> verbs for tense and/or aspect, but there is no reason Writ Large In
> The Nature Of The Cosmos why verbs have to be marked at all in some
> situations.  Some languages do *not* always mark verbs for tense or
> aspect.  Sometimes the temporal or aspectual characteristic is merely
> irrelevant.  If so, why persist in marking it?  If a time reference is
> clearly in the past, for example, it is simply redundant to keep marking
> verbs with 'pa', 'pa', 'pa', 'pa'.
> 
>     I think that there is only one consideration for excess markers: a
> noisy channel for speech.  This does not apply to writing, and even in
> speech I consider it a bit of a stretch, because if the channel is that
> noisy, probably a lot else of the speech stream will be garbled anyway.
> 
>     This business of over marking of nouns and verbs in Glosa is a hobby
> horse of mine which others already know about, so I had best climb down
> from it.
> 
>     Lancelot Hogben published Interglossa in the dark days of World War
> II, which probably had a lot with why it did not get much of a trial.
> It had some significant features which Ron Clark and Wendy Ashby changed
> in creating Glosa.
> 
>     For example, Hogben knowingly and deliberately eschewed strict
> phonemicity of spelling in order to keep better recognizability of
> roots.  C&A changed (some would say mutilated) many roots in order to
> have strictly phonemic spelling.  There were some roots in Glosa which
> I simply did not recognize as first because of the way C&A had changed
> them.
> 
>     Glosa does use some different words for the particles, such as 'id'
> for IG's 're', 'pa' for 'pre', and the like.
> 
>     However, the greatest difference, as I see it, between the two
> languages is the overall structure.  As I mentioned, if you allow for
> the substitution of particles for residual inflection, Glosa is nearly
> relexified English.  Interglossa is not.  This is what I meant by Clark
> and Ashby "pulling" in the direction of English.
> 
>     Although there are a few tense, modal, aspectual, and other
> auxiliaries, IG has only twenty (if I recall the number correctly)
> real verbs, whereas the number of verbs is more or less open ended in
> Glosa.  IG builds verbal structures from one of the twenty verbs
> (which Hogben tends to call verboids for a reason I have not yet figured
> out -- the style of the book "Interglossa" is not as transparent as it
> might have been), allowing for the use of auxiliaries if strictly
> needed.  To one of these verbs is usually added a word H calls an
> "amplifier," so that the actual verbal structure is usually composite.
> 
>     These verbal structures need to be distinguished from English
> phrasal verbs, which should be scrupulously avoided in an auxiliary
> language.  (I once read a remark by a European with near native fluency
> in English that he had more trouble mastering English's phrasal verbs
> than he did the bizarre spelling.)  An English phrasal verb at times is
> nearly a lexical atom, not entirely lexically decomposable into its
> constituents.  (This is why Basic English is basically fraudulent.)
> IG's verbal structures, however, *are* decomposable.  For instance, the
> IG skeleton 'P mote Q ex R as S' conveys "P shifts Q from R to S" or 'P
> mote Q apo R' as "P removes Q from R, P takes Q from R.'  As such,
> 'mote' stands for induced motion without specific reference to its
> direction.  Thus, one could construct the tables:
> 
> P mote Q latero R  P puts Q beside R
> P mote Q epi R     P puts Q on R
> P mote Q laevo R   P puts Q to the left of R
> P mote Q peri R    P puts Q round R
> P mote Q supero R  P puts Q above R
> P mote Q hypo R    P puts Q under R
> 
> P mote Q supero    P raises Q
> P mote Q hypo      P lowers Q
> P mote Q extra     P ejects Q
> P mote Q in        P inserts Q (in)
> P mote Q peri R    P winds Q around R
> P mote Q in terra  P buries Q
> P mote Q in liquo  P immerses Q
> -- and so on --
> 
>     I think that it is the verbal structure which most distinguishes
> Glosa and Interglossa.  Also, IG has a limited vocabulary, and the
> verbal structure is significant in this.  The base vocabulary has only
> 880 words, although in everyday speech, to avoid defining rather than
> naming it might be advisable to have additional words for everyday
> things.  (For instance how would one speak of a raccoon or opossum?  The
> common approach is to use the biological nomenclature name, at least the
> genus thereof.)  On the other hand, Glosa does not have at present a
> closed vocabulary.  (Its vocabulary lists are not even consistent, but
> that is an editing problem.)
> 
>     There are other differences, but I myself think that these are the
> most significant.
> 
> -- 
> Paul Bartlett

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au, kbs{at}qualitycode{dot}com
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Proba
From: "Paul O. Bartlett" <bartlett{at}smart{dot}net>
Date: Sun, 19 Aug 2001 18:47:10 -0400 (EDT)

On Sat, 18 Aug 2001, Kevin Smith wrote:

> > [I wrote:]
> >     Recently I acquired a copy of "Interglossa," and I realize how
> > much A&C "pulled" the language in the direction of merely almost a
> > relexified English, in which case just teach people real
>
> I'm not a linguist. Can you elaborate on your statement? I'm fairly
> familiar with Glosa, but not with interglossa, so if you can frame it in
> terms of English and Glosa it would be most helpful.

    A relexification of a language is simply a one-for-one substitution of
vocabulary items while keeping the overall structure of the language the
same.  In this regard, Glosa is not strictly a relexification of English,
although it comes close.

    For instance, English has kept a few residual inflections, whereas
Glosa has none, the relationships shown by Indo-European inflections
being shown in Glosa by particles.  However, some Glosa-pe whose native
language is English seem to be unable to break themselves of their
native English habits, so that allowing for simple particles to
substitute one-for-one for residual inflections, their Glosa comes close
to a relexification of English.

    In the Indo-European languages, for the most part, including
English, nouns are always marked for number. (There are minor
exceptions, such as "sheep" in English, but even then number tends to be
marked in other ways, if nothing else by context.)  There is no inherent
logical necessity for this, and some languages allow nouns *not* to be
singular, dual, plural, or whatever.  But some Glosa-pe persist in
marking nouns for number whether they need to be or not.

    This is one shortcoming which Glosa did inherit from Interglossa,
in that in both the particles 'u(n)' and 'plu' mark nouns (and do not
serve as "a(n)" or "the," despite the confusing statements in some of
the Glosa literature) when nothing else makes it clear that words are
nouns, but unfortunately the IG/Gl particles *do* mark for number.  This
is unnecessary.  Sometimes number is unknown or simply irrelevant, so
why mark it?  Learners of Glosa whose native tongues do not insist on
number marking may think the habits of anglophone Glosa-pe simply to be
strange, and if the anglophones cannot break themselves of their native
habit, they might conceivably have trouble understanding the usages of
others.

    Another such habit is verb marking.  Indo-European languages mark
verbs for tense and/or aspect, but there is no reason Writ Large In
The Nature Of The Cosmos why verbs have to be marked at all in some
situations.  Some languages do *not* always mark verbs for tense or
aspect.  Sometimes the temporal or aspectual characteristic is merely
irrelevant.  If so, why persist in marking it?  If a time reference is
clearly in the past, for example, it is simply redundant to keep marking
verbs with 'pa', 'pa', 'pa', 'pa'.

    I think that there is only one consideration for excess markers: a
noisy channel for speech.  This does not apply to writing, and even in
speech I consider it a bit of a stretch, because if the channel is that
noisy, probably a lot else of the speech stream will be garbled anyway.

    This business of over marking of nouns and verbs in Glosa is a hobby
horse of mine which others already know about, so I had best climb down
from it.

    Lancelot Hogben published Interglossa in the dark days of World War
II, which probably had a lot with why it did not get much of a trial.
It had some significant features which Ron Clark and Wendy Ashby changed
in creating Glosa.

    For example, Hogben knowingly and deliberately eschewed strict
phonemicity of spelling in order to keep better recognizability of
roots.  C&A changed (some would say mutilated) many roots in order to
have strictly phonemic spelling.  There were some roots in Glosa which
I simply did not recognize as first because of the way C&A had changed
them.

    Glosa does use some different words for the particles, such as 'id'
for IG's 're', 'pa' for 'pre', and the like.

    However, the greatest difference, as I see it, between the two
languages is the overall structure.  As I mentioned, if you allow for
the substitution of particles for residual inflection, Glosa is nearly
relexified English.  Interglossa is not.  This is what I meant by Clark
and Ashby "pulling" in the direction of English.

    Although there are a few tense, modal, aspectual, and other
auxiliaries, IG has only twenty (if I recall the number correctly)
real verbs, whereas the number of verbs is more or less open ended in
Glosa.  IG builds verbal structures from one of the twenty verbs
(which Hogben tends to call verboids for a reason I have not yet figured
out -- the style of the book "Interglossa" is not as transparent as it
might have been), allowing for the use of auxiliaries if strictly
needed.  To one of these verbs is usually added a word H calls an
"amplifier," so that the actual verbal structure is usually composite.

    These verbal structures need to be distinguished from English
phrasal verbs, which should be scrupulously avoided in an auxiliary
language.  (I once read a remark by a European with near native fluency
in English that he had more trouble mastering English's phrasal verbs
than he did the bizarre spelling.)  An English phrasal verb at times is
nearly a lexical atom, not entirely lexically decomposable into its
constituents.  (This is why Basic English is basically fraudulent.)
IG's verbal structures, however, *are* decomposable.  For instance, the
IG skeleton 'P mote Q ex R as S' conveys "P shifts Q from R to S" or 'P
mote Q apo R' as "P removes Q from R, P takes Q from R.'  As such,
'mote' stands for induced motion without specific reference to its
direction.  Thus, one could construct the tables:

P mote Q latero R  P puts Q beside R
P mote Q epi R     P puts Q on R
P mote Q laevo R   P puts Q to the left of R
P mote Q peri R    P puts Q round R
P mote Q supero R  P puts Q above R
P mote Q hypo R    P puts Q under R

P mote Q supero    P raises Q
P mote Q hypo      P lowers Q
P mote Q extra     P ejects Q
P mote Q in        P inserts Q (in)
P mote Q peri R    P winds Q around R
P mote Q in terra  P buries Q
P mote Q in liquo  P immerses Q
-- and so on --

    I think that it is the verbal structure which most distinguishes
Glosa and Interglossa.  Also, IG has a limited vocabulary, and the
verbal structure is significant in this.  The base vocabulary has only
880 words, although in everyday speech, to avoid defining rather than
naming it might be advisable to have additional words for everyday
things.  (For instance how would one speak of a raccoon or opossum?  The
common approach is to use the biological nomenclature name, at least the
genus thereof.)  On the other hand, Glosa does not have at present a
closed vocabulary.  (Its vocabulary lists are not even consistent, but
that is an editing problem.)

    There are other differences, but I myself think that these are the
most significant.

--

On Sun, 19 Aug 2001, MGxcr{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> I'm not a linguist either and don't pretend to understand a lot of what you 
> said, but it sounds to me that Interglosa is a superior conlang. Why doesn't 
> someone revive it?

    One important thing to remember (or realize) when it comes to
constructed international auxiliary languages is that one man's
necessary feature is another man's fatal flaw.  For instance, I myself
think that Ido is superior to Esperanto, but I know one Esperantist who
is of just the opposite opinion.  I am tending to like Interglossa over
Glosa, but others may hold to the contrary.  And so it goes.  In the
end, structural linguistic characteristics will probably not the the
only, or even the most important, factor determining whether any conIAL
gains widespread acceptance.

    More to the point. ;-)  Why doesn't someone try to revive
Interglossa (note the double 'ss')?  One difficulty might be in
descriptive or instructional material.  Copies of the book are
sometimes hard to find, as it was printed on cheap paper in the middle
of a major war.  I don't know how many copies were ever printed.  More
importantly, I once read that Ron Clark bought the copyright to the
book "Interglossa." If so, I have no idea what the copyright status is,
because he died farily recently.  Unfortunately these days, especially
on the internet, there is a tendency to ignore such things as
copyright, a tendency I cannot support.  I do not know enough about
intellectual property law around the world to know if it would be
feasible to provide enough material without infringing the right of
whoever -- if anyone -- owns the copyright now.

    Even apart from copyright, if any proposed conIAL is to go very far
and be anything other than the plaything (not that there is anything
wrong with that, mind you) of a few individuals who already have a
language in common, material needs to be available for learners in more
than just one language (English in this case).  To the best of my
knowledge, information about Ido, Interlingua, Esperanto, Lojban, and
maybe Volapük are available on the world wide web in various languages.

    Finally, I suspect that few people who do not have (or at least
have read) a copy of "Interglossa" (the book itself) really know the
language well enough to try to revive it -- or more accurately, to try
to get it going in the first place, as I doubt that it ever really did
get a good start.  Unfortunately, Hogben's style was not the easiest to
read, at least for me.

    Although I have some interest, I am not now personally in a good
position to speahead such a movement.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

"Paul O. Bartlett" wrote [excerpts]:

> In this regard, Glosa is not strictly a relexification of English,
> although it comes close.

Perhaps it is a good feature of an auxlang to permit near-direct
translation from the languages of the anticipated audience.
If some tend to add "redundant" articles or tenses, especially in
early stages of learning, why not permit without encouraging it.

But by choosing a strict word order, this limits the audience.
Approx 50% of the world's languages place the verb after what we call
the direct and indirect objects, contrary to English and Glosa.
And 50% of the languages usually put the modifier after the modified
word. So fully 75% of the world will find the word order foreign.

However, by using particles in a consistent way, some of the
strictness of ordering can be relaxed, e.g. by always marking
indirect objects with the "ad" preposition, always marking the
verb with a tense or aspect particle, and using prepositions to
mark the direct object ("em") and "ergative/ablative" subject ("per").

Overall, such marking seems to me very helpful in an auxlang.

> For instance, English has kept a few residual inflections, whereas
> Glosa has none

Particles are exactly equivalent to inflections, though.
As long as they are relatively few, and consistent, no harm.

> In the Indo-European languages, for the most part, including
> English, nouns are always marked for number.

Glosa prefers prepositions (including articles and tense markers) to
suffixes/inflections. With a well-designed set of articles/quantifiers,
one should be able to avoid number-marking *and* monotony.

> Learners of Glosa whose native tongues do not insist on
> number marking may think the habits of anglophone Glosa-pe simply to be
> strange, and if the anglophones cannot break themselves of their native
> habit, they might conceivably have trouble understanding the usages of
> others.

Why not cater to the habits of both? Allow optional marking.
Design the lang so it's easy to get right, difficult to be wrong.

> Another such habit is verb marking.  Indo-European languages mark
> verbs for tense and/or aspect, but there is no reason Writ Large In
> The Nature Of The Cosmos why verbs have to be marked at all in some
> situations.

Actually, there is. No language fails to indicate transitive/intransitive
in some way, and all verbs have a notion of aspect indicated by default
(zero-marking) which can be over-ridden by some means. So I think the best
thing to do is to mark consistently but minimally. There are several
different ways to do it. Glosa does better than many pidgins by providing
a (nearly) full set of aspect/tense particles, and only lacks the
accusative marker ("em") for transitivity.

> For example, Hogben knowingly and deliberately eschewed strict
> phonemicity of spelling in order to keep better recognizability of
> roots.  C&A changed (some would say mutilated) many roots in order to
> have strictly phonemic spelling.  There were some roots in Glosa which
> I simply did not recognize as first because of the way C&A had changed
> them.

And many different roots fall together by merging C into S/K.
Since all nations pronounce Latin and Greek roots differently
but recognize them visually, the cleverest solution is to
*keep the spelling* and *change the pronunciation*.

> Glosa is nearly
> relexified English.  Interglossa is not.  This is what I meant by Clark
> and Ashby "pulling" in the direction of English.

If there were a few particles added to differentiate adjectives from
nouns, then a true-to-itself Glosa could also accommodate relexing
from Spanish, French, and Japanese. 100% of the languages of the world
would be easy to relex into Glosa, *and back again*.

> IG has only twenty (if I recall the number correctly)
> real verbs, whereas the number of verbs is more or less open ended in
> Glosa.

I like that idea, but we'd need more like 100 basic verbs, and the ability
to easily create "phrasals". I believe Glosa could support that, as-is.

> An English phrasal verb at times is
> nearly a lexical atom, not entirely lexically decomposable into its
> constituents.

Right. Importing them straight into Glosa would be bad.
It is a productive and inevitable process of language,
to build up complex verbs from simpler components.
The alternative of 5000 Romance verbs is not workable.

> Also, IG has a limited vocabulary, and the
> verbal structure is significant in this.  The base vocabulary has only
> 880 words, although in everyday speech, to avoid defining rather than
> naming it might be advisable to have additional words for everyday
> things.

Yes, that's another major issue. There was an experiment by Jeffrey
Henning to try to reduce roots to a minimum. A base vocab of particles
and verbs and such, minus the world of things and names, could be
kept under 1000. Glosa as an "isolating" type of language should be
able to borrow specific nouns freely, without impacting its structure.

"Paul O. Bartlett" wrote:

> One important thing to remember (or realize) when it comes to
> constructed international auxiliary languages is that one man's
> necessary feature is another man's fatal flaw.

Yes, but everything in human life is the same way. That's why
a majority of 50% (or less in the USA) rules the day.

>     More to the point. ;-)  Why doesn't someone try to revive
> Interglossa (note the double 'ss')?

Glosa needs a revision, for sure. Rather than complain,
though, I'll list *good* points (IMO) to keep:

* no inflections, all grammar is in prepositioned particles

* easy-to-pronounce roots based on Latin and Greek

* does not mimic Romance languages (others do that better anyway)

* attempts to be easy to learn for non-Euros

* is relatively open and unsophisticated and simple

have been working on the free word order:-
subject before verb or with "per" otherwise 
object after or with "de" (instead of "em" as "de" already in G)
i.e. de plu flora pa dona a gina per andro

At 18:47 19/08/2001 -0400, you wrote:

>On Sat, 18 Aug 2001, Kevin Smith wrote:

>

>> > [I wrote:]

>> >     Recently I acquired a copy of "Interglossa," and I realize how

>> > much A&C "pulled" the language in the direction of merely almost a

>> > relexified English, in which case just teach people real

>>

>> I'm not a linguist. Can you elaborate on your statement? I'm fairly

>> familiar with Glosa, but not with interglossa, so if you can frame it in

>> terms of English and Glosa it would be most helpful.

>

>    A relexification of a language is simply a one-for-one substitution of

>vocabulary items while keeping the overall structure of the language the

>same.  In this regard, Glosa is not strictly a relexification of English,

>although it comes close.

>

*  Hello All,

   Here is a slight variation on on the relexification story:-

   When putting Glosa together, Ron and wendy (C&A) chose to make up a composite language which carried - as well as possible - the 'best' qualities from the various existing languages - national and classical.

   For Grammar, they chose that of English, but with the avoidance of inflections (both different forms of the same word EG 'go; went' and meldings onto words EG 'quick; quickly); also, they promoted a ~fairly strict sequence of word function within phrases (NP: determinant - number - modifier[s] - "noun" ... VP: tense particle - modifier[s] - "verb" - amplifier). As well as all this, they chose to make room for clauses, and after some prompting from other Glosa-pe, the passive form.

   However, to do all this well takes a little practice, and some trial and error.  There is, I believe, a straight version of Glosa, which is somewhat away from Hogben's original pattern; however, I feel it is more in line with the way 'most' humans handle language than was that of Hogben.  Here, I should say that it is too easy for speakers of English to assume that many of their beloved structures from English MUST also be understandable in Glosa.  This is a false belief: with Glosa the syntax is what determines the meaning of a sentence, so word order - according to fairly simple rules as suggested above, and in my website http://www.zeta.org.au/~rgaskell - will, I believe, give the language life. 


   Here I must also say that psychologically I differ from Paul, in that I feel considerably more comfortable with the wider range of more specfic words - or concepts: Paul finds the unnecessary repetition of tense particles irksome; I do not, but agree with him that, once a time-frame has been established, it need not be reinforced with every Verb Phrase.  On the other hand, I find repetition of lexical concepts somewhat off-putting, thus I would rather simply say 

~An pa leva id.~ [(he did raise it) = He raised it.] than ^An pa mote id supra.^ [(he did move it up/over) = He raised it.]

AND  ~An pa leva id; e loka id epi u grada~ [He raised it, and put it on the step.] rather than ^An pa mote id supra; e mote id epi u grada.^ [He raised it, and put it on the step.]

I will agree that the 'phrasal' structure either ~leva ana~ [raise upwards] or ^mote supra^ [move up] are less preferred, yet ... for some meanings can be imagined to be better  ~E nu, leva ana tu braki.~ [(and now raise upwards your arm<<s>) And now, raise up your arms.]


>    These verbal structures need to be distinguished from English

>phrasal verbs, which should be scrupulously avoided in an auxiliary

>language.  (I once read a remark by a European with near native fluency

>in English that he had more trouble mastering English's phrasal verbs

>than he did the bizarre spelling.)  An English phrasal verb at times is

>nearly a lexical atom, not entirely lexically decomposable into its

>constituents.  (This is why Basic English is basically fraudulent.)

>IG's verbal structures, however, *are* decomposable.  For instance, the

>IG skeleton 'P mote Q ex R as S' conveys "P shifts Q from R to S" or 'P

>mote Q apo R' as "P removes Q from R, P takes Q from R.'  As such,

>'mote' stands for induced motion without specific reference to its

>direction.  Thus, one could construct the tables:

*  Interglossa (?)                       ***       Glosa (added by R.G.)


>P mote Q latero R  P puts Q beside R ...........P loka Q alelo R

>P mote Q epi R     P puts Q on R ...............P vesti R ko Q

>P mote Q laevo R   P puts Q to the left of R ...P loka Q laevo de R

>P mote Q peri R    P puts Q round R ............P loka Q peri R

>P mote Q supero R  P puts Q above R ............P loka Q supra R

>P mote Q hypo R    P puts Q under R ........... P loka Q supro R

>P mote Q supero    P raises Q ................. P leva Q

>P mote Q hypo      P lowers Q ................. P loka hipo Q


>P mote Q extra     P ejects Q ................. P loka apo Q

>P mote Q in        P inserts Q (in) ........... P loka intra Q; P in-lo Q

>P mote Q peri R    P winds Q around R ......... P loka Q peri R

>P mote Q in terra  P buries Q ................. P loka Q in-suela

>P mote Q in liquo  P immerses Q ............... P loka Q in-liqi

>-- and so on --                                     e cetera

>


>genus thereof.)  On the other hand, Glosa does not have at present a

>closed vocabulary.  (Its vocabulary lists are not even consistent, but

>that is an editing problem.).

>

*   As I understand it, Glosa is supposed to be an 'open' language.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

Saluta, karo Glosa-pe!
We have many persons in this group, which prefer English for discussions in
this list, so in the message I'll use only this language. So, I'm not a
native speaker of English and, please, excuse my errors.
Here are some my thoughts about Glosa, Interglossa and English:
1. Glosa isn't English with LG-vocabulary! Yes, there are some similar
places in constructions of declarative sentence, but neither in negative
one, nor in questions!
2. I propose to use Glosa-dialects' names as RC did. So, Interglossa is
Interglosa, there is also common Glosa, Euro-Glosa, and there will be also
Puta-me-Glosa etc.
3. Why all of you think that Glosa isn't perfect?
I think that there are only some vocabulary problems as in all "young" IALs!
4. The fact that we can use almost all words in Glosa as verbs is very good,
because we have no "idiomatic verbal constructions" from different national
languages!
5. Adjective before noun is the best way. It occurs in all analytic IALs.

Saluta,
Alex.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au, kbs{at}qualitycode{dot}com
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Proba
From: "Paul O. Bartlett" <bartlett{at}smart{dot}net>

    It took me longer to get back to this than I had anticipated.  Sorry
for the delay.

    One matter as a general response is the extent to which we discuss
any language other than Glosa.  Although Interglossa was the forerunner
of Glosa, I consider them more or less separate languages.  If others
prefer it, we should probably drop the discussion of IG except insofar
as it sheds light on Glosa, which after all is the subject of this list.

On Mon, 20 Aug 2001, Kevin Smith wrote (somewhat excerpted for space):

> On Sun, 19 Aug 2001, Paul O. Bartlett wrote:
>
> >     For instance, English has kept a few residual inflections, whereas
> > Glosa has none, the relationships shown by Indo-European inflections
> > being shown in Glosa by particles.  [...]

> An example here would be really helpful. I understand on one level what
> you're saying, but it's not concrete without an example.

    Yesterday I go to town.  I buy five book.  I eat lunch.  Then I
visit friend, who I visit before.  We talk about many thing.  I come
home.

    Yesterday I went to town.  I bought five books.  I ate lunch.  Then
I visited a friend, whom I had visited before.  We were talking about
many things.  I came home.

    The second paragraph conveys no more real information than the
first, despite the tense, aspect, and number (and even case)
indications.

    I want to make clear that it is NOT somehow "wrong" to use (or
reuse) various particles marking plurality or tense or aspect or
whatever.  They do not somehow violate the grammar of the language (and
we must remember that grammar is much more than morphology*).  It is
just that it is often superfluous to do so.  Also, semantically it can
happen that number or time or whatever is unknown or simply irrelevant,
so there need not be any marking at all, but Indo-European habits can
lead one to think that marking is forced when it is not.

    If Glosa is intended to be used only by people speaking
Indo-European languages, it doesn't really matter.  However, if it is
to be used by people from many different language families (and a man
in China and I once exchanged two letters each way in Glosa), they
might think it strange to keep marking everything unnecessarily, because
to them it is "natural" not to do so.  We must always beware of the
temptation to think that how our native language does things is somehow
"natural" or "the way the mind works."

    (At this point, I will insert something I typed in a long time ago
about misconception of language.  I am not claiming that Eddings' work
is on the level of, say, Tolkien.  It just happens to be a sample I have
ready to hand.)

..........
    Consider the following excerpt from David Eddings' fantasy novel,
"Domes of Fire" (1992).  Eddings' fantasy series "The Elenium" and its
sequel "The Tamuli" are set in a multi-racial, multi-lingual, medieval
world with the common motifs of chivalry, magic, religion, and so on.
Kalten is a brave and likable, but not always bright, Church Knight of
Elenic language, race, and religion, and the Church Knights are trained
to cast spells using the Styric tongue.  Sephrenia is a polyglot wisewoman
of the Styric race.  In this episode, an Elenic party are in the Tamul
Empire and need to learn to speak Tamul.  Incidentally, linguistic theory
is not my point here.  My point is the misjudgment of considering that
one's own language is somehow the "natural" way that all humans think.

        "Kalten, dear," [Sephrenia] said gently, why was I trying
      to teach you Styric?"
        "So that I could perform magic tricks, I guess."  He
      shrugged.  "That's unless you just enjoy making people
      suffer."
        "No, dear one.  It was just as painful for me as it was for
      you."  She shuddered.  "More painful, probably.  You _were_,
      in fact, trying to learn Styric so that you could work the
      spells, but in order to do that, you had to be able to _think_
      in Styric.  You can't just mouth the words and make them come
      off the way you want them to."
        "Wait a minute," he objected.  "Are you saying that people
      who speak other languages don't think the same way we do?"
        "They may think the same way, but they don't think in the
      same words."
        "Do you mean to say that we actually think in words?"
        "Of course we do.  What did you think thoughts were?"
        "I don't know.  But we're all human.  Wouldn't we all think
      in the same way and in the same language?"
        She blinked.  "And which language would that be, dear one?"
        "Elenic, naturally.  That's why foreigners aren't as clever
      as we are.  They have to stop and translate their thoughts from
      Elenic into that barbarian gabble they call language.  They do
      it just to be stubborn, of course."
        She stared at him suspiciously.  "You're actually serious,
      aren't you?"
        "Of course.  I thought everybody knew that's why Elenes are
      smarter than everybody else."  His face shone with blinding
      sincerity.
        "Oh, dear," she sighed in near despair,
..........

> > irrelevant.  If so, why persist in marking it?  If a time reference is
> > clearly in the past, for example, it is simply redundant to keep marking
> > verbs with 'pa', 'pa', 'pa', 'pa'.
>
> I could go either way on this. I guess I'd have to be fluent enough in a
> language to know when it would be redundant.

    Any time a marker (such as a particle or inflection) conveys no
additional information, it is redundant (even if, strictly speaking,
not wrong).

> >     For example, Hogben knowingly and deliberately eschewed strict
> > phonemicity of spelling in order to keep better recognizability of
>
> Personally, I prefer phonetics, as in Glosa.

    This becomes a judgment call, and Hogben called it differently from
Clark and Ashby.  In "Interglossa" Hogben writes:

        If we ain at easy recognition and easy association, it is
        fatal to maltreat roots for the task of uniform spelling.
        _Uniformity is less important that consistency._  It does
        not matter whether one sound always has one symbol.  What
        does matter is whether the same symbol stands for only
        one sound. [page 16, italics original]

        The inconvenience of having a few anomilies which go into
        a dozen lines of print is far less that the disadvantage
        which would result from mutilating roots beyone visual
        recognition. [page 30]

        With a few exceptions the vocables of _Interglossa_ are
        based on _unmutilated_ roots of words which now belong to
        the vocabulary of _all_ countries where modern technology
        and hygiene have penetrated. [page 31, italics original]

When I first looked at some of the Glosa wordlists, I did not recognize
some of the "mutilated" roots Hogben was talking about.  I have a good
grounding in English etymologies and smatterings of Greek, Latin, and
French, and I was simply puzzled by some of them at first.  Clark and
Ashby made a different decision from Hogben.  I tend to go with Hogben.

> >     However, the greatest difference, as I see it, between the two
> > languages is the overall structure.  As I mentioned, if you allow for
> > the substitution of particles for residual inflection, Glosa is nearly
> > relexified English.  Interglossa is not.  This is what I meant by Clark
> > and Ashby "pulling" in the direction of English.
>
> Again, here, without an example, I'm just not quite getting it.

    I think the best example, in the time and energy I have available,
it the very example I gave of verbal structures, the first part of an
example of which is still below.  Glosa's set of verbs is essentially
open (although the set of auxiliaries is more or less closed), just as
the set of verbs of English is open, and the verbs of each language can
be more or less mapped onto the other's (to a degree, anyway).  However,
the set of verbs of Interglossa is small and closed.  It has (more or
less) the same (closed) set of verbal auxiliaries, but unlike both
English and Glosa, it has only eighten verbs (which Hogben calls
"verboids").  All verbal structures are composed with these eighteen
verbs, unlike both English and Glosa.

> > IG's verbal structures, however, *are* decomposable.  For instance, the
> > IG skeleton 'P mote Q ex R ad S' conveys "P shifts Q from R to S" or 'P
> > mote Q apo R' as "P removes Q from R, P takes Q from R.'  As such,
> > 'mote' stands for induced motion without specific reference to its
> > direction.  Thus, one could construct the tables: [omitted]

..........
* Even some constructors of respectable international auxiliary
languages confuse grammar with morphology.  Giuseppe Peano, who
developed (the original) Interlingua, which was also called Latino sine
Flexione, was a mathematician, not a linguist, and he said that the best
grammar is no grammar, confusing grammar with the elaborate inflectional
morphology of Latin, which he discarded in Lsf (the more of which I read
the more I like).  This is on a level with C&A's sometime statement,
"Glosa has no grammar."  A "language" which has no grammar is not a
language.  Glosa, IG, and (nearly) LsF have no _inflections_ but they
certainly have grammars.  We must always take care to use terminology
accurately if we are to be taken seriously.  For instance, the proposed
"tense table" of Glosa would be better named the "verb table," because
it deals with aspect, mood, and voice as well as tenses.  If we are not
sure of the proper use of a technical term, we are better off not to use
it and to say what we want to say in a different way.


--

Anyway, thanks for the quick lesson in some interesting
corners of the Glosa language.

    Certainly.  In this respect, both IG and Glosa follow Indo-European
habits, although I do not know whether there is any language anywhere
which would elide the second subject.  Pidgins, perhaps?

> On phonemicity, I still prefer simplicity over perfect
> reuse of existing roots. And I accept that it is merely a

    As I say, it is a judgment call based in part on one's goals.

> I do have concerns about the size of Glosa's vocabulary.
> From where I sit, less is more. I would much rather
> construct my own meaningful phrases out of existing little
> words than have to master hundreds or thousands of
> additional complete words.

    This was Hogben's goal, and as nearly as I can tell, at least the
original goal of Clark & Ashby.  Some of their earlier publications, at
least, claimed that Glosa 1000 would allow you to say at least most
things.  (Although when I collated the various versions of "1000" to
create the original Glosa Basic Reference which I put up on the WWW
with permission, I wound up with more like 1500 words.)  I personally
tend to agree with the idea of a smaller vocabulary for basic
interpersonal communications, probably because I have a deuce of a time
retaining vocabulary.  At first I said that I would hate to see a law
code written in a 1000 word (plus proper names) vocabulary, but I have
read that Tok Pisin (a pidgin English) is used in the Parliament of
Papua New Guinea and that Australian radio broadcasts some in Tok
Pisin.  Also, the world news service of the Voice of America (I think
that is it) uses a restricted vocabulary of about 1800 words plus
proper names.  So with judicious choices it can be done.

*   Hello Kevin,
   I write in English because the concepts are tricky, and it takes longer
to work out the right expressions in Glosa. 
   In English we abbreviate our usage a lot and often leave out words -
this is called elision. (Verb: to elide)  EG. "I went home."  ~Mi pa ki a
mi domi.~
    We can say "The dog went him." - but this is slang.
    In Glosa we can't correctly use the concept 'go' in relation to the
concept 'home.'  
    In Engish we describe "go" as intransitive: it does not take a Direct
Object.  So "I go to my home." is the unelided form; "to my home" is an
Indirect Object.  

    You have asked about Interglossa, and I have gone off at a grammatical
tangent.
    But Grammar is the crux of the difference between Interglossa and its
decendent, Glosa.
    I do have a copy of Hogben's book, but only pull it out when someone
goes (back) to asking questions about the earlier language: I see the
relationship as an evolutionary one.  Having spent time talking to Ron
Clark and to Wendy Ashby, I am pragmatically promoting Glosa, not
Interglossa, because I feel that Clark and Ashby did a good job in
vivifying the basic language that Hogben produced. 
    On the few occasions that I tried to create sentences using
Interglossa, I found its structure rather blocky, and not yielding to human
tendencies - possibly I can describe the feeling as 'angular' and not
'flowing.'  It seemed like a formula language.

    When I first met Ron, in 1977, he was still struggling to make Hogben's
angular structures work.  In 1978 Ron Clark returned to the drawing board,
knowing that the basic specification of Interglosa was sound, but that the
syntax needed loostening up. It was at this stage that Ron did serious work
on the structure of Verb Phrases in what he was then calling Euro Glossa.
He was concentrating on making the language usable by scientists, for
international communication.  Also, he took into account the newly invented
electronic computers, and, as well as that, wished to get the language
flowing - so that it felt more amenable to human syntax.

   While Paul finds linguistic interest in Interglossa, I see it as only
having purely historical interest - as the parent of Glosa.

   With apologies, I cannot find the time to check through Hogben's book to
search for example to make comparisons.  When you see the language written,
it looks much like the present Glosa, with only a few words with different
roots or different spelling, and some rearrangements in the verb phrases.  

EG p109       Mi pre kine apo; pre fe kine para.

               I went away before she came here.


 p130         Id eque geno re; an esthe hedo.

               It is the sort of thing he likes.


 p184         Mu habe cliesto in quo geno?

               How are they related? 

It might take a while to get yourself a copy of "Interglossa": few were
printed, the flimsy war-time paper is disintegrating, and they are
"collectors' items".

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

*   Thanks Charles for this clear restatement of your ideas.

     # Some level of optionality in word order at the start - allowing learners to filter into Glosa from different language traditions. 

     # Optional additon of a couple of extra particles to allow learners to specify the transitive ~em~, and for indirect objects ~per~.

     # Functionally using _particles_ similar to _inflections_ - but maintaining the separateness as either discrete words or hyphenated pre- or post- fixes.

     # Glosa prefers prepositions (including articles and tense markers) to suffixes/inflections. With a well-designed set of  articles/quantifiers, one should be able to avoid number-marking *and* monotony.

     # "Allow optional marking.  Design the lang so it's easy to get right, difficult to be wrong. 

        *** This is, I feel, beautifully put. ***

     # Allowing optional marker-particles, but ensuring people use these consistently.

     #%%  Since all nations pronounce Latin and Greek roots differently

but recognize them visually, the cleverest solution is to *keep the spelling* and *change the pronunciation*.

        %%%This is the one idea I find clashing%%%

     # For certain language traditions:- "If there were a few particles added to differentiate adjectives from nouns, then a true-to-itself Glosa could also accommodate relexing from Spanish, French, and Japanese. 100% of the languages of the world would be easy to relex into Glosa, *and back again*."

          *** Yes, were we able to introduce transitive phases, where learners with different habitual ways of thinking about language, were able to ^shoe-horn^ themselves into Glosa, by bringing - for a transitional period only - some particle that had a similar feel to those of their native tongue, then we would have a funnel by which most people could gradually merge into using Glosa.***  [This would need some serious thinking.] 

     # With keeping some of the "verboid" concept of Interglossa, there are definitely compound "verbs" in Glosa, but these are set structures, and not idiosyncratic forms that have grown out of usage.  Agreed, importing idiomatic phrasal verbs - from any other language - into Glosa is wrong

     # "It is a productive and inevitable process of language, to build up complex verbs from simpler components.  The alternative of 5000 Romance verbs is not workable."

        ***Not every word in "GLOSA 6000" can be 'verbed', but having a discrete and unique lexical unit for every concept is an unnecessary burdon on learners - and wrong, when it prevents the grouping of similar concepts into a word-family, in which compound "verbs" contained the same verboid.***

     # [There was an experiment by Jeffrey Henning to try to reduce roots to a minimum.]  "A base vocab of particles and verbs and such, minus the world of things and names, could be kept under 1000. Glosa as an "isolating" type of language should be able to borrow specific nouns freely, without impacting its structure."

         *** Yes, excluding the 'concretes' and proper nouns, 1000 lexical items (function-words, actions and modifiers) would cover most people's needs.***


   So, there are two or three hurdles to cross: can the linguistic fraternity be convinced that a phased learning process is acceptable; who is going to do the work in setting up the various pathways into Glosa; and will the world be able to live with an auxiliary language that might contain elements of two, or more, of its ontological pathways - as still persist in Modern English, and, I understand, in modern Greek.

   Would people be able to live with the concept of an auxiliary language that was not monolithic, but which allowed untidy optionalities to facilitate learning?

   Ron Clark did visualise a series of three major usages of Glosa.  At the plebian level a basic vocabulary and fairly loose syntax might apply; at the second, or scholarly, level, a wider vocabulary put together using a tighter, more proscribed syntax, would ensure ready, global interaction at the academic, scientific and commercial level; and, for the third, legal, level, a highly specified lexicon with a tightly controlled syntax would apply - ensuring as much exactitude as written language permits.

   What Ron Clark suggested, can be visualised in the vertical direction (or Y axis);  while the suggestions from Charles can be pitured as a broadening of Glosa on the basal plane (or X and Z axes).


   Prior to reading Charles' post, I had not thought in terms of introducing a Planned Language through parallel, but slightly different, pathways.  However, the precedent is there with the Initial Teaching Alphabet(ITA) for children: while the young can cut back from eighty different 'sound/letters' to the standard twenty-six - after their achieving fluency, will adult learner be anywhere near as flexible with the learning of Glosa?

   Owing to my knowlege of only Glosa and English, I would be able to participate in such a project more as a consultant; though, I would be happy to do as much as I could, of the planning and developmental work.


   What does the group think of this initiative of Charles'?  Is it feasible, in the practical world; and would hard-nosed Linguists accept the concept, in the theoretical world?  Or don't we have to worry about possible theoretical concerns, if it works, practically?

   How many volunteers?


Is this what "Proba" was all about?


Saluta,

    I will just respond to the last thing Robin wrote, for general
interest.

On Sat, 25 Aug 2001, Robin Gaskell wrote:

> It might take a while to get yourself a copy of "Interglossa": few were
> printed, the flimsy war-time paper is disintegrating, and they are
> "collectors' items".

    There is an excellent source for used books (at least in English)
on the world wide web, the Advanced Book Exchange (abebooks).  The URL 
is

http://www.abebooks.com

The Advanced Search option is especially useful.  Certainly, not every
used bookseller is listed, but many in the US and the UK are.  I found
my copy of "Interglossa" from a British bookseller who was only asking
GB£5 (plus air post charge) for a copy in quite good condition.  I also
discovered another hard-to-find conIAL book on abebooks, as well as
some highly technical, non-language books.  It is an excellent resource.

>     A practical suggestion to all, whether for mailing lists or

> http://
> in fromn of the address.  Some mail agents (such as mine) can pick off
> the address without the http:// but some cannot.  If you include it,

I usually do include that http, for sysmmetry with urls using other
mechanisms, but explicitly chose to drop it in this case, since that's
how Robin listed the corresponding URL in his signature. When in Rome...

As for picking off web addresses in mail agents... I'm even more
old-school than you are, Paul, haha! I highly disapprove of such
behavior. Mail programs are for mail (which should be plain ASCII
text) and should know nothing of the Web. While I don't actively
fight such behavior, and even occasionally use it, I would not use
the enabling of it as justification in situations like this. That
is, including http is the right thing to do, but for a different
reason.

As for html in mail... yeccchhhh! It may become common for regular
purposes in the future, but in my world mail with html is usually
advertisement, whether unsolicited (spam) or not. I've been tempted
to filter all html mail, but I get just enough nonspam html mail
to discourage that.

- Bill

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Glosa and Esperanto, Grammatical Similarity
From: William W Patterson <ailanto{at}neosplice{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 26 Aug 2001 08:49:56 -0400

Je sab, 25 aug 2001 20:41:22 -0400 (EDT), Paul Bartlett skribis:

> ... I do think that
> structurally Glosa is workable.  As Alexander says, and I agree, there
> are only some vocabulary issues to be resolved.  Come up with a
> consistent, standard, and adequate (whatever that means) vocabulary,
> and you have a usable language...

Yep, I've always considered Glosa's grammar to be the thing that sets
it apart. Occasionally while struggling with the dictionaries I toyed
with the thought of applying Glosa's grammar to Esperanto's vocabulary.
I never really did anything much with that idea, but was amused to find
this bit a couple of years later, quoted in Pierre Janton's "Esperanto:
Language, Literature, and Community": "In the only place in which Zamenhof
describes the linguistic theory that he used to create his language",
he said...

#  I have arranged the language to allow for the *analysis*
#  of ideas into independent words, so that the entire
#  language, instead of consisting of words in various
#  grammatical forms, is made up exclusively of *unchanging*
#  [invariant] words. If you take a text written in my
#  language, you will find that every word appears *always*
#  in one invariant form *only*, namely in that form in
#  which it is printed in the dictionary. And the various
#  grammatical forms, the reciprocal relations among the
#  words, and so on, are expressed through the combination
#  of invariant words. But because a linguistic structure
#  of this kind is entirely foreign to European peoples
#  and it would be difficult for them to grow used to it,
#  I have presented this analytical aspect of the language
#  in a completely different way, in conformity with the
#  spirit of the European languages, so that anyone learning
#  my language with a textbook, without having read the
#  introduction first (which is quite unnecessary to the
#  learner), would not even imagine that the construction of
#  this language differed from his or her mother tongue. The
#  word "fratino", for example, in reality consists of three
#  words: "frat" 'brother', "in" 'woman', "o" ('something
#  that is, or exists') (= that which is a brother-woman
#  = 'sister'). But the textbook explains "fratino" as
#  follows: 'brother' is "frat", and it ends in "-o" because
#  all nouns end in "-o" in the nominative, hence "frat'o";
#  to indicate the female form of this same idea, we add the
#  small word "in", hence "frat'in'o"; and the apostrophes
#  are added to show the constituent grammatical parts of
#  the word. In this way the *analytical* nature of the
#  language in no way embarrasses the student; he does not
#  even suspect that what he calls an ending or a prefix or
#  a suffix is, in fact, an entirely free-standing word,
#  which carries the same meaning whether it comes at the
#  beginning or end of another word or stands on its own;
#  that every word can be used equally as a root-word or as
#  a grammatical particle. [Zamenhof 1903: 234-35]

Interesting, no?

- Bill

interspersed with what looked like formatting/html lines, perhaps this was 
affected/infected?

mine unless I am asked not to.

and find in mails to me. with the number of times each word is used  in a 
word-used dictionary. There can also be a file with the words listed in order 
of frequency. Sub dictionaries can then be found of words of more than a 
given amount of importance.
3)  Following Robin's mail and as I am doing various experiments etc 
suggested in part by members, I would be interested in what Paul and Charles 
put forward as a rather wayward volunteer
