    I will only respond to a point here and there.  (By the way, the
odd formatting is an artifact of the way my mailer handled the
non-standard formatting it received.)

On Sun, 26 Aug 2001, Robin Gaskell wrote:

> At 17:37 21/08/2001 -0700, [Charles] wrote:
> 
> >"Paul O. Bartlett" wrote [excerpts]:

> >> [etc.]

> >But by choosing a strict word order, this limits the audience.
> 
> >   .....
> 
> *   Thanks Charles for this clear restatement of your ideas.
> 
>      # Some level of optionality in word order at the start -
>      # allowing learners to filter into Glosa from different language
>      # traditions.

    I have long disagreed with the idea of allowing free word order 
in an international auxiliary language, at least in straight prose.
Suppose I am trying to learn Language X (natural or constructed).  If
it has a customary word order, I can learn it and depend on it even if
that word order differs from that of my native language.  However, if
the word order is relatively free, I am always struggling to keep my
footing, as it were.  Relatively free word order just increases the
learning burden, something that should be lessened as much as possible,
not increased.  The languages of the world are diverse enough that no
matter what language -- natural or constructed -- we choose and use,
SOMEBODY is going to be at a disadvantage over SOME characteristic(s)
of the language.  I see no way around this unpleasant fact.

> # "Allow optional marking.  Design the lang so it's easy to get
> # right, difficult to be wrong.
> 
>         *** This is, I feel, beautifully put. ***

    Beautifully put, yes, but I don't think that it is possible.  I
will, however, consider arguments.

    Of reforms there is no end.  I myself, as I have stated previously,
think that structurally Glosa is workable as is, with no changes
needed.  For me the only issue is vocabulary selection.  Once an IAL is
good enough, then it is good enough, and endless tinkering just impedes
use and promotion.  In the end, linguistic characteristics are NOT the
most important factors in the spread and use of a conIAL.  Just look at
Esperanto.

> Is this what "Proba" was all about?

    No.  According to "Glosa 6000," 'proba' means "test, trial."  Right
after I re-subscribed to the list, I was wondering whether I was having
email problems, so "Proba" was nothing more, originally, than a test
message.  A thread developed, keeping the same Subject.

--

"Paul O. Bartlett" wrote:

> > Some level of optionality in word order at the start -
> > allowing learners to filter into Glosa from different language
> > traditions.

>     I have long disagreed with the idea of allowing free word order
> in an international auxiliary language, at least in straight prose.

Word order or constituent order? The 2nd is practically unavoidable.
And then, how to handle participial constructions? Glosa basically
can't handle them at all, which makes writing anything more than
a few sentences very difficult.

But even limited to just the adj-noun vs. noun-adj issue, half of Europe
and half of the world are going to have difficulty; maybe, that's just
part of the cost to be paid -- but Occidental and similar IALs avoid it.

> Once an IAL is
> good enough, then it is good enough, and endless tinkering just impedes
> use and promotion.

Glosa isn't, and has essentially zero user base to worry about losing.
I'm not interested in a "freeze it" vs. "reform" debate, I consider it
beyond reasonable doubt that reform or disappearance is Glosa's future.
So rather than argue it, I'd prefer to discuss the major features that
most people would want to keep in Glosa, or see appear in a revision
or similar new effort. If nobody else agrees, I've said my piece.

I really beg your pardon for not writing in Glosa but English which even
isn't my own language so I am in fact using it as an international
language. On the other hand I don't think it correct to use the language I
would use in principal for international communication.

Now ad rem! Free word order is generally a misunderstanding. When learning
Latin I was told that the word order was so free! This is not true. It
looks free, much like a nomad people looks free to the antropologist who
comes to study these people roaming the deserts. They don't see the little
limitation, the unseen relations etc. Same with free word order languages.
You can use word order for emphasis, to show whether a word should take
the article if you translate it or a lot of other things, so what looks as
free word order in most cases might not be that.

Cellus

Glosa belongs to the type of international auxiliary languages that need a
very strong PR base and lots of people to use it. In comparison to languages
like Interlingua and Occidental that I could profit from even if I were the
only speaker of them, Glosa needs, like Esperanto and Ido a very strong
promotion base.

This is not to be understood as a playing down of their value, just that
they have to be propagated in another way.

As far as I can understand Glosa is wrong from its very start. It would need
a lot of work to get flying.

> Well, Glosa did teach me some Greek words. I don't
> bump into those very often, well, explicitly anyway!

I think Glosa's weak web presence (especially up until
recently) has been a problem. My perception of it was that
much of the material was "closed", and only available on
paper, for a fee. Certainly a turn-off in this day and age.
I think it is better now, but not yet as open and available
as it should be.

Glosa needs to be good enough, in a dramatic way, to catch
people's attention, and then hold it. I think the
syntax/grammar/whatever you want to call it does that. I
don't see major problems with the variance of trailing
vowels, nor with the repetition of pa and whatever.

So what would it take for ME to start using Glosa on this
list, at least? Hmmm. I guess I would need to take another
look at the Glosa 1000 list. If it's freely available,
seems stable, and enough other people can agree to use it,
then I think I'm on board.

With a core group of maybe ten people using Glosa as the
primary language for this list, it should start to grow. I
would encourage people who post in Glosa to include an
English translation too, to allow part-timers to understand
the material, and practice their translation.

After that, it's a matter of getting the news out to the
world at large. Mentions on personal Websites, getting into
search engines and dmoz, etc. We would need to write
stories, articles and other samples so people have lots of
Glosa to read and learn from.

Can Glosa become widely popular? I have no idea. I just
know that I prefer Glosa (as-is) over Esperanto, Lojban,
and every other auxlang that I've evaluated. If any one of
them is going to win the popularity race, I would prefer it
be Glosa.

Kevin

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: [glosalist] 18 Steps online
From: "Marcel Springer" <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>
Date: Fri, 7 Sep 2001 22:39:15 +0200

Very good news:  Wendy gave me permission to publish her book "18 Steps
to Fluency in Euro-Glosa" on the web.  And so I did, please visit 

  http://www.glosa.org/en/g18s.htm 

(190 kB HTML and about 185 kB GIF).  A German version is under
construction: 

  http://www.glosa.org/dt/g18s.htm 

Before, Glosa had no real description and no good learning material in 
the internet.  So this is a step forward, I think.  

Perhaps it is strange, but remarkable, that the Glosa authors did 
not present their language in a theoretical grammar book or a somehow 
scientific work, but in form of a children's school book. 

Here is my foreword: 

"This HTML-file is a light version of the book

  Ashby, Wendy/ Clark, Ronald: 
  18 Steps to Fluency in Euro-Glosa, 
  The Interlanguage for Europe and the World, 
  3rd edition (c) 1992 by Glosa Education Organizaton, 
  Richmond, UK; ISBN 0 946540 15 2. 

You can buy the book from Wendy Ashby (c/o Glosa Education 
Organization, P. O. Box 18, Richmond Surrey TW9 2GE, England). 
With its price of 8.95 GBpound you would supply Glosa development and 
spreading. 

This file is not the whole book, and does not want to be.  
Though all sample sentences and all roules are contained, only
Step 1, 2, 3, 5, 9, 13, 16, 17 and 18 are really complete.  
The Glosa 1000 vocabulary list is missing, please refer to the 
  Glosa Internet Dictionary ( http://www.glosa.org/gid/index.html ). 
This version is meant only as a supplement of Glosa's presentation in 
the internet. 

>From the book itself and a letter I got from Wendy Ashby, I have 
the feeling, that this book is meant as THE OFFICIAL description 
of Glosa. 
  
Please report errors to marcel{at}glosa{dot}org !  Thank you. 

M. Springer, 2001"

Kevin Smith wrote:

> How is "o" pronounced in Glosa?

Like in Spanish, Italian (most dialects), Swahili, Japanese.

The problem for non-linguists is that British English often
uses /eu/ diphthong for /o/ instead of the "pure" O vowel.
Americans use /ou/, also not quite right, needs clipping.
But since there are only 5 Glosa vowels, anybody can make a
good enough approximation. Just spread them out (dissimilate).
It's *supposed* to be easy, by design ...

Assuming you speak with my accent, words like "bought" and
"boat" straddle the boundaries of a theoretically meticulous
Glosa O, and it's pretty nearly the same with most other
Euro-style IALs like Esperanto and Ido etc. But an L.A.
accent rhymes "bought" with "bot", more like Glosa A,
so one must specify which dialect is used.

New Jerseyan to Glosa vowel mapping:
A: as in "bat" or "bot" (not "bad")
E:       "bet" or "bait" (not "beat")
I:       "bit" or "beat" (not "bite")
O:    "bought" or "boat" (not "bot")
U:      "book" or "boot" (not "but")

BTW, "bot" is Modern Cyber English for "robot".

Kevin pa grafo, 01-09-13:
 > The dictionaries all have aperi, not apri. Dosie isn't in

 > 
 > There seem to be several words in the "18 steps" that
 > aren't in the other lists, which is a bit disturbing. Are

Yes, we should do that. 

The biggest part of the "18 Steps" book contains word lists.  A lot of 
them are missing in the internet version, because (I was lazy and) I 
thought, a dictionary would be a better place for them. 

"18 Steps" has got a lot of special words (household, apiculture), 
that are not in the Dictionary yet and that are worth a research and 
supplement to the Internet Dictionary.  

We could write a program (with "grep" or whatever), that compares my 
HTML-file ( http://www.glosa.org/en/g18s.htm ) with the Glosa Internet 
Dictionary ( http://www.glosa.org/gid/glen.txt ).  So we could 
identify words not yet in the dictionary.  And we can supplement new 
meanings. 

With the same program we could research in texts of the newspaper 
"Plu Glosa Nota".  Then we would get official Glosa words not yet in 
any dictionary.  Because "Plu Glosa Nota" is a lot of material 
(85 issues so far), covering a lot of topics, we would get a 
vocabulary, that is quite ripe.  Ripe, because it is not made by 
construction but by use in texts and communication, so a little 
"natural". 

My impression is, that "18 Steps" is OLDER (mainly 1985) than most of 
the word lists (mainly early 90ies).  So the GID is to be prefered.  
Certainly "18 Steps" would need an update, but I do not believe that 
we ever get it, because its author has died.  Nevertheless, the 
additional words and meanings should be collected.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Proba
From: "Paul O. Bartlett" <bartlett{at}smart{dot}net>
Date: Fri, 14 Sep 2001 20:42:58 -0400 (EDT)

    I was looking back over some old files, and I came across this post
by Charles.  Despite the time lapse, I decided to offer a thought or
two.

On Mon, 27 Aug 2001, Charles wrote:

> "Paul O. Bartlett" wrote:
> 
> > [cutting down to the end]

> > Once an IAL is
> > good enough, then it is good enough, and endless tinkering just impedes
> > use and promotion.
> 
> Glosa isn't, and has essentially zero user base to worry about losing.
> I'm not interested in a "freeze it" vs. "reform" debate, I consider it
> beyond reasonable doubt that reform or disappearance is Glosa's future.
> [...]

    I do not agree and have previously expressed my opinion that all I
think Glosa really needs is an agreed-upon, adequate (whatever that
turns out to be) vocabulary.  If it were not already workable, I could
not have exchanged two letters each way with a man in China who said
that he knew little English, and I know no Chinese.

    Now I agree that Glosa has at least very little (in relative terms)
user base to lose.  But I simply cannot agree that it is in a "reform
or die" condition.  It might disappear, but not because of any
intrinsic adequacy that I can see (if the standardized vocabulary
matter can be addressed).  In the end, linguistic characteristics are
only *one* factor relating to whether or not some auxiliary language
succeeds (in relative terms), and not the most important factor at
that.  Just look at Esperanto, or, even more to the point, English. 
Who in his right mind :-) would deliberately *construct* something like
English as an international auxiliary language and expect to be taken
seriously?  And yet English is the most successful international
auxiliary language the world has ever known -- it just isn't a
constructed one.

    In my essay "Thoughts on IAL Success" on my web site, I discuss
seven factors relating to why an IAL might or might not succeed.  One
of those, and the only one really addressing linguistic characteristics
as such, is "Good Enough."  For heaven's sake, if *English* (!) is the
world's most successful IAL ever, and if Tok Pisin (New Guinea Pidgin
English) can be used in parliamentary debates (so I have read), then
structurally Glosa works.

-- 
Paul Bartlett

>     I do not agree and have previously expressed my opinion that all I

Having said what I did, I wouldn't want to merely rehash it now,
though obviously we have each failed to convince the other.
But I can add one point, namely that I spent several years
trying many of the well-known and some lesser-known IALS,
and they certainly vary greatly in perceived effectiveness.
Failure to distinguish significant differences is an indictment
of the whole lot of IALs, whose purpose is to provide a *better*
solution than "just learn English", or (worse) "lernu Esperanton".

u fiti,tagetes minuta, du poto militi plu-id ne-ama in plu de insekte e in 
plu de hetere fiti. il du es u fiti qi poto kresce proxi bi metre alta - id 
du es plu floro qi es minutu.

id du repulsu plu-id solu habita ne-anima per du exkrete plu keme ab u-id 
radi. HDRA pa kursu plu experimente te detekte si tagetes du poto cidi 
agropiron repens (u gra qi es fo dificili te kontrolo). SP pa auxu. sed u-la 
anua pa es fo frigi e fo hidro e u  peci de tagete  sperme pa reste somno. no 
homo plu ne-bono sperme. plu-mu fiti pa kresce,  kresce e kresce

a-kron de-u (em-u) peci pa (ge-) tege e kripti per-u prese de alta kloro. a 
ultimi, SP pa deskende a plu-an manu e genu e pa cerke. an, a-u-la tem, pa 
vidi plu
baba-fiti qi an pa no rekogno. an pa trakta pan plu hetere fiti ana e pa 
detekte pente striki de tagete. u seqe di, tem an pa es ab, u-an gini pa ki 
ad in
u horti te puru u peci e pa cidi proxi pan u tagete. tem u sti hiberneia, il 
pa es  oligi pusi, tristi panda fiti qi pa morto a u primi kristi.

anti-co, de pan pa no perde, plu agropiron gra pa es establa itere e plu-id 
infri-solu kulmu pa faca u kripti histi tape sed qo-lo plu tagete pa pre 
kresce, plu de plu kulmu pa haba plu pusi longo de aridi, brunu e pato lo. 
pluso u solu pa rauta.  u-co solu du es kimerage kerama, tem hidro, u glisi 
limi,tem aridi, u fisi sklere betono . nu, pere plu tagete radi, u homo solu 
pa es u horti-pe delekto - moli, fria e facili de ergo e kresce.

<HTML><FONT FACE=arial,helvetica><FONT  SIZE=2>---------
<BR>15-9-01
<BR>
<BR>u fiti,tagetes minuta, du poto militi plu-id ne-ama in plu de insekte e in plu de hetere fiti. il du es u fiti qi poto kresce proxi bi metre alta - id du es plu floro qi es minutu.
<BR>
<BR>id du repulsu plu-id solu habita ne-anima per du exkrete plu keme ab u-id radi. HDRA pa kursu plu experimente te detekte si tagetes du poto cidi agropiron repens (u gra qi es fo dificili te kontrolo). SP pa auxu. sed u-la anua pa es fo frigi e fo hidro e u &nbsp;peci de tagete &nbsp;sperme pa reste somno. no homo plu ne-bono sperme. plu-mu fiti pa kresce, &nbsp;kresce e kresce
<BR>
<BR>a-kron de-u (em-u) peci pa (ge-) tege e kripti per-u prese de alta kloro. a ultimi, SP pa deskende a plu-an manu e genu e pa cerke. an, a-u-la tem, pa vidi plu
<BR>baba-fiti qi an pa no rekogno. an pa trakta pan plu hetere fiti ana e pa detekte pente striki de tagete. u seqe di, tem an pa es ab, u-an gini pa ki ad in
<BR>u horti te puru u peci e pa cidi proxi pan u tagete. tem u sti hiberneia, il pa es &nbsp;oligi pusi, tristi panda fiti qi pa morto a u primi kristi.
<BR>
<BR>anti-co, de pan pa no perde, plu agropiron gra pa es establa itere e plu-id infri-solu kulmu pa faca u kripti histi tape sed qo-lo plu tagete pa pre kresce, plu de plu kulmu pa haba plu pusi longo de aridi, brunu e pato lo. pluso u solu pa rauta. &nbsp;u-co solu du es kimerage kerama, tem hidro, u glisi limi,tem aridi, u fisi sklere betono . nu, pere plu tagete radi, u homo solu pa es u horti-pe delekto - moli, fria e facili de ergo e kresce.
<BR>sid</FONT></HTML>

Here, I confess that I've taken an English shortcut. This
is a problem with any language, of course. "German" is our
English name for that language, and not the Deutscher (?)
word for it.

>From the "18 Steps" document:

the native name. Eg. England-lingua or English."

I guess it would be English and Espana-lingua (?). Not sure
about China. But in "18 Steps" they sometimes use "France"
instead of "Francais". 

Of course we also have problems because Glosa doesn't have
an n with a tilde, nor the modified c used in French. And,
of course, that is also a common problem between languages.

Perhaps someone more expert in Glosa could clarify this. Is
there a list of common country and language names in Glosa?

Kevin

Kevin pa grafo, 2001-09-16:
 > Is it true that the Glosa word
 > should *look* rather than *sound* as much like the native
 > word as possible? That is, would it be Espana instead of
 > Espania? Canada instead of Kanada?

I would say:
 - Normal words phonetical,
 - but names look and sound as in their original language.
 - By languages, that do not use the Latin alphabet:
     ---> Try to find the original name and put it into
          Glosa-phonetical letters (Greece becomes "Helas").
          Or use the English name, speak it Italian and put that into
          Glosa-phonetical letters (China becomes "Cina").
 - Names start always with capital letters.

Exsamples:
 - Spain, write "España" and speak "Espanja". "España-lingua",
   "Español".  Only, if no n-tilde available, write "Espanjol".
 - "France-lingua" (speak "Frons-lingua") or "Français" (speak
   "Fronsei") for French
 - "German" in German "deutsch" (small letter), in Glosa "Deutsch",
   speak "Doec".
 - write "Canada" and speak "Kanada".

Now, only one problem is left ...

Kjell pa grafo:
 > Sverige and Sverige-lingua then for Sweden and Suomi - Suomilingua
 > for country and language. Sverige-pe would be a Swedish person like
 > myself.
 > Right?

... but it is not so big, I think: - countries with more than one
language.  So "Suomi" (Finnish) and "Finland" (Swedish) should be
correct.  Similar "Belgique" (French, speak "Belscik") and "Belge"
(Flemish), "Suisse" (French), "Schweitz" (German, speak "Scvaits")
and "Svizzera" (Italian).

U-la mode mi pa logi plu Glosa autori.  Si tu doxo; mi habe ero; place
grafo.  Saluta a Sverige, USA (Mi dice "yoo-es-ey" e ne "oo-es-aw".) e
pan-pe ex Marcel

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Why is Glosa6000 for sale?
From: hzi{at}uol{dot}com{dot}br
Date: Sun, 23 Sep 2001 11:21:12 -0300

Hello-

	I'm sorry that I have to write this in English, this is my
third day of Glosa.
	
	I would like o express the opinion here, that ** all **
materials must be downloaded. The concept that someone will make money
out of an international language is outrageous.
	It will never truly be a candidate for a srong IAL if things
are sold.
	
	I think you have to garantee that the material is not
copyrighted by someone else, though.

	Are you familiar with the GNU/Linux computer distribution? These
guys have come up with a way to make the only operating system that
even threatens Microsoft. They way it's done is that key things in a
GNU/Linux operating system cannot be "sold". They can be distributed,
though.
	The GNU/Linux distribution I use is the Debian GNU/Linux. It
is a non-profit organization, made up of hundreds of international
volunteers that are in the computer industry. They don't make any
money out of it. You can download the whole operating system for free,
if you want. If, however, for your convenience, you shouold choose to
buy a CD-ROM, it's ok. All that will be charged is the fact that I
made the CD-ROM and mailed it to you. Our reward is the development of
a better product which we ourselves use. We think we've come up with
one of the best solutions in the market, although we remain ** outside
** the market. We think we're better than Microsoft, and we don't care
if people believe it or not. We don't even care if they use Debian or
not. We do. (No entirely true - we care in a political sense - we
think too many governments waste money on products, when they could be
using Free Software).

	Likewise, I think Glosa6000 material should be freely
downloadable. If people want to buy a book, there should be that
option too. But ** having ** to buy Glosa6000 is going to hinder the
progress.

	Do you think all people the remote corners of the world have a
credit card? Just now, governments in the Third World are setting up
free internet access.

	I'm interested in Glosa because the Debian GNU/Linux
distribution has been translated to some 80-plus languages. It is
possibly the only distribution that has achieved this, since we're not
market-oriented, but quality-oriented. As you can imagine, I think
interaction between our software developers could be greatly augmented
by the adoption of an IAL. 

	I found Esperanto difficult, even though Portuguese is my
native language. I also read Spanish, Italian, French, and I am now
studying German. As soon as I laid my eye on Glosa, I was able to
understand, or sort out, what was written. Esperanto is not like this
at all. Interlingua is too biased towards the languages I already
speak. As I've said, many of the languages in the Debian distribution
are non-western.

	The Debian linux community I believe, will eventually come to
the realisation that an IAL is vital necessity for the way we develop
software. 

	From what I've seen, you might have to change a few things,
like one having o ** buy ** Glosa6000. I mean, you're entitled to sell
a book, because you put effort into it. But if that's the only source
of Glosa6000, and ** there isn't anyother available ** from a link at
www.glosa.org, than you're not ever going to succeed. Which would be
rather unfortunate for the whole of us, since Glosa seems to be such
an excellent choice.


	Regards,

	Henry

> I am a very bad glosa-pe myself and have not been able to learn the
> language, but in the IAL-market perhaps this is a good way in promoting
> Glosa, allthough I am very doubtful of bot the way it has been promoted and
> the language itself.
> 
> There are those who think that people should pay for what they get. Then you

> Cellus

 If your payment is the product itself, and the benefits derived from
 the widespread use of it, then I think it's more than paid for.

 That's why I mentioned the Linux community.
 More than 60% of the computers serving the web pages you see run on
 Free Software (the Apache server). I am not talking of home PCs, but
 the infra-structure behind them, which you do not see.

 This is a perfect example.

 I feel people will not join Glosa if they feel someone's making a
 profit with it, all the while saying that it's "a language for the
 world".

 We'll all have to stick with Esperanto, if it's like that...

 Regards,

 Henry

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Why is Glosa6000 for sale?
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 23 Sep 2001 11:00:53 -0700

hzi{at}uol{dot}com{dot}br wrote:

>         I'm sorry that I have to write this in English, this is my
> third day of Glosa.

Everybody interested in Glosa writes in English, for several reasons.
If you hang around long enough you will come to understand why.

>         I would like o express the opinion here, that ** all **
> materials must be downloaded. The concept that someone will make money
> out of an international language is outrageous.

Anything that requires work to produce, requires payment for the worker,
directly or indirectly.

>         Likewise, I think Glosa6000 material should be freely
> downloadable. If people want to buy a book, there should be that
> option too. But ** having ** to buy Glosa6000 is going to hinder the
> progress.

Nobody forces you to buy the book. Pick it up by just using it
with others (if you can find any). Some other IALs work that way.
Use "international vocabulary", which Wendy referred to somewhere.

> I think
> interaction between our software developers could be greatly augmented
> by the adoption of an IAL.

Now, that's a cool idea ... but I think English will have to do.
No IAL is so easy that it can be picked up without some effort
and a lot of continual practice, so programmers won't do it --
we'd prefer to engineer our own new interlingua-protocol.

>         I found Esperanto difficult, even though Portuguese is my
> native language. I also read Spanish, Italian, French, and I am now
> studying German. As soon as I laid my eye on Glosa, I was able to
> understand, or sort out, what was written.

If more people had such great language skills as you do, there would be
no need for any IAL. Are you saying all you need is a vocab list and
then you could handle Glosa? That is available, see Marcel's web pages.

Mi akorda, panto baso dosie du nece existe libe e gratis (e

ma de 6000 verba, ka-co mi du kredi qod panto-ra nece du

---
I agree that all the fundamental materials must be freely
available (and have said so in the past). And, in fact, the
online word lists seem to have at least 6000 words, so I
believe everything you need is available for free.
(Although I don't know if Glosa 6000 is more than just a

> 	The GNU/Linux distribution I use is the Debian

===
Iso de mi.
---
Me too.
===

===
U fo-importa ra te extende u Glosa es du habe ma grafo IN
Glosa. So mi du translati mi nexu loka
(www.qualitycode.com) a Glosa. Na du pote lekto DE Glosa
holo tem, sed id ne fu gene popula, si ne na du lekto e
grafo IN Glosa.
---
One of the most important tools to spread Glosa is having
more text IN Glosa. That's why I'm translating my website
to Glosa(www.qualitycode.com). We can sit around reading
ABOUT Glosa forever, but it won't catch on unless/until we
are reading and writing IN Glosa.
===

===
Kausa tu du interese de puta-me programa, fu vide a mi

fini, a-nu.
---
Since you have an interest in software, be sure to look at
my list of technical terms in Glosa. It's not finished yet.
===

===
Mi du spe, tu du resta ko Glosa. Na sio uti plu tu auxi.
---
I hope you continue to work with Glosa. We can use the
help.
===

(Forgive any Glosa errors--this was written fairly quickly)

Kevin

From: Kevin Smith <kevinbsmith{at}yahoo{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 23 Sep 2001 11:30:12 -0700 (PDT)

Mi du ergo ko u baso verba lista de "Glosa Basic
Reference". Id es ma boni de plu hetero existe lista. Multi
verba es fo-hetero, anti de plu hetero lista.

Mi du detekti multi verba ko homo semani. Mi du krea u neo
lista: mi du apo multi verba, e mi du adi multi verba. Mi
fu publika.

Plu-ci verba fu ge-apo, kausa ne es ma uti:
vestibula
tetra-ze
abe
album
kristonati
game-zo
sue-me
sulko

Plu-ci verba fu ge-apo, kausa u hetero verba es ma-boni.
Singu proto verba fu ge-apo, kausa du existe u seqe verba:
sti mira -> stupe
leuko -> albi
miria -> multi (fo-multi)
austra -> sud
boreo -> nord
limni -> laku
limno -> laku
pluvia -> pluvi
stereo -> solidi
undu -> unda
grafi -> grafo
lexi -> verba
signifi -> semani
skribe -> grafo
latici -> latex
semi -> hemi
vita -> vive
poli -> multi
seti -> septi
zero -> ze
siniorina -> siniora
fungus -> fungu
gosipa -> kotona
kotoni -> kotona
malus -> pomi
residu -> resti
olface -> odoro
gimno -> nudi
keno -> vaku
laxi -> laxa
artro -> artikula
nima -> nomina
pragma -> ra
mana -> matina
noktu -> nokti
po-kron -> tardi
foli -> fisa
kaeto -> seta
kapsu -> paketa
kunea -> kune
mekina -> mekani
vasa -> vaso
mobi -> vagona

Mi sio amo plu tu idea.

Kevin

Please take the Glosa Internet Dictionary 
(GID, http://www.glosa.org/gid ).  

The vocabulary list of the book "Glosa 6000" is completely included!

money for a paper version.

     the GID via internet.

--- Marcel Springer <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de> wrote:
> My suggestion for a base vocabulary would be the GID-Core
> version. 

Interesting. In my own writing, the Basic Reference has
often had better word selections than the core.

I'm curious about the chronology and relationships between:
G1000
G6000
GID full
GID core
Basic Reference
18 steps

Which are newest? Oldest? Which were derived from which
others? What are the credentials of the GID core that put
it on top?

My goal is to have a word list for my own use, which is a
good subset of standard Glosa dictionaries. If other people
choose to use it, that's fine, but it's really for me. I
almost created my own word in one case [1], but ended up
sticking entirely to existing words.

I don't like having multiple words with the same meaning,
so I'm removing all exact duplication. At the same time,
I'm omitting some words that don't belong in a "core" list,
and adding others that I need on a regular basis, or feel
would be important in daily use (like sink, chair, shovel,
important, "ke", etc.)

I've put my list into a standard-format data file that will
allow me to automatically generate lists sorted three ways:
English-Glosa
Glosa-English
Categorized

I've created a bunch of categories, like "animals" and
"time", which really helped me detect duplications. I've
also annotated all changes from the original Basic
Reference, so people will know what I added, removed, or
changed.

Anyway, it's a fun project.

Kevin

[1] besboli really bothers me. It has neither of the roots
for "base" nor "ball". I had basbola in my list for a bit,
but then realized that it was the only professional sport
in the list, which seemed out of place. So I just removed
besboli instead. As long as I don't have to look at it, it
won't bother me.

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>, <kevins{at}pobox{dot}com>
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Glosa core vs. Basic Reference
From: "Marcel Springer" <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>
Date: Mon, 24 Sep 2001 10:02:39 +0200


Kevin pa grafo, 2001-09-24: 
 > I'm curious about the chronology and relationships between:
 > G1000
 > G6000
 > GID full
 > GID core
 > Basic Reference
 > 18 steps
 > 
 > Which are newest? Oldest? Which were derived from which
 > others? What are the credentials of the GID core that put
 > it on top?

I want to try an answer.

G1000 (1972 ... 1992):
  Is the 'heart of Glosa'.  The words that should be prefered. 
  But unfortunately there are several lists of G1000 contradicting 
  each other. 

G6000 (1983, 1985, 1992): 
  Some Glosa-pe complained, that 1000 words are too few.  So Ron Clark 
  wrote the G6000-book.  
  Unfortunately, G1000 is not completely included. And it does not 
  really increase the expressivity of Glosa, because there are a lot 
  of synonyms to G1000 words in it.  It also has typing errors and 
  ending vowel confusions.

  So we needed a list, that contains all words, a list, that preferes 
  G1000, but that is supplemented by the words of G6000, which are 
  really valuable because they are not synonyms to G1000 words.  That 
  is what the GID tries. 

Basic Reference (1996): 
  is an Internet version of G1000 by Paul Bartlett.  Paul recognized 
  some lacks of G1000 and so he made some little changes/additions. 

18 steps (1985, 1989, 1992): 
  - a short version of it is http://www.glosa.org/en/g18s.htm - 
  is a learning book.  Its sections (steps) have vocabulary lists with 
  some very special words that are in no other list (e.g. sito-api - 
  forager bee). 
  At the end of the book, there are two G1000 lists, G-E and E-G, 
  unfortunately contradicting each other again. 

GID full (1998-2001): 
  Several people all over the world have worked on this list. 
  It is a combination of several word lists.  G6000, English5000 to 
  G1000 of the book Central Glosa (1993) and G-E of 18 Steps are 
  completely included. 
  But of course, there is a lot of work to do yet. 

GID core (1998-2001): 
  is a subset of GID full, and this time without contradictions, 
  because it is generated by a computer program. 
  It is a suggestion, which words should be prefered.  
  The words are elected that way, that their English meanings cover 
  possibly the most part of three scientifical lists of most often 
  used and most essential English words. 
  The words are nearly all G1000.  So GID Core is quite close to the 
  authors's Glosa.

>

>Are there no libraries you could go to and borrow the book? Then you read it

>and take notes...

>

*   Plura anua pre nu, mi pa habe u ^Glosa 6000^ ge-kopi in elektroni mode.

    To mi domi, mi habe mo de plu-ci bibli ko u spina ge-seka: u kompani; qi pa skano u bibli pa sekti id.

    Po la, mi face u prima elektroni versio, de u Glosa -> England-lingua mero, de ^Glosa 6000^.  U-ci pa gene ge-distribu a plu membra de u Glosalist uti u puta-me diska.

    Epi u-ci diska; qi mi bali ad ali Glosalist-pe; petitio id, es pluso u ge-versi verbi-lista de proxi 6000 verbi - ex England-lingua a Glosa.

   ------

    A nu, boni.

    Sed, per forma u retro versio de u diktionari, mi pa detekti poli homo-nima.  E ex u-ci detekti, plu Glosalist-pe pa ski ke u lista nece habe meliora.

    Holo plu tenta, de forma plu ma boni diktionari, pa seqe u-ci proto ergo.


    Po u-la tem, mi logi ke u 6000-verbi lista es epi u Reti.  Sed u major buta de distribu id ab un Inter-reti, pa es te alexi u merca de u bibli per u Glosa Eduka Organiza.  ^Glosa 6000^ ne es libe de kopi-lega, sed mi kredi ke Wendy Ashby nu sio acepta u publika de u-ci bibli per u Reti.


    Te publika un origi papira versio de u bibli uti valuta, so Wendy e Ron pa vendo poli kopi de id, e oligo tem, don id a plu pove Glosa-pe.

    Durante mo anua, mi pa uti u ge seka kopi de ^Glosa 6000^; qi pa gene ge-separa te face facili u skano procesa.  Seqe-co, mi pa merca u hetero no-seka versio de ^Glosa 6000^ ex Wendy, ka mi prefero uti u bibli, anti uti un epi-skuto, elektroni-pagina.


    U papira bibli dona facili de uti, sed habe u produce preci.


    Ali persona; qi habe forti este koncerne u publika de u-ci bibli epi u Reti, sio debi grafo a Wendy Ashby te don an kaso pro loka id intra u Publiko Area.


Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

At 10:02 24/09/2001 +0200, Marcel Springer wrote:

>

>Kevin pa grafo, 2001-09-24: 

> > I'm curious about the chronology and relationships between:

> > G1000

> > G6000

> > GID full

> > GID core

> > Basic Reference

> > 18 steps

> > 

> > Which are newest? Oldest? Which were derived from which

> > others? What are the credentials of the GID core that put

> > it on top?

>

>I want to try an answer.

>   .....

>

>G6000 (1983, 1985, 1992): 

>  Some Glosa-pe complained, that 1000 words are too few.  So Ron Clark 

>  wrote the G6000-book.  

>  Unfortunately, G1000 is not completely included. And it does not 

>  really increase the expressivity of Glosa, because there are a lot 

>  of synonyms to G1000 words in it.  It also has typing errors and 

>  ending vowel confusions.

>

>  So we needed a list, that contains all words, a list, that preferes 

>  G1000, but that is supplemented by the words of G6000, which are 

>  really valuable because they are not synonyms to G1000 words.  That 

>  is what the GID tries. 

>

*   While I did find difficulties, particularly with checking both ends to see if the translation was present - so I would know a reader was able to find the meaning of the Glosa word I used, I definitely felt a lot happier with the flexibility offerred by the larger list.


    However, having said that, I recognise the absolute need for an unambiguous, all-inclusive GID, and encourage its completion.


    While putting the lexicon into shape, I feel, also, that we should - at the same time - be taking the language out of the garage, and giving it a run around the block a couple of time, periodically.

    To this end I suggest the compilation of a book of children's stories - in Glosa, of course.


Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

U-ci du monstra u stimula qestio. Pre nu, u repli pa indiki
ke plu natio du debe litera iso de auto in u origi lingua.
U-ci du es boni pro grafo.

Sed u-ci, Sydney du proposi u mode ke es homo de multi
hetero lingua: du litera plu natio homo ma fono, in u origi
lingua. U-ci du es boni pro dice. Plus, id du evita plu
problema de alterna litera-fa, qi es gravi, mi du kredi.

Qe, mi ne ski de plu gravi profito de u proto mode? Qe, es
ma boni kausa na du kredi ke Glosa fu ge-uti pro grafo ma
de dice?

Kevin

---
This raises an interesting question. Earlier, the response
was that countries should be spelled as they are in the
native language. Which makes sense for written
communication.

But here Sydney is proposing the approach taken by many
other languages, which is to spell countries phonetically
as they are spoken in the native language. Which makes
sense for oral communication. It also avoids issues with
alternate character sets, which is (in my mind)
significant.

Am I missing some major advantage of the former approach?
Is it better because Glosa is expected to be used more for
writing than for speaking?

Kevin

From: "Marcel Springer" <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>

... "18 Steps to Fluency in Euro-Glosa" ...
... http://www.glosa.org/en/g18s.htm ...
... I got corrections from Nick Hempshall ...

I was very happy, that Nick - as an English man - had problems with
"kemi-bo" (="chemist's", Nick suggested "medika-ma-bo" or "farmako-bo")
and "kloro-bo" (="green grocer's", Nick suggested "sito-fito-bo"),
too.

I did not like some other things in the "18 Steps", because my native
language is not English.  I would rather hear some comments from you
about them:

-----------------------------------------

p. 11:
Pend id epi mura
- Hang it on the wall
- Häng es an die Wand
 ---> Mi sio ma amo "ad mura" (cf. adhesive)

p. 11:
skope u programa epi TV
- Watch a program on TV
- eine Sendung im Fernsehen sehen
 ---> Mi sio ma amo "in TV".  (Tu pote loka u flori-vasa "epi" TV-me.)
      Mali-fortuna, English "program" eqa Deutsch "Sendung" e Deutsch
      "Programm" eqa English "channel".

p. 19:
Siniora. Siniorina (Sa.)
- Mrs. Miss (Ms)
- Frau. Fräulein
 ---> Qe "Sa." es brevi verba pro "Siniora" alo "Siniorina"?
      Mi sio amo simpli "andro" vice "Sinior" e "gina" vice "Siniora"
      e (!) "Siniorina".
      U Deutsch verba "Fräulein" (="pusi gina") es paleo e ne ge-amo.

p. 19:
A tu sinceri
- Yours sincerely
 ---> Mi sio ma amo solo "Saluta".
      (German commercial letters have only two possible greetings:
      friendly "Mit freundlichen Grüßen", and (perhaps a little less
      friendly) "Mit freundlichem Gruß".  All others are
      old-fashioned and should not be used any longer.)

p. 49:
Note: When 'who' or 'which' are the object of a clause they
are usually left out in English.  In Glosa we always leave them out.
Instead of saying; "The man WHOM I saw yesterday" we say "The man I
saw yesterday".
 ---> This rule is bad for an IAL.
      It is not only superfluous, but means an irregularity and,
      because it is an English phenomenon, it attacks Glosa's
      neutrality.
        "Un andro; mi pa vide qi pa-di."
      And very important: ";"!

-----------------------------------------

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] 18 Steps online
From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>

Marcel Springer wrote:

> I was very happy, that Nick - as an English man - had problems with
> "kemi-bo" (="chemist's", Nick suggested "medika-ma-bo" or "farmako-bo")
> and "kloro-bo" (="green grocer's", Nick suggested "sito-fito-bo"),
> too.
> 
> I did not like some other things in the "18 Steps", because my native
> language is not English.

Those are not even general English idioms, but ones peculiar to England.
Of course they should be corrected.

> Pend id epi mura
> - Hang it on the wall
> - Häng es an die Wand
>  ---> Mi sio ma amo "ad mura" (cf. adhesive)

That looks like a "causative" construction. I can't believe
it would seem natural to most non-English non-Germans. Better
would be "you make hang the object preposition somewhere".
Which preposition is used doesn't matter so much, "ad/at" is
most general but "on" must be allowed too.

> skope u programa epi TV
> - Watch a program on TV

I'd use "de" certainly. My cats watch from "on" the tv (monitor).

> Siniora. Siniorina (Sa.)
> - Mrs. Miss (Ms)
> - Frau. Fräulein
>  ---> Qe "Sa." es brevi verba pro "Siniora" alo "Siniorina"?
>       Mi sio amo simpli "andro" vice "Sinior" e "gina" vice "Siniora"
>       e (!) "Siniorina".
>       U Deutsch verba "Fräulein" (="pusi gina") es paleo e ne ge-amo.

A world language needs an honorific but it should not be sexist.
Unfortunately the Japanese "san" won't work as a preposition ...
Use of abbreviations should be avoided also.

> A tu sinceri
> - Yours sincerely
>  ---> Mi sio ma amo solo "Saluta".

A postposed adverb is an atrocity. Should be "con sinceri" or like that.

> Note: When 'who' or 'which' are the object of a clause they
> are usually left out in English.  In Glosa we always leave them out.
> Instead of saying; "The man WHOM I saw yesterday" we say "The man I
> saw yesterday".
>  ---> This rule is bad for an IAL.
>       It is not only superfluous, but means an irregularity and,
>       because it is an English phenomenon, it attacks Glosa's
>       neutrality.
>         "Un andro; mi pa vide qi pa-di."
>       And very important: ";"!

Glosa does not have a workable relative clause structure.
The semicoloned syntax is ridiculous. I would suggest using
"que/ke" for both animate and inanimate references, and add
a resumptive particle instead of relying on the more complex
syntax of gapped constructions. But what to use for the RP?

un  andro ke  mi pa  vide RP   in pa-di    ...
the man   who I  did see  such in past-day ...

Kevin Smith wrote:

> > un  andro ke  mi pa  vide RP   in pa-di    ...
> > the man   who I  did see  such in past-day ...
>
> Why does there need to be anything where the RP is? Isn't
> it already unambiguous? I feel like I'm missing something.

English uses the "gap" method, many other languages use a
"resumptive pronoun". In brief, the gap method is inferior.
The best URL (AFAIK) discussing these syntax issues is:

http://www.srv.net/~ram/syntax.html

To: glosalist <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: [glosalist] Mi du nece plu verba semani klari
From: Kevin Smith <kevinbsmith{at}yahoo{dot}com>
Date: Sat, 29 Sep 2001 22:08:35 -0700 (PDT)

I'm putting together my own updated Glosa/English core word
list, and I'm having trouble with several specific word
meanings. 

Each entry below has the Glosa word in question, the
English word that appears in the GID as a meaning, and my
question.

My goal is to have (relatively) unambigous links between
specific Glosa and English words. I want to provide
guidance as to why you might choose this translation over
that one, and eliminate any Glosa words from my list that
aren't provding real value. 

Some of my questions may seem really picky. In some cases,
the word might currently have two meanings for historical
reasons, but my goal is to try to distinguish between the
two, and point to a
different word.

I think it's important for an IAL to eliminate as much
ambiguity as possible. This means avoiding disparate
meanings for the same word.

ANY help would be greatly appreciated!

bato;deep (?), depth (?);
Is this physical depth only, or "profoundness" also?

bulbo;bulb (?);
Is this a plant seed like a tulip bulb? Or a shape like a
light bulb or bulbous nose?

decimali;decimal (?);
Is this an adjective? Or is it a decimal point? Or
something else? Why not use dek... instead of dec...?

delega;delegate (to?)
Is this transative or intransative? Is it to-delegate, or
be-a-delegate?

dirigi;direct (?);
I assume this is more like straight, and less like guide or
steer.

diskusi;conference (?)
Is this like a parent-teacher conference (huddle)? Or like
an international meeting?

figura;figure (?);
I'm guessing this is a noun, meaning something like a
shape, and not the verb to calculate.

fonda;background (?)
Is this like a visual backdrop? Or like foundational
background information?

hedo;fun (?)
ludo;fun (?)
How would you describe when "fun" is more like hedo, and
when it is more like ludo? Could I just remove it from
hedo?

idio;private (?);
Most of the meanings of idio have to do with identity and
uniqueness. How can it also mean private?

imagi;image (?);
Is this a physical image? Conceptual image? Any oft hose?
Imagina already takes care of imagination (mental image).

kompani;company (?);
Is this a business? Or like having company come to visit?
Or like a company of soldiers?

koncentra;concentrate (?);
Is this mental focus, or the physical opposite of dilute?
Perhaps in this case it is reasonable to mean both.

koncerne;concern (?);
Is this like "to worry", or "related-to"?

kontenta;content (?), constituent;
This seems like it would be the contents of something, like
a packing list, as opposed to being happy and content.

korka;cork (?);
Should I focus on the material (like a cork-board), or the
bottle-stopper (that might be plastic)?

kredito;credit (?);
Is this financial credit? Or respect for a job well done?

limita;rather (?);
Most of the meanings are limit, bound, frontier, etc. How
did "rather" get in this list?

liqi;fuse (?);
I assume this is like welding or soldering--fusing together
_by liquifying_, right?

lisi;smooth (?);
The other definitions are separate and isolate, so smooth
seems really out of place. I would think glisa would be
better for smooth.

orange;orange
I asked before, but is this the color or the fruit. I'm
leaning towards the fruit (since that seems to be the
original source of the word), which would make the color
ruby-xanto. Ok?

Kevin

On Sat, Sep 29, 2001 at 10:08:35PM -0700, Kevin Smith wrote:


Hi Kevin-

	I will try to help you with my limited knowledge.
	Since my native language is a neo-romance (Portuguese) I found
	some of your questions quite easy to answer.
	I am not a Latin scholar though...
	Therefore, the opinions expressed are not authoritative.
	I have to say I was kind of amused to see the questions that
	came up in your mind. Things I or other latin-speakers would
	never have any doubt about.
	But I see you point of view and in a way, I learned __how__ you
	think, as a native English speaker. It's clear that English
	carries more "precision" in the definition of terms, since you
	can borrow from latin and old-german roots. Latin languages
	are more ambiguous, or perhaps I should say things are defined
	more by their context or by analogy.
	Hope this helped.

> ANY help would be greatly appreciated!
> 
> bato;deep (?), depth (?);
> Is this physical depth only, or "profoundness" also?
>
 
  This has to do with depth, as in a "bathysphere", and not profound,
  as in "De profundis".

> bulbo;bulb (?);
> Is this a plant seed like a tulip bulb? Or a shape like a
> light bulb or bulbous nose?

  Seed. A light bulb is somewhat seed-ahaped, is't it?
> 
> decimali;decimal (?);
> Is this an adjective? Or is it a decimal point? Or
> something else? Why not use dek... instead of dec...?

  A "decimal" in Portuguese is a number with a decimal point; not a
  whole number and not expressed as a fraction.

> 
> delega;delegate (to?)
> Is this transative or intransative? Is it to-delegate, or
> be-a-delegate?
> 
  You delegate someone the power to vote for you.

> dirigi;direct (?);
> I assume this is more like straight, and less like guide or
> steer.

  "Dirigir" (Port.) [a car]. Dirigir as negociações (Steer, maneuver
  the negotiations). Guide or steer, or drive [as in car]. At least
  those would be my options. I believe someone speaking French would
  agree.

> 
> diskusi;conference (?)
> Is this like a parent-teacher conference (huddle)? Or like
> an international meeting?
> 
  Whe we say "conference" in Portuguese, or when I read it in French,
  Spanish, or Italian, it's that designates a situation more like an
  international meeting. It is more formal, and more important.
  It may also mean a "speech", or "lecture", or "presentation", as in
  a medical congress, or an academic lecture.

> figura;figure (?);
> I'm guessing this is a noun, meaning something like a
> shape, and not the verb to calculate.
 
  It designates shape, no doubt about that. "Calculate" = "calcular"
  (Port., Span.), "calculer" (Fr.), "calculare" (Ital.)
 
> fonda;background (?)
> Is this like a visual backdrop? Or like foundational
> background information?

  Both, depending on the context.

> 
> hedo;fun (?)
> ludo;fun (?)
> How would you describe when "fun" is more like hedo, and
> when it is more like ludo? Could I just remove it from
> hedo?
> 
  Ludo, IMMO, is probably more "child-like", as in "to play". It has
  do more with the imagination, or the creative mind or moment.
  Hedo is more "sensual", or having to with the five senses: the
  "hedonists", those that are adept of carnal pleasures.

> idio;private (?);
> Most of the meanings of idio have to do with identity and
> uniqueness. How can it also mean private?
>
  Take "identity": you have you __own__ identity, you have a unique
  face, and life history. It [this identidy]  doesn't belong
  to anyone but yourself. Therefore, it's also "private" in the sense
  of "1. of, belonging to, or concerning a particular person or groups
  of persons; not common or general; as __private__ property." Not in
  the sense of "5. not known to the public; secret; confidential; as
  in one's __private__ opinion".
  The above definitions are from Webster's Unabridged Dictionary, 2nd
  ed.

> imagi;image (?);
> Is this a physical image? Conceptual image? Any oft hose?
> Imagina already takes care of imagination (mental image).
> 
  Both. A mental image, a picture (physical or in the mind's eye), or
  a reputation.

> kompani;company (?);
> Is this a business? Or like having company come to visit?
> Or like a company of soldiers?

  All three, I feel, would be correct.
> 
> koncentra;concentrate (?);
> Is this mental focus, or the physical opposite of dilute?
> Perhaps in this case it is reasonable to mean both.

  Both.

> 
> koncerne;concern (?);
> Is this like "to worry", or "related-to"?

  Both.
> 
> kontenta;content (?), constituent;
> This seems like it would be the contents of something, like
> a packing list, as opposed to being happy and content.
> 
  To be happy is to be full of the quality, or feeling, of Happiness,
  right? So, as you can see, there's logic to both propsitions:
  content=happy, or content=contents.
  However, in Portuguese there's a difference between "contente"
  [happy and content] and "conteúdo" [contents].
  If kontenta is the root word then I feel it must mean both, since
  it had not evolved to the different, and more specific, forms.

> korka;cork (?);
> Should I focus on the material (like a cork-board), or the
> bottle-stopper (that might be plastic)?
>
  Since there was no plastic around in Acient Rome or Greece, to make
  things simple, I wouldn't make the difference. Maybe you could say
  "korka plastica".

> kredito;credit (?);
> Is this financial credit? Or respect for a job well done?
> 
  Both.

> limita;rather (?);
> Most of the meanings are limit, bound, frontier, etc. How
> did "rather" get in this list?

  Sounds logical, but I can't think at the moment, of an example in a
  latin language.

> liqi;fuse (?);
> I assume this is like welding or soldering--fusing together
> _by liquifying_, right?
>
  Or as in "mixing" different liquids.

> lisi;smooth (?);
> The other definitions are separate and isolate, so smooth
> seems really out of place. I would think glisa would be
> better for smooth.

  Smooth, IMHO.
>

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>, <kevins{at}pobox{dot}com>
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Mi du nece plu verba semani klari
From: "Nick Hempshall" <nick{at}hempshall{dot}fsbusiness{dot}co{dot}uk>
Date: Sun, 30 Sep 2001 23:08:29 +0100

My thoughts relating to Kevin Smith's questions.

A word in Glosa is intended to stand for only one
concept. But this concept may be represented in
English by a large number of words, and remember 
a Glosa word can act in any part of speech category.
A metaphorical usage must also be allowed.
 
> bato;deep (?), depth (?);
> Is this physical depth only, or "profoundness" also?

Physical depth is the intended meaning.

> bulbo;bulb (?);
> Is this a plant seed like a tulip bulb? Or a shape like a
> light bulb or bulbous nose?

Any swollen onion-shaped object .

> decimali;decimal (?);
> Is this an adjective? Or is it a decimal point? Or
> something else? Why not use dek... instead of dec...?

No fixed assignment to part of speech categories in Glosa!
The name of the base 10 system of counting.
Decimal point is "koma" (",").

C/K: My guess is the Latin "CI" tends to remain "CI" in Glosa.
 
> delega;delegate (to?)
> Is this transative or intransative? Is it to-delegate, or
> be-a-delegate?

I have ~delegati~.
It appears to me to be the action of giving a job to 
someone to do on your behalf. That makes the 
person doing the job a "ge-delegati-pe".

> dirigi;direct (?);
> I assume this is more like straight, and less like guide or
> steer.

I have ~direkti~ as the preferred form. Both mean guide/steer.
Straight would be ~rekti~.

> diskusi;conference (?)
> Is this like a parent-teacher conference (huddle)? Or like
> an international meeting?

Any kind of discussion.
 
> figura;figure (?);
> I'm guessing this is a noun, meaning something like a
> shape, and not the verb to calculate.

A shape.
Calculate is ~kalkula~.
Figure out (think) is ~puta~.
 
> fonda;background (?)
> Is this like a visual backdrop? Or like foundational
> background information?

Explanatory info. 

> hedo;fun (?)
> ludo;fun (?)
> How would you describe when "fun" is more like hedo, and
> when it is more like ludo? Could I just remove it from
> hedo?

~Hedo~ is pleasure or happiness and ~ludo~ is playing or a game.
So it depends on what you are doing for fun.

> idio;private (?);
> Most of the meanings of idio have to do with identity and
> uniqueness. How can it also mean private?

Private in the sense of personal, not public.

> imagi;image (?);
> Is this a physical image? Conceptual image? Any oft hose?
> Imagina already takes care of imagination (mental image).

A physical likeness.

> kompani;company (?);
> Is this a business? Or like having company come to visit?
> Or like a company of soldiers?

Business.
"Company come to visit" ~hospi~
Company of soldiers would be ~grega~.

> koncentra;concentrate (?);
> Is this mental focus, or the physical opposite of dilute?
> Perhaps in this case it is reasonable to mean both.

Focus mental activity, time or resources on something.
~Apo aqa~ remove water.

> koncerne;concern (?);
> Is this like "to worry", or "related-to"?

Worry is ~turba~. 
Related-to is ~de~. 
~Gravi pro~ is to matter/be concerned about.

> kontenta;content (?), constituent;
> This seems like it would be the contents of something, like
> a packing list, as opposed to being happy and content.

Contents are ~plu in-ra~.
Content is ~ge-place~ [pleased].
Constituent is ~mero-ma~

> korka;cork (?);
> Should I focus on the material (like a cork-board), or the
> bottle-stopper (that might be plastic)?

Material.

> kredito;credit (?);
> Is this financial credit? Or respect for a job well done?

Finance

> limita;rather (?);
> Most of the meanings are limit, bound, frontier, etc. How
> did "rather" get in this list?

Rather in the sense of "somewhat" / "to some extent or degree".
 
> liqi;fuse (?);
> I assume this is like welding or soldering--fusing together
> _by liquifying_, right?

Yes, or fusing "apart" (melting) as an electrical fuse does.

> lisi;smooth (?);
> The other definitions are separate and isolate, so smooth
> seems really out of place. I would think glisa would be
> better for smooth.

Yes, the G seems to have got separated from the rest of
the word. ~Glisa~ is slip, slide. Smooth is ~glabro~.


> orange;orange
> I asked before, but is this the color or the fruit. I'm
> leaning towards the fruit (since that seems to be the
> original source of the word), which would make the color
> ruby-xanto. Ok?

Fruit

Henry grafo

>   Don't know. When did the word "orange" come up. What do our
>   phylologists here say? "Xanto" is greek, so it's old. Is "orange"
>   Neo-Latin, or is it present in Latin texts?
>

13th century. Via Old French pomme d'orenge, a translation (influenced by
Orange, a town in France) of Italian melarancia 'orange fruit', via Arabic
naranj and Persian narang from Sanskrit narangah .

--- hzi{at}uol{dot}com{dot}br wrote:
> 	I will try to help you with my limited knowledge.
> 	Since my native language is a neo-romance (Portuguese)
I

Gratia!

> I have to say I was kind of amused to see the
questions
> that came up in your mind. Things I or other
latin-speakers
> would never have any doubt about.

I have several goals for my word list (which I will
describe more fully later). One of them is to avoid the
"accidental" multiple meanings inherited from the Romance
languages.

A perfect example is kanceri, for "crab" and "cancer". My
word list will NOT have one word mean both of those things.
(I'm leaning towards kanceri = crab, mali-amorfo =
cancer).

If I wanted a Romance IAL, I would choose LFN or Romanova.
One of Glosa's appeals (to me) is that it is slightly more
fair to non-Romance speakers.

> > bato;deep (?), depth (?);
>   This has to do with depth, as in a "bathysphere",
and

Ok.

> > bulbo;bulb (?);
>   Seed. A light bulb is somewhat seed-ahaped, is't it?

I've noted both meanings, but decided this word is too rare
to be in my core list.

> > decimali;decimal (?);
>   A "decimal" in Portuguese is a number with a decimal
> point; not a whole number and not expressed as a
fraction.

My current thinking: decimali should not be a Glosa word,
since it really should be dekamali. So, instead, I have:
deka-sistema for the decimal system, and mero for a
fraction. There should also be terms for integer,
real/non-integer (floating point), etc.

> > delega;delegate (to?)
>   You delegate someone the power to vote for you.

Ok.

> > dirigi;direct (?);
>   Guide or steer, or drive [as in car]. 

Ok. It won't be in my word list, because it is a dupe of
duce.

> > diskusi;conference (?)
> more like an international meeting. It is more formal,
and more
> important. It may also mean a "speech", or "lecture",
or
> "presentation", as in a medical congress, or an academic
lecture.

Hmmmmm. But diskusi sounds like discussion, which would be
a more informal conference. But there is also diskursi
which means discussion. This one is still open for me.

> > figura;figure (?);
>   It designates shape, no doubt about that. 

Ok.

> > fonda;background (?)
> > Is this like a visual backdrop? Or like foundational
> > background information?
> 
>   Both, depending on the context.

I might be able to live with this having two meanings.

> > hedo;fun (?)
> > ludo;fun (?)

Here's my current version:
hedo;fun (feeling)
ludo;fun (play)

> > idio;private (?);
>   It [this identidy]  doesn't belong
>   to anyone but yourself. Therefore, it's also
"private"

Ah. That helps. I've added:
idio;private (personal), personal

> > korka;cork (?);
>   Since there was no plastic around in Acient Rome or
> Greece, to make   things simple, I wouldn't make the
difference. 

Again here I've noted both definitions, and also marked the
word as being too rare for my core list. They didn't have
planes, cars, or computers back then either, but our
language must adapt to the times.

Kevin

--- Nick Hempshall <nick{at}hempshall{dot}fsbusiness{dot}co{dot}uk> wrote:
> My thoughts relating to Kevin Smith's questions.

Gratia!

> A word in Glosa is intended to stand for only one
> concept. But this concept may be represented in
> English by a large number of words, and remember 
> a Glosa word can act in any part of speech category.
> A metaphorical usage must also be allowed.

Understood. However, as much as possible I want each Glosa
word to stand for one clear concept, not several concepts
that are related in one culture. I also want each concept
to be represented by only one core word, so translators
don't have to make ambiguous choices.

I already responded to the other person who replied.
Fortunately, there was a fair amount of agreement between
the two of you. My notes below cover areas that my earlier
response didn't.

> > dirigi;direct (?);
> I have ~direkti~ as the preferred form. Both mean
> guide/steer.

My list has direkti as meaning "direction", which I took to
mean a compass point. Does it really mean to direct?

> > diskusi;conference (?)
> Any kind of discussion.
Which would make it redundant with diskursi.

> > imagi;image (?);
> A physical likeness.

Still not sure here. I need to think more.

> > kompani;company (?);
> Business.
> "Company come to visit" ~hospi~
> Company of soldiers would be ~grega~.

Very helpful.

> > koncentra;concentrate (?);
> Focus mental activity, time or resources on something.

Does fokali also refer to mental focus, or should it be
strictly physical? This is one where the abstract and
physical _seem_ closely aligned, although it may just be my
own cultural bias.

> > koncerne;concern (?);
> Worry is ~turba~. 
> Related-to is ~de~. 
> ~Gravi pro~ is to matter/be concerned about.

So should I just omit koncerne from my core list?

> > kontenta;content (?), constituent;
> Contents are ~plu in-ra~.
> Content is ~ge-place~ [pleased].
> Constituent is ~mero-ma~

So should I just omit kontenta from my core list?

> > limita;rather (?);
> Rather in the sense of "somewhat" / "to some extent or
> degree".

Ah. the british RAH-thur. I'll just leave that definition
out.

> > liqi;fuse (?);
> Yes, or fusing "apart" (melting) as an electrical fuse
> does.

I've included fuse (weld) and weld as defining words.

> > lisi;smooth (?);
> Yes, the G seems to have got separated from the rest of
> the word. ~Glisa~ is slip, slide. Smooth is ~glabro~.

Ok. Lisi does not mean smooth.

> > orange;orange
> Fruit

Agreed. Rubi-xanto is the color.

Kevin

Subject: [glosalist] Changes from core
From: Kevin Smith <kevinbsmith{at}yahoo{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 7 Oct 2001 21:18:08 -0700 (PDT)

In putting together my own personal Glosa core words list,
I am changing the following:

akti-verbi -> akti-verba
deskribe-verbi -> deskribe-verba
nima-verba -> nomina-verba.

"verbi" is not a core word, but "verba" is. "nima" is not
core, but "nomina" is. One of my (many) goals is
consistency, so hyphenated core words can only consist of
other core words. I strongly recommend the keepers of the
GID to adapt this same policy.

I plan to leave "poli" out of my core list, since it is
redundant with "multi". Given that, and the above policy, I
will be changing:

poli-pe -> multi-pe

As always, comments are welcome.

Kevin

To: glosalist <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: [glosalist] Plus plu qestio
From: Kevin Smith <kevinbsmith{at}yahoo{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 7 Oct 2001 21:46:09 -0700 (PDT)

Mi du ergo de mi verba lista, e mi du habe multi questio.

As always, I would like to hear opinions from everyone on
these...

mite;send
How is this send different from bali?

morali;moral
Is this moral/good, or the concept of a moral which might
be relativistic? I assume the former (unfortunately) due to
the Western European culture, but want to be sure.

es la;exist
existe;exist
onto;exist
Is there any real difference between these? My current plan
is to remove "es la" and "onto", leaving just existe.

kontra;opposite
opositi;opposite
Is there any real difference between these? If not, I'll
probably leave out opositi and keep kontra.

petita;pet
Is this a noun or verb?

place;please
I plan to cast this as a request, and not tie it to the
concept of something being pleasing. I know that's where
the roots join, but I think they're separate concepts.

ponda;pound
Is this a pound of weight? If so, I'll drop it since we
have the metric system. Similarly if it's a pound of money
I'll drop it. I assume it's not the verb to pound.

primitive;primitive
I assume this refers to something being one-of-the-first.
Is it really different from proto? I'd like to drop it.

procesa;process
I assume this is both the noun (a method), and the verb (to
execute the method on something). 

promise;undertake
Most of the meanings of promise have to do with promises,
so this meaning doesn't make sense to me.

provide;foresee
Most of the meanings have to do with providing. How does
this relate to forseeing?

recepta;receipt
Is this the act of receiving? Or the piece of paper that
indicates it was received? It shouldn't mean both.

regula;principle
Most of the meanings have to do with regulating. Why is
principle here? It seems to be a side effect that regulate
-> rule (v) and rule (n) -> principle. I don't like it.

safe;manifest
I have no idea how this fits.

sensi;attitude
This meaning doesn't seem to belong

sibila;whistle, soothsay
Huh? I plan to make it whistle, and drop the soothsay
meaning.

sperma;pip
I thought a pip was a dot, like on a die. Sperma is seed.

Kevin

--- Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com> wrote:
> > In putting together my own personal Glosa core words
list,
> > I am changing the following:
> 
> Not objecting, but asking: Why? Is it a reform project?

I prefer to think of it as a clarification project, rather
than a reform project. Sometime soon, I'll write up all my
goals so it will become more clear. The end product will be
a Kevin Core Glosa list that I can use for my own writing
purposes. If anyone else chooses to use it, that will be
fine with me, but it's not my motivation.

Whenever possible, I am staying within the GID, and
preferably the GID core. In a very few cases, I will be
including some words in my core which are not in the GID
core. An example would be that there is no word in core for
"sink (n)", which seems pretty core to me.

I doubt I will make up any new Glosa words. I think I can
fill out my core list with words from GID basic, or by
hyphenating core words.

For my own sanity, I am greatly enhancing the english word
mappings to the Glosa words. In some cases this means
clarifying which English meaning was intended. In some
cases, it means adding more English words within the same
concept, so I can more easily find the Glosa word I want.
In some cases, it is omitting English words which don't fit
the "one" concept of that Glosa word.

Also for my own sanity, I plan to eliminate most or all
Glosa synonyms. Each of my core words will represent a
single concept, and will be the ONLY core word to represent
that concept. I am also leaving GID core words out of my
list for a variety of other reasons, each of which I will
document.

Note that I am not eliminating any words from Glosa. I am
merely creating a subset list that people can choose to use
if they wish--if they agree with my choices. I believe the
loose vocabulary of Glosa is its weakest point right now,
and this is my own personal solution.

As I said, it's mostly so I can create my own tool, and all
my aims and goals will be spelled out when I post the
list(s) on my website.

Thanks for asking :-)

Kevin

--- Marcel Springer <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de> wrote:
>  > I plan to leave "poli" out of my core list, since it
is
>  > redundant with "multi". 
> 
> The Glosa authors certainly prefered "poli".  It can be
> found more often in their publications. 

Interesting. On the positive side, "poli" seems to be more
Greek, and since Glosa hinges on Greek, I tend to favor
Greek roots when there's a choice.

However, my big concern about "poli" is confusion with
unrelated words like "polica", "polisi", and "politika". I
believe this confusion comes from the other Greek root of
Pol, roughly meaning person.

I do feel, somewhat strongly, that only one of the two
should be in any core list. At this point, I guess I still
lean towards keeping "multi" because it is more distinct.

Kevin

Plus plu qestio de Kevin Smith 
>
> As always, I would like to hear opinions from everyone on
> these...
> 
> mite;send
> How is this send different from bali?

Same meaning in Glosa. One word is Latin and the other Greek.
I would prefer ~bali~.
 
> morali;moral
> Is this moral/good, or the concept of a moral which might
> be relativistic? I assume the former (unfortunately) due to
> the Western European culture, but want to be sure.

~morali~ is from ~more~ [custom]. So it's what's good
for you in your society/period of history.


> es la;exist
> existe;exist
> onto;exist
> Is there any real difference between these? My current plan
> is to remove "es la" and "onto", leaving just existe.

No difference. I prefer ~existe~.

> kontra;opposite
> opositi;opposite
> Is there any real difference between these? If not, I'll
> probably leave out opositi and keep kontra.

No difference. I would say ~anti~ also covers this meaning.

> petita;pet
> Is this a noun or verb?

Noun. I would use ~domi-zoa~.
 
> place;please
> I plan to cast this as a request, and not tie it to the
> concept of something being pleasing. I know that's where
> the roots join, but I think they're separate concepts.

~place~ seems only to be used as polite request marker.

~petitio~ ask/request.
~gluko~ pleasing/nice/comfortable.
~sukro~ sweet tasting.

 
> ponda;pound
> Is this a pound of weight? If so, I'll drop it since we
> have the metric system. Similarly if it's a pound of money
> I'll drop it. I assume it's not the verb to pound.

Money.

> primitive;primitive
> I assume this refers to something being one-of-the-first.
> Is it really different from proto? I'd like to drop it.

Yes. I'd prefer ~proto~ too.
 
> procesa;process
> I assume this is both the noun (a method), and the verb (to
> execute the method on something). 

Seems likely.

> promise;undertake
> Most of the meanings of promise have to do with promises,
> so this meaning doesn't make sense to me.

"undertake" can be "pledge to do something".
 
> provide;foresee
> Most of the meanings have to do with providing. How does
> this relate to forseeing?

Literal meaning. ~pro-vide~ seeing ahead. ~pro-~ = forward, is
an official "useful prefix", but I don't think they fit well into Glosa.

> recepta;receipt
> Is this the act of receiving? Or the piece of paper that
> indicates it was received? It shouldn't mean both.

~cepti~ is act of receiving.

> regula;principle
> Most of the meanings have to do with regulating. Why is
> principle here? It seems to be a side effect that regulate
> -> rule (v) and rule (n) -> principle. I don't like it.

~regula~ is rule/principle.
"regulate"/"control" should be ~krati~.


> safe;manifest
> I have no idea how this fits.

>From Greek saphes, clear, plain, manifest.
 
> sensi;attitude
> This meaning doesn't seem to belong
 
An "attitude" is a general feeling about something.

> sibila;whistle, soothsay
> Huh? I plan to make it whistle, and drop the soothsay
> meaning.

Latin sibilare, to hiss and Greek sybil "prophetess".
Can't have both words in Glosa.
 
> sperma;pip
> I thought a pip was a dot, like on a die. Sperma is seed.

Apple, orange and pear (etc) seeds are called pips.

--- Nick Hempshall <nick{at}hempshall{dot}fsbusiness{dot}co{dot}uk> wrote:
> > Klavi-verba doesn't make sense to me..."closed word"?
> > "key word"? 
> 
> Key. The most important word in the sentence, and so
> the key to its meaning.

Ah, but I don't think the concept of "key" as in unlocking
something (klavi) is really the same as "key" as in
important. So if you really mean the most important word,
it should be something like gravi-verba.

If you mean the word that unlocks the meaning of the
sentence, then klavi-verba would make sense. But that still
seems like a stretch to me.

Also, I'm not sure the noun really is the most important.
Some sentences don't have nouns, or only have objects and
not subjects. The distinction (to me) is still that a noun
names or identifies something. I guess idio-verba would
work for me, too.

But at this point, rather than trying to figure out a
better word for it, I'm inclined to go with the (corrected)
GID core word for noun: nomina-verba.

> > I also think "describing word" is somewhat better
> > than "quality word".
> 
> That people's tastes differ, is one of the reasons that
> Glosa has so many exact synonyms. The other reasons
> being Greek and Latin sources, and the problem of having

> writing. The extra words don't  put a great strain

one word per meaning. Even if it's not my favorite.

> does
> > this relate to forseeing?
> 
> Literal meaning. ~pro-vide~ seeing ahead. ~pro-~ =
> forward, is
> an official "useful prefix", but I don't think they fit
> well into Glosa.

Then I suspect I'll drop this meaning.

> > recepta;receipt
> > Is this the act of receiving? Or the piece of paper
> that
> > indicates it was received? It shouldn't mean both.
> 
> ~cepti~ is act of receiving.

So "recepta" would be the confirming document. I'm not
thrilled that gluing "re" on the front turns it into a
document. But unless there's a cool hyphenated word that
means receive-confirm-document I'll probably leave it.

> > regula;principle
> > Most of the meanings have to do with regulating. Why is
> > principle here? It seems to be a side effect that
> regulate
> > -> rule (v) and rule (n) -> principle. I don't like it.
> 
> ~regula~ is rule/principle.
> "regulate"/"control" should be ~krati~.

Interesting. "Krati" currently seems to have strong
government overtones. We also have "sistema" for
organization. More thought required.

> > safe;manifest
> > I have no idea how this fits.
> 
> From Greek saphes, clear, plain, manifest.

Ok, manifest (adj - obvious), as opposed to manifest (v
-cause), or manifest (n - list of contents). Sounds like a
job for "klari".

> > sensi;attitude
> > This meaning doesn't seem to belong
>  
> An "attitude" is a general feeling about something.

Which really has little to do with the core concept of
sensing and perceiving (in my mind, at least). It's closer
to a belief ("kredi") or opinion ("doxo"). Not to mention
"mode" which currently lists attitude as a meaning.

> > sibila;whistle, soothsay
> > Huh? I plan to make it whistle, and drop the soothsay
> > meaning.
> 
> Latin sibilare, to hiss and Greek sybil "prophetess".
> Can't have both words in Glosa.

Right, and since whistles are much more common today than
soothseers (or prophets), I'm inclined to stick with
whistle. Unless there's a great Greek word for whistle we
could use...

Itera grati!

Kevin

I've often thought about what the "true essence" of Glosa
(or Interglossa) really might be, and attempted some "reform"
projects on a small test scale.

Hogben wanted to use Greek and scientific international roots.
I suppose this could be accomplished, but there are not many
such roots, and the vocabulary would be inadequate without
a more powerful derivational system than simple compounding.
Ron/Wendy used Latin/Romance to fill out the vocab in a highly
inconsistent manner. Unfortunately, so many roots conflict in
meaning between Latin and Greek that the result is confusion.

So, Glosa enthusiasts have been trying to clean up the vocab.
But without clear agreed principles, and lacking a charismatic
leader or significant financial investment, ...

POLI and PLU are both from the Greek POLY; MULTI is Latin.
A definitive list of all the articles/determiners is needed
before attempting to reform any one, because they form an
interdependent set. In fact, they are among the 100 or so
crucially important words of an "analytic" language. A true
vocab reform would gather the entire set of functional words
(particles) into a rational paradigm, and review them for
completeness and efficiency in actual use.

The "semantic" (rather than "grammatical") words are another
issue, and should be kept separate. Ron/Wendy did try to
categorize words, and I think their effort should be updated.
My own esthetic ideal would be to make the primary separation
obvious by reserving one-syllable words for particles and
doubles for semantic words, but that may not be achievable.

Quoth Marcel:

> ballo is from Greek ballo - to throw.
>   (ballistics, ball,
>   devil=dia-bol-os= one throwing things into confusion).

>   bali - (mainly) to throw;
>          to send (object is a thing that cannot move on its own)
>   mite - (mainly) to send (object is a person or a thing, delivered
>          by a person)

The Latin/Romance word for dance conflicts with the Greek for throw.
Using "ject = throw", we get many more unambiguous derivatives.
For a minimal core vocabulary, "bal" and such are too troublesome.

I'm thinking that a purely apriori vocab would be preferable
to a mangled naturalistic one such as Glosa and Esperanto.

But better still would be a careful selection of the most useful
non-ambiguous roots from Latin (and latinized Greek) without the
mangling, so that Europeans do get a head-start but for others
the roots are no worse than pure apriori (in other words,
avoid importing the many european irregularities).

Those unfamiliar with Lojban/Loglan should also examine the
list of "gismu" for hints as to core vocabulary selection:
http://www.lojban.org/files/roadmap.html#wordlists
