At 08:21 20/11/2001 -0800, Kevin Smith wrote:
>I wrote to ask Marcel if I could get permission to update
>the "18 steps" document to conform to my unofficial core
>list (www.qualitycode.com/glosa).
>
>His response politely suggested that perhaps I should not
>tamper with this classic work of art (which other folks are
>also working on at the moment), and that my time might be
>better spent updating some of the other material.
>[Hopefully that's a reasonable summary. Marcel?]
>
*  Yes, Kevin,
   As I found (~1982-1992) things were a bit fluid during the 'evolution'
of Glosa.  I was very relieved when the _GLOSA 6000_ (1992) was published.
   Then, I still had to check from front to back of this bi-directional
dictionary to make sure I had the right word .. but I accepted this as a
part of the teething troubles, and assumed that a cleaned up version of
_Glosa 6000(Revised)_ would be produced with the aid of computer sorting
and the making of a standardised lexicon.
   It didn't quite happen this way, and Paul Bartlett was the first to
proclaim loudly that there were at least two or three varying "Glosa 1000"
word-lists.
   What had been a problem of the excesses of creativity, had become a
serious 'marketing' dilemma.
   Then, I attempted to form a standard Glosa lexicon by reversing the
GLOSA-ENGLISH list from _GLOSA 6000_, and this only showed that there were
more synonyms than we had bargained for.  Ron and Wendy, in their
enthusiasm threw in more Greek and Latin roots than were warranted.

   That was when I presented the problem to the Glosalist seeking
assistance; and, although we had long discussions about the optimal length
of the desired lexicon revision, each tended to follow his own inclination,
and ultimately a range of Glosa electronic dictionaries was produced.

   I felt a little exhausted by this activity, and thought, as Ron had,
that usage would tend to knock the rough edges off the language, as we all
started communicating in Glosa and writing stories and articles using Glosa.

   BTW, Wendy Ashby asked me to submit items for the upcoming PLU GLOSA
NOTA, so I would suggest that everyone supports her in this, and sends in a
short fictional work or an article for publication.  My guess is that Wendy
will edit items to be in line with Glosa 6000 spelling and standard PGN usage.
 - - - - - - - - - 
   But this is all a long way from "18 Steps to Fluency in Glosa."

   Yes you were right to open the discussion to all.  Perhaps "18 Steps ...
" is a "classic work of art", but it can readily be bettered as a first
reader.  So, I welcome your efforts, Kevin, and suggest that you have a
look at other introductory language readers, to give you an idea of the
different possible approaches.  When "18 Steps ... " was written, it was
aimed at the African learner of Glosa, so it was published in inexpensive
paper format.  Also, the economy cut both ways: Ron and Wendy could afford
neither the production of a thick printed book, nor the postage to their
enthusiastic learners in Africa of a wieghty tome. 
   Now, taking the world view, I imagine that Internet format is the
least-cost mode, and that printed versions can be run from electronic
master copies.
   The Web version of something like "18 Steps ... " could include HTML
coded hypertext links, some of which could call up sound.  I still have not
got organised into the technology of putting sound on the Web, but some on
this list might have the technology to do it.  
   The world has changed a lot since the production of "18 Steps ... ," and
while it can still be used to good effect, future learning materials can
range from possibly a little better .. to exciting audiovisuals, probably
in electronic format.

>here it is:
>
>---
>
>In my mind, one of the very large obstacles to adoption of
>Glosa is that there are now FIVE distinct dialects out
>there:
>1. 18 steps/PGN
>2. Glosa Basic Reference
>3. GID core/basic
>4. Syd Pidd's reforms (trailing vowels)
>5. My own word list
>
>Someone who uses words from any of the five will have some
>difficulty communicating with any of the others. I hope
>that material created based on my list would be the most
>widely understandable because generally my list is a subset
>of the others.
>
*   Where would you place _GLOSA 6000_ in this schema?  Do you have a copy
of this 1992 publication?  If not, I will organise to get one to you: all I
need is your land address.
    I must visit your website to see how your word list looks.

>My big concern is that "18 Steps" is being listed as the
>MOST official source, and it's also the only lengthy
>tutorial available. The web page says it is "the best way
>to learn Glosa." It is also the most widely translated
>material. This will lead new people to learn from it
>first...at which point they will find many, many words
>which are not in any of the other references.
>
*   I did not realise this.  However, if the words they learn are valid
Glosa words, no harm is done.  I ought to peruse my copy, to see if these
words are instances of Old Glosa.

>If "18 Steps" is really an unchangable work of art, it
>should be described as that. People should NOT use it as a
>first step towards learning Glosa. They should only look
>back at it after they have learned "modern" Glosa to gain
>perspective.
>
*   Basically, there should be 'no turning back.'  The only reason for
studying the formative publications is for academic research of Glosa, and
the world is not doing that, yet.  So, "18 Steps ... " can stay in the
archives while a more up to date 'First Reader' - Glosa-wise and
educationally -  is prepared.

>If we actually want people to learn from "18 Steps", it
>must be updated, at least to GID Basic (Core would be
>better), if not to my own list. It is disturbing to realize
>that Russians will be learning what some of us consider to
>be an obsolete dialect of Glosa.
>
*   This is all painfully true.
    I mean we could have a Glosalist competition for the most suitable
update of the "18 Steps ... " as it stands.  This would serve to give us
all a look at the way the different members of the group interpret it into
current Glosa .. leading quickly, I would hope, to a concensus version,
that all agreed was the best line through the 'versions' of Glosa you
describe - with the whole exercise acting as a standardising influence, as
well.

>My other option is to create my own tutorial, from scratch,
>using my word list. Obviously this would be much more
>difficult.
>
*   Probably better, but involving more variables, and a longer production
time.  I would go with the concensus upgrade of the historical "18 Steps
... " as a first task; this could be completed before Christmas.

>So I close with these questions, to which I would really
>like to hear your own personal answers:
>
>What are your goals for the Glosa langauge and community? 
>
*  1. Development of community of fluent users of Glosa - possibly written
Glosa, at first, but subsequently exchanging recordings of spoken Glosa.
   2. Availability of a group of Glosa speakers, so that IF, or WHEN, world
leaders call for selection of an International Auxiliary Language, Glosa
will be represented by a team.
   3. Fun.  Global communication has to be fun or its not worth doing.
   4. A meeting of progressive minds.

>What are the one or two projects someone could do right now
>that would have the most impact towards those goals?
>
*  A. Preparation of one definitive Beginner's Lexicon - of possibly 2500
words, having synonyms for only a few common concepts.
   B. Preparation of a standard paper instruction book, but with standard
rules, reading passages, and short lists of questions for each chapter.
   C. Production of interesting Audio-visual sequences of Glosa
instruction, aimed at circulation through websites and on CD.
   D. Glosa comics.  This would be fun for the more visually oriented Glosa
learners.
   E. An active postal exchange of cassettes with spoken Glosa.

>What do you see as the biggest weaknesses of the language
>(and/or its community) right now? 
>
*  Language: Need for agreement on a standardised lexicon.
             As a concept-based language with syntax based grammar, Glosa
does not have the comfortable feel of a native language with all of the
usual inflections: speakers of Glosa have to think before they speak.
             The lack of a complete lexicon - all the vegetables,fruits,
animals, trees, etc. 
             Although well-written Glosa is a pleasure to read, because of
lack of morphological grammar, it is very extremely easy for the
over-confident learner to write very bad Glosa: the syntactic signposts are
in the head, not provided by visible and audible inflection.   

  Community: Appears to be stuck at the 'vocabulary formation' stage.
             Few fluent writers and speakers.
             African learners, especially in Uganda, are being starved of
contact with other Glosa-pe.
             + +  Development of Glosa segments to websites is a very
encouraging sign among the more affluent learners.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell
  P.S. I feel that with a more positive global intellectual climate there
would be exponential growth of Glosa usage.  Also, I feel that in the same
way that the world's knowlege should be freely available to all, such
global information could be available in one language medium, and Glosa is
suitable for this task.

Subject: [glosalist] 18 steps copyright?
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

Robin wrote:

> but I accepted this as a
> part of the teething troubles, and assumed that a cleaned up version of
> _Glosa 6000(Revised)_ would be produced with the aid of computer sorting
> and the making of a standardised lexicon.

>              As a concept-based language with syntax based grammar, Glosa
> does not have the comfortable feel of a native language with all of the
> usual inflections: speakers of Glosa have to think before they speak.
>              The lack of a complete lexicon - all the vegetables,fruits,
> animals, trees, etc.

What's needed is an algorithm to select vocabulary. It could be re-run
periodically for updates. When I challenged the Interlingua "experts",
they were unable to describe any effective, repeatable, objective method.
But it's possible to derive the Glosa vocab according to clear principles
by a published computer program using public data sources.

Recently I've been experimenting with a "language sound change" program,
running English through it without regard to semantics, similar to how
language evolves. It's basically another "English spelling reform" but
with a few twists. Imitating what seems Ron Clark style, it simplifies
the alphabet and shoehorns all English words into easily pronounceable
CVCV-ish bisyllables. (C.S. people call it a hash table.)

The "euro-international" names of the days of the week are based on
astrology, sun-day moon-day mars-day mercury- jupiter- venus- saturn-.
But with usage they became smoothed out a bit. Here are some day names
cranked out by my program, just for fun, sorted by frequency:

26342   todu    today
19507   jeste   yesterday
9364    sundu   sunday
8310    satu    saturday
7783    joli    holiday
5540    fridu   friday
5286    mondu   monday
4406    vedne   wednesday
3722    fursu   thursday
3568    tesdu   tuesday
3247    birfu   birthday
1018    duli    daylight
555     midu    midday
536     duti    daytime
184     vekdu   weekday
49      dudra   daydream

This is just from the BNC corpus, English-only; one could include other
lists for a more international flavor. The words automatically "compete"
for their positions, no subjective judgement or hand-tuning is ever needed.
The top-3000 words would be the "core" list by definition. It looks like
8000 or so root-concept-words will cover the entire set (approx 100,000
distinct English words). This style of reform, basing decisions on an
objective basis, escapes the limitations of the "artlang" approach.

--- Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au> wrote:
>    As I found (~1982-1992) things were a bit fluid 
> during the 'evolution' of Glosa.  I was very 
> relieved when the _GLOSA 6000_ (1992) was published.

Thanks for the history. Context aids understanding.

>    I felt a little exhausted by this activity, and
> thought, as Ron had, that usage would tend to knock 
> the rough edges off the language, as we all started 
> communicating in Glosa and writing stories and
> articles using Glosa.

I think one of the reasons this has not happened is because
there are too many words in G6000 and the full GID. As new
people learn a language, if they are given a wide choice of
words, each will naturally choose a variety of words.

I guess that's mostly because many people probably learn
Glosa by themselves, from word lists. There isn't enough
existing Glosa material, or enough ongoing discussions IN
Glosa for people to learn that way.

6000 words is far too many for everyday usage. I'm not sure
such a work should even exist, but if it does, people
should be discouraged from using it.

As you move beyond 1000-2000 words, almost all the
additions should be specific names of plants, animals, and
scientific terms, and/or compounds that build on existing
roots. We don't need twelve roots that mean "happy".

Kevin

>   B. Preparation of a standard paper instruction 
>book, but with standard rules, reading passages, and

Interesting. I have trouble imagining a paper book getting
much distribution. Do you have a particular target group or
geography in mind?

>   C. Production of interesting Audio-visual sequences

word list. I think I could pretty easily tweak my software

file (Spanish, Russian, etc).

How valuable to you all think either of these would be?

From: Kevin Smith <kevinbsmith{at}yahoo{dot}com>

>>What do you see as the biggest weaknesses of the 
>>language (and/or its community) right now?

>*  Language: Need for agreement on a standardised 
>lexicon.

Agreed. But how can we reach "standardization"? Would that
require Wendy's participation and approval? Or has the
language community grown to the point where the original
author(s) become just one voice among many?

Participants in this list do not seem to be active or
involved enough to actually "vote" on issues that come up.
When issues do arise, I don't think we reach consensus very
often.

>           The lack of a complete lexicon - all the
>vegetables,fruits, animals, trees, etc.

That would be interesting. I have thought about having
multiple "add-ons" to the core word list. If you are
interested in technical issues, add the technical list.
Some people might add the anatomy list, or the foods list,
or whatever. That way, the core list can remain simple.

>          Although well-written Glosa is a pleasure to 
>read, because of lack of morphological grammar, it is 
>very extremely easy for the over-confident learner to 
>write very bad Glosa: the syntactic signposts are
>in the head, not provided by visible and audible 
>inflection.     

Well put. Some of my early Glosa writing is unclear because
I kept too many signposts in my head, instead of explcitly
writing them out. I'm very slowly going back and updating
that text (and at the same time updating the vocabulary to
match my streamlined word list).

>Community: Appears to be stuck at the 'vocabulary 
>formation' stage.
>             Few fluent writers and speakers.

Agreed. There seem to be about five or ten of us here. And
in the long time I've been monitoring the list, I think
that number has only gone up by one or two.

>             African learners, especially in Uganda, 
>are being starved of contact with other Glosa-pe.

Very interesting. I wasn't even aware of them. I assume
they have no (or very limited) internet access. My own life
is so tightly bound to the computer, I'm not sure I could
help there. Perhaps we could set up some kind of system to
automatically route any in-Glosa postings to a monthly
printed newsletter?

---
I would add a couple more community weaknesses:
1. Aside from the recent and very welcome influx of Russian
speakers, we remain very English-centric. I would love to
have a Glosa site similar to the Romanova site, which
offers information in MANY languages.

2. The members of this list seem more interested in
learning about (or debating :-) Glosa, rather than actually
using it.

Kevin

I agree. One of the major design aims of the Interglossa/Glosa
Project was to produce a language with "word economy".

See what Hogben had to say on the subject.
http://www.zeta.org.au/~rgaskell/paraleli.htm


The Glosa authors also very frequently stress that Glosa has
two vocabularies; Mega Glosa and Central Glosa.

Plu Glosa Nota 37 is a typical example

"We agree that to sell Glosa to bodies such as EEC, UN, 
UNESCO etc. MEGA-GLOSA, a large vocabulary is 
essential. Scientists, literary people and politicians require 
it. 

"We however insist that GLOSA 1000 must remain the 
Centre, the Heart of Glosa. Glosa is a truly International 
Auxiliary Language. It will appeal to the motivated Third 
World artisan only if it is simple to learn and accurate, and 
able to deal with all kinds of information exchange. Glosa 
will not be allowed to fall into the trap of becoming only 
a holiday language for wealthy people of the industrialized 
nations. The world will never be healthily united until 
accurate information is readily available to everyone 
everywhere, and everybody in the world has enough to eat, 
good shelter and a good all-round education - an education 
for living not merely for earning a living. The world has now 
the means (but not yet the will) to bring all this about quickly 
and thoroughly. 

"Europeans are used to large vocabularies, which can contribute 
to mis-understandings not only between nations but also 
between classes. We hope that although perhaps enjoying the 
variety and freedom of Mega Glosa people will at the same 
time work their way up to Central Glosa 1000."

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote
k for Christians di k1 =mondays as the creator rested on 7th
day=sabbath=sunday
j  for Jewish   di j1 = sunday
i for Islam    di i1=??
also years  k2001= now etc
?????

Whilst Christians, Jews and Muslims have their 'special' day of the week on
Sunday, Saturday and Friday respectively. They are all in agreement that
Sunday is the first day of the week.

Interestingly, Hebrew also uses numbers for the names of the days of the
week.

Slavs think of Friday as the fifth day, for example Russians call it
"pyatneetza". And also some calendar printers put Monday as the
first day of the week, but this is far from being universal practice.

Year numbering is more controversial. But "Common Era" dates (C.E.),
which are the same as A.D. dates, are the most international, and, of
course, are not actually related to the birth year of Jesus of Nazareth.

EuroWordNet or other ideas I've discussed here previously.

growth, it must become an ongoing committee-standardized and
regularly updated product (even if free, like Linux).

>EuroWordNet or other ideas I've discussed here previously.
>The only wrong way to do it is to hand-pick as in an artlang.

*   I could not agree more.

    At present, the subscribers to Glosalist + Wendy Ashby comprise such a
"standardising committee."

    Were the members of Glosalist .. using a suitable standard list, such
as that from _EuroWordNet_ .. to be able to agree upon an approx. 1000 word
list for Glosa, that would be a start.

    This should not be an impossability, but it would suggest the need for
some painful thinking on the part of those wishing to "improve" upon the
various, existing basic Glosa word-lists.

    Were we to agree on using one standardised list, such as that suggested
by Charles, _EuroWordNet_, then we would certainly add credibility to the
exercise; this sort of thing takes Glosa from hobbyist level to committee
level, and would give the project more authority - as seen through the eyes
of UN and EC committees that decide on things like Universal Standards.

    Wendy Ashby would have to be informed of our actions before we started
on such a venture, because she would need to be part of the process: were
she on the Net, I would CC: this message to her; as things are, I will have
to print out and post hardcopy of our deliberations to her.

    Please Charles, is a suitable version of the EuroWordList available for
forwarding to the Glosalist as an attachment?  Do other members of this
list have an alternative standard that they feel is superior to that
proposed by Charles?  If the selection of a standard is the first step,
then such a decision should be possible within one month; alternatively, if
there is no objection, the basic EuroWordList can be agreed to by majority
vote, or concensus, within two to four weeks.

    While Wendy is not getting too old to wait for further delays, I, at
65, might be.  If we, as a group, are to get serious, and to phase up to
the professional level, then there is no room for the luxury of endless
discussion: I would like to bring the matter .. of the embarrassing range
of "Glosa 1000/Basic Glosa" lists .. to a head, and suggest that we work -
to proposed 'deadlines' - to arrive at one 'basic' list.

    IF we can do this, then we can press forward to derive standardised
lists at the "Glosa 2500" and "Glosa 6000" marks.  Of course the obvious
approach is to create one comprehensive lexicon, of say 6000-odd words, and
snip backwards, selecting "Basic" and "Learner" vocabularies from this.
However, such an approach might assume a singularity of purpose beyond that
of the Glosalist subscribership: I believe that the formation of the
smallest standardised list would 'test' our integrity as a group, and, as
such, might determine whether, or not, Glosa has a future.

    The technical language extensions to Glosa, suggested by Kevin Smith,
are vitally important to the growth of Glosa as a potential Global
Auxilliary; but, such extension need to be built onto a firm foundation;
it is the lack of a standardised lexicon that prevents many Glosa
enthusiasts from progressing into normal spoken use of the language.  Once
the foundation is reasonably well set (of course with rules for alterations
to the language with cultural change) there will be a redirection of energy
into the creation of a "corpus" (collection of original works written in
Glosa), and the language will start growing again.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell
  P.S. Hardcopy mailed to Wendy Ashby.   R.G.

I don't want to discuss one IAL versus another, because
such discussions always become unpleasant disputations.
Actually, I like all of them, and so-called artlangs too.
My own experience to try many of them and eventually
settled on one as "best": Occidental, designed for those
who already know at least one other European language and
have at least studied some others. But if people want to
discuss other IALs, I urge that it be done off-list.

Glosa has a different idea, to use analytical grammar and
non-Latin roots, for a global audience that is non-European.
It more closely approximates a pidgin/creole like the
Lingua Franca or Chinook Jargon or even Indonesian, and
theoretically should be easiest to learn. I've seen a few
other projects somewhat like Glosa (Lingua Franca Nova, Tunu)
and believe that Glosa needs to be improved in many ways.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] other IALs
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

> Should I search the archives for the things you feel should
> be improved in Glosa? Or can you restate them briefly?
> (Aside from vocabulary

My opinions have evolved a lot, and continue to do so ...

Generally, Glosa principles need to be clearly defined.
Then it can be extended and updated by people other than
the author-artist. As it is, there are bits of everything
but no real system -- and lots of contradictions. In an
"engineered" language this is unacceptable, though as a
prototype it's an interesting experiment.

Should the "scientific vocabulary" and Latin prefixed verbs
and mangled Greek roots all be thrown together into the pot?

Should there be any affixes, and if so should they be
prefixed or suffixed? Why select derivational suffixes
like -DO when the full word is only 2 syllables and fits
the "no morphology except compounds" scheme? Why have
GE- for something like a past/passive participle but
not have any present/active participle? Etc.

As for vocabulary, why not stipulate that Roget's headwords
and/or Euronet's top ontology and/or Kanji-6000 as the
official set of roots? And then systematically relex them
to a pure bisyllabic CVCV scheme that fits the phonology?

And then let's see some realistic translations, without the
parochial English idioms, to compare with the equivalent text
in other languages.

Draconian pronouncements, e.g "all Greek roots" or "pure relex"
would be more acceptable to me than the current mish-mash.
Maybe what I'd like best is basically a renewed Lingua Franca.
Others will have very different preferences, naturally,
and it would be interesting to hear them.

a little rambling:-
glosa started as words from latin and greek plus syntax from england. This 
made it easy to use by europeans especially me, g is the easiest language I 
have come across.  The people who are using it and discussing it are , on the 
whole, a pretty brainy lot and can cope with several languages and technical 
terms etc. they tend to forget that that g should be aimed at simpler folk. 
But, g should become a language of its own, let us forget the latin, greek 
and english, it has, on various web sites and glosalist computers, a pretty 
comprehensive and useable vocabulary and hidden away to some extent, its own 
syntax. We should be making them all clear for our simpler folk like a 75 
year old englishman with patches of confusion and memory loss to trouble him.
Looking back over the last 60 years or so, g and glosalist can claim credit 
for a miracle or two, a german and englishman on friendly terms and working 
together, russians and americans doing the same - things were not always like 
that. Over the last few years I have exchanged ideas through glist and pgn 
and in g, with people from china, uganda, greece,   sweden, germany russia 
usa  for instance. g is a success , small perhaps but a success
it can stand alone, it has fledged, ............

about voting, voting is already taking place - I am a self appointed 
returning officer - much g, I have put on my PC the number of times each word 
is used is noted and I shall make a dictionary based on it to go with the 
welter of files from G1000, G6000, core and so on
sid

> Were the members of Glosalist .. using a suitable standard list, such
> as that from _EuroWordNet_ .. to be able to agree upon an approx. 1000 word
> list for Glosa, that would be a start.

There is a mass of data and it's easy to get lost in it;
prepare to wade through a lot of academic bureaucratese ...
what we want is the "1024 Common Base Concepts".

http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/data.htm
http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/corebcs/topont.htm
http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/corebcs/corebcs.html (164 top concepts)
http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/corebcs/ewnTopOntology.htm
http://www.hum.uva.nl/~ewn/corebcs/AbstractInfo.htm

> This should not be an impossability, but it would suggest the need for
> some painful thinking on the part of those wishing to "improve" upon the
> various, existing basic Glosa word-lists.

At this point we should be adding words, not subtracting any.
But the personal efforts to identify "core" subsets are a good
exercise. In a full dictionary, the 1000 most frequently used
words should be highlighted. IMHO.

> Do other members of this
> list have an alternative standard that they feel is superior

There are several other good options, and they could all be
done independently and additively. The 6000 Kanji taught to
all Japanese students are a very good alternative. And the
example of Tunu shows how this might look:

a/an            SpE LDV SFL BNC  bija
ability/able    SpE LDV SFL BNC  nilo
about           SpE LDV SFL BNC  naju
above           SpE LDV SFL BNC  bamo / situ
abroad              LDV          mite
absence/absent      LDV          lalaju

The author has taken Rick Harrison's meta-list of English
vocabulary, which includes Special English, top-1000 of BNC,
Longman's Defining set, and Eaton's list ... at my suggestion,
BTW ... and provided the Tunu equivalents on the right. Tunu
is another analytic style IAL like Glosa.

I have several other English vocab lists from the time we last
discussed "what is core?" on this e-list. Let 1000 flowers bloom.

this is from "recruitable" a publication by an organisation to help get 
people back to work. It is for us simpler folk and written for us in a simple 
direct english which would be very useful to translate into g. very nice 
english too.

"Recruitable helps people who want to work, to find a job"
l
exicon:-
R, auxi, pe, qi, volu, ergo, te, detekti, u, ergo-topo

let us try:-
pa auxi/helped     ok
pa pe/personed   ???
qi=intro-verba/intro-word,particle         no pa
pa volu/wished    ok
pa ergo/worked   here ok
te=intro-verba
pa detekti/found  ok
u=intro-verba
pa ergo-loka/workplaced     ???

auxi, volu, ergo, detekti are tem-mero-frasi/tem-verba-grupo/verbs
auxi/volu-ergo and detekti need intro words/particles
glosa= du auxi, du volu ergo, te detekti
R is earlier than auxi, qi is earlier than volu-ergo, and also earlier than 
detekti so precede those verb phrases
pe is later than auxi, ergo-loka is later than detekti so are after the verb 
phrases
pe and ergo-loka need intro-words
plu pe, u ergo-loka

so:-
"R  du auxi plu pe qi volu ergo te detekti plu ergo-loka"
the intro-words make it much easier and quicker to understand the sentence, 
no-qe?
sid

I revisited the lists done in august 2000. They were 7 lists
of "essential" English vocabulary compiled by various people.
Any dictionary for Glosa would have to translate at least the
top few thousand items that appear in most of them, and I feel
that they should all be one-root words rather than compounds.

The sources were:
Paul Bartlett's list
Rick Harrison's metalist
Tunu vocab
General Service List
Top 10000 from the BNC
Kilgariff's list
Yang's learner list

I've now added the EuroWordNet set, but it wasn't very useful;
only 117 new entries, and just 650 or so in total. All 8 lists
were merged/sorted, and a count made of how many lists included
each word. I think that adding 100 more lists would not change
the results much.

193 words appear on all 8 lists, 832 appear on 7 (or more) lists,
1532 are on 6+ of the lists, 1990 on 5+, 2441 on 4+, 3310 on 3+,
5437 on 2+, 9629 in all. Those that appear only once include
some flaky stuff like abbreviations; the 3-or-mores look pretty
reliable. Anyway, it's uploaded for any who care, at:
http://catty.com/~catty/lang/engcore

perhaps always a verb. "du" can be omitted. In "auxi", some people and often 
that includes me, might find the meaning of the sentence less clear if "du" 
is not used with "auxi"
"id es de qo?"

id feno a mi ke in glosa, u verba "ge" du habe bi funktio.
1) normali, u glosa frasi du habe S V O sed plu kron, il du habe uti te loka 
O ante V. si u g frasi ge grafo per mi (homo u-co ), id ge deriva ex "mi du 
grafo u frasi" e u O "frasi" es moti pre u V "grafo". in g, u-co ge sema per 
u uti de "ge" e id es normali ge-nexi ko u hifen. na pote omite u-co hifen. 
na pote uti id te intro u V vice "du", alo id pote ge moti ad u sti de frasi 
"ge u frasi du grafo per mi". na pote es mali e moti id ad u fini e kripto 
olu-na lekto-pe "u frasi du grafo per mi, ge"   

it seems to me that in glosa the word/particle "ge" has 2 functions,
1) usually a glosa sentence has S V O but sometimes it is useful to put O 
before V. if a sentence is written by me (like this one), it is derived from 
"I write a sentence" wher the O "sentence" is brought to the front of V 
"write". In glosa this is signalled by using "ge" and is usually placed just 
before V and joined by a hyphen. we could leave out the hyphen, we could use 
it to introduce V, in which case it could replace "du" or it could occur at 
the beginning of the sentence. I should like to know as soon as possible that 
the time of phrase that starts earlier than the time of the verb and placing 
"ge" first in the sentence, would help my understanding. we could be naughty 
and put the word at the end and keep the reader guessing.

sid

--part1_123.8671dfc.293cd512_boundary

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Your statistics are clear: By looking around at alternative lists, the

>From earlier (much earlier) discussions, we still have the human question
of how many words is enough to get someone started and confident with a
language.  Then, once they have mastered the mechanics and the feel of the
language, and are demanding the ability to become more functional, should
we develop and recommend a mid-term learner's vocab.  Following that, what
is the necessary number of words capable of providing a standard
'man-in-the-street' vocab for the speaker/writer of an auxilliary?

   Once we derive the standard 9629 Glosa words parallel to the maximum
number of words found in all the lists you checked, then we could posibly 
create sectional lists, as follows:-

   193              Glosa primer  ("18 Steps ... " level)
   832              Basic Learner List               (~ Glosa 
  1532                "      "     "   - possibly         1000)     
  1990         
  2441              Mid Learner Vocab                    
  3310    
  5437              Glosa Standard Vocab (~ Glosa 6000 level)
  9629              Glosa Lexicon 

   This breakdown depends on a couple of things: with uninflected Glosa
words, there could be some cases where the root Glosa word has two or more
English language equivalents; and, that I have interpreted your statistical
analysis correctly.

ge 2 was interupted by hurried phone call.
ge b1 ge frakti per u ge-tako telefono kla.
a hurried phone call interupted ge 2. 
If there is a little fancy altering of the verb phrase, you can change SVO to 
OVS this has a fancy name - passive tense/voice/mood - the name doesnt matter 
two hoots, all it does is alter the usual phrase order. In glosa, we alter 
SVO to OVS by adding "ge", dead simple. this is ge 1

u ge-tako telefono pa frakti ge bi
si il es u pusi orna muta ad akti-verba-grupo, na pluso du muta SVO ad OVS - 
fo fo simpli

I have here not use a hyphen for ge 1 because I wish to use it for ge 2 which 
is rather different from ge 1. We have an example above - "ge-tako 
kla/hurried call" which forms an adjective.
mi ci pa no (ze) uti u hifen kausa mi du volu uti id pro ge 2 qi du difere ab 
ge 1. na du habe un exemple ana "ge-tako kla" - qi du face un auxi verba.
sid

--- Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com wrote:
> 193 words appear on all 8 lists, 
> 832 appear on 7 (or more) lists,
> 1532 are on 6+ of the lists, 
> 1990 on 5+, 2441 on 4+, 
> 3310 on 3+,
> 5437 on 2+, 
> 9629 in all. 

So I think we should target 6+ as an initial goal.

> Anyway, it's uploaded for any who care, at:
> http://catty.com/~catty/lang/engcore

Unfortunately, a non-annotated English list like this is
not very useful. Too many synonyms and ambiguous meanings.
On the other hand, the EuroWordNet list, which seems to
solve this, is quite cumbersome to work with.

I'm willing to put some effort into this standardization
project, but does anyone have an idea of a structure that
avoids the English problems but is manageable? 

My unofficial core list attempted to solve this by listing
multiple English words for each Glosa word, and to clarify
which English meaning was intended. Is there a way to
leverage that work here?

We should also agree, in principle, about the degree to use
existing Glosa words vs. making new ones up. If there is an
existing word that fits, but is perhaps unpleasant to some
people, how do we proceed?

Kevin

I have put my current used-glosa dic at:-
Your page can be found at:
<A HREF="http://hometown.aol.co.uk/sydpidd/myhomepage/business.html">http://hometown.aol.co.uk/sydpidd/myhomepage/business.html</A>_

an explanation of the format:-
"+" introduces a glosa word, "*" intro english and "^" intros a comment
"VC" shows a g word that begins with a vowel, glosa tries to have CVCVCV>>>>>
CV as this is easier to pronounce generally and like this, the CV alternation 
is preserved between words. 
"PC" indicates (usually) that a plosive (b c d g k p t ) is followed by a 
consonant. some speakers find this difficult at times.
q, x, r, l are included in the glosa.
some people, including me to some extent, prefer not to have a couple of 
single signs representing pairs of sounds and think it would be more logical 
to have "kw", and "ks"; the latter is a PC and might be better avoided.
for some speakers in east asia, l and r are not so easy to distinguish so 
that if there are two g words that only differ with "l" and "r", those 
consonants perhaps should be avoided. the number in square brackets [] show 
how often the word has been used so far in PGN or glosalist (not an 
exhaustive count) and could be used as a guide in choosing.
sometimes, a concept is represented by more than one word, the comments may 
help choice.  
    
I shall update the list about every fortnight or month. if you write in g, 
you will influence the list.....
sid

> anyone know the english equivalent of "tali"

According to the full GID, it's "heel" or "ankle". Kalku is
preferred for heel, and tarsu is preferred for ankle.

There's also an "X" (avoid) entry for "u tali" as being the
same as talo (such; such a). Talo is preferred.

Kevin

mi pa trova "insult" in"central glosa"

u bus pa es qieta. a dorsa, il pa es tri matura-pe; proxi dorsa, septi alo 
okto ju-an de sud asia. u-co ju-an pa es ko civiliza e boni akti. pluso, tem 
plu hetero ju-an pa es homo plu agrio bestia. po oliga minuta, mo de [lu asia 
an pa sta. an pa skope ad plu an ami ante an, pa lati hedo-vultu e pa sti u 
longi dice ad mu. id pa es in flu enge-lingua. sed, id pa es fo mali, ple de 
multi deino mali-dice. u enge-lingua an pa feno ski pa es pan plu obsceni alo 
plu blasfema. plu-an kompani viagia-pe pa es holo silento. dubar pa dura dice 
ko kresce entusi tem plu an audi-pe pa tenta, sine sucede, sema pro u-an sto.

--part1_136.5db8ec6.294d0859_boundary

--- Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
> mi du pote no trova "insult", auxi place

GID du habe:

mali akti (=akti mali) 1  insult; offence; offend; offense
dice mali 1++    insult
mali-dice 1++    curse; slander; swear (curse)
insulta          insult

Mi no-amo 'dice mali', kausa 1) id es no-klari, e 2) id es
konfusi ko 'mali-dice'.

Mi no-amo 'mali akti', kausa u ~insult~ no es u akti, e id
es plus no-klari.

Mi ne-amo 'insulta', kausa id du feno fo-homo Engla-lingua
verba.

Posi: 'no-lauda' alo 'dice no-lauda' alo 'dice anti-lauda'?

Kevin

--- "Alexander E. Kirpichev" <brickswall{at}mtu-net.ru> wrote:
> Mi es sura; poli Loglan materiali ge-ruski de Andrey
> Rogachev.

Fo-stimula. An ne dice de u-ci ergo.

> Tu pa grafo "no-amo", sed in moderna Glosa de GEO no-amo
> = hate (doesn't like = ne amo). Qe pe posi "hate" u 
> lingua?

Mi du uti 'no-amo' pro ~dislike~. Mi sio uti 'fo-no-amo'
(alo odio) pro ~hate~. A mi, 'ne-amo' du semani ni amo ni
no-amo.

Mi du puta; an du no-amo u Loglan. Mi du puta; an ne du
odio u Loglan.

> Mi ski; tu uti "du", ka id es logika. Sed qo-ka tu ne uti
> "nu"?

A mi, 'nu' du semani 'nu-kron', e 'du' du semani 'nu-tem'
(alo holo tem). Qe, es logika? Posi mi holo-tem debi uti
plu-la verba, vice 'du'?

Qo-tende Glosa du uti 'holo tem', vice 'pan tem'?

> Mi nu ergo kon u mi programa, sed mi ne es sura, qe mi
> nece uti Glosa 6000 o Glosa 1000. Tu puta qo?

Mi fo-kredi; tem pe du *grafo* Glosa, pe debi uti G1000
(alo ~GID core~). Tem pe du *lekto* Glosa, pe nece habe
G6000 (alo ~GID complete~). Tem mi du grafo Glosa, mi du
pene nuli-kron nece ma verba de mi ~core~ lista.

Vale,

Kevin

but ...........

mero mo de dubar pa feno ge lose - u-ci id es:-



proxi tri penta anua retro, mi pa tenta doci engelingua a u ju-an, dubaro 
nio, ex benglalanda (25n93e).an pa sedi in u-mi doci grupo e pa feno logi no 
ra. u hetera ju-an sed ex punjabilanda (35n75e) pa dice a mi ke dubar ( plu 
nima es no veri) pa dice gujerati-lingua. mi pa ki a u bibli-do e, po ma 
cerka, pa detekti u fo paleo bibli ko plu de u-co lingua, mi pa monstra id a 
dubar qi skope ad id ko u fo vaku facia. kusdev, de punjabi-landa, e mi pa 
lento seismo plu-na kefa - no veri. 
"urdu", kusdev pa ofere. bengla-landa pa es a u-la tem, est pakistan e u 
lingua de pakistan pa es urdu. u urdu bibli pa es ma facile de detekte so mi 
pa gene sko u urdu frase. "dubar, e kja cis he?", kusdev salta ana e kata ko 
hedo " kursi he. kursi he!" - nuli signi ex dubar!. an pa no dice urdu.
( na pa dice:- "u-ci ra es qo?", "es sedi-mobile") 
versi a bibli-do!. apo longi tem, mi detekti u mega e paki bibli ko multi 
lingua in id qi mi pa sume ab. 
kusdev, dubar e mi pa sti a pagina mo e na tri pa skope u lingua epi id, na 
pa skope pagina tri e ma e ma pagina. mi pa pote logi plu de pagina e kusdev 
plu hetera, punjabi-lingua e hindi-lingua e po multi pagina, dubar pa dice ko 
hedo "bengla" e sti lekto id. an pa pote lekti id facile e tako. po u tem, an 
pa feno enigma, an pa lekto u kristi bibli e an pa es u muslim. 
retro a bibli-do, id pa es dificile te gene u bibli de bengla-lingua. anti-co 
na pa profito e plu sko de enge-lingua pro dubar pa sti. sed. dubar pa no es 
u boni gene ski pe e u-an progresi pa es fo fo lento. mo di, mo de u 
engelanda ju-an qi pa habe simpati ko u-mi auxi dubar, pa dice ke mi pa es 
disipa u-mi tem e fo-tenta. u hetera ju-an ridi e dice ke mi debi audi u 
enge-lingua de dubar epi u bus!
proxi mo penta di seqe, mi pa akuti id!
u mi moto-me ruptu e mi nece ki a e ab u-mi sko-do per uti bi bus e mo di mi 
pa sume u mo qi pa ki ab mo mero de sko-do ad hetero proxi tri kilometri 
dista e dia ad u centra de civita. mi pa sto u bus, pa gradu epi id e pa 
skende plu skala. un akro tegu pa habe tri matura-an e un amaso de ju-an de 
u-mi sko-do.
u kako foni pa posi face pe ple non-audi, il pa es plu sporta milita, plu 
misili pa vola in pan via, plu bibli, plu saka, plu papira, plu stilo, plu 
pedi-ve, plu sito etc. u fenestra pa es aperi e em ma misili pa ge-jeti dia 
id e kata epi u movimento infra. .....................     

--part1_a4.1e4c15b1.29536e1f_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

      If the latter is true then your Internet machine is not operating
properly.

</fontfamily>  Omissions stopped me from being able to attempt a serious
interpretation of your message.


  My first suggestion is that you limit the length of your lines, either
by pulling in the RHS margin, or by adding a 'hard return' when the lines
are long

enough.  I am regulating line

lengh, now, using this method.

  One other suggestion is to use the mail program Eudora; but if you have
an Apple system, this would not apply.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

Hello,
I am new to Glosa. I once studied Esperanto for awhile, but gave it up 
because I felt it was simply impractical. Glosa may well also be impractical, 
I don't know, but from what I've seen of it, it seems a superior product to 
Esperanto and maybe one doesn't have to have a practical reason for learning 
it. Perhaps learning  just for fun is reason enough.

Anyway, as I say I'm completely new to the language, only just discovering 
it. I'm wondering if anyone would be willing to correspond in very simple, 
core vocabulary. I'm thinking that might be a good way to learn. I'm not a 
linguist, just a regular guy. I promise not to get personal, I'd just like to 
practice reading and writing simple Glosa and to have someone critique my 
efforts. If anyone would be interested drop me a line. Please keep it very 
simple to begin with.
Allan

--part1_ce.1eef50ea.29584b44_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Saluta Kevin,
I won't attempt to write to you in Glosa just yet, but below is my attempt at 
translating your letter. Please correct me.

Hello,
The Glosa e-list ought to serve this purpose, however I can understand that 
you might prefer to write one on one instead of to many people. If you want, 
we can write one on one using Glosa. I like to use my core list here: 
http://www.qualitycode.com/glosa/glosaenglish-abc.html
I can almost always write with only the verbs on this list.
I learned Esperanto, however, I believe Glosa is much easier to learn.

I would very much like to belgin corresponding one on one if you don't mind. 
Perhaps next letter I'll attempt some  rudimentary Glosa. Could you send me 
some sentences in English so I can practice translating to Glosa?

Thanks and Merry Christmas
Allan

*    Sid,

         I find it difficult splitting up the above format, so will
answer in a lump.The last attempted reply was lost when the new Net
computer froze: thus, I will be brief to ensure finishing before such a
thing happens again.


     . There were ten lines in the message when I saw it: it appears to
have shrunk again.  A computer overhaul seems necessary.

     . I am a caps man, and see value in denoting new sentences and
proper nouns, as in English, also for Glosa.

     . If we don't denote phrase and clause starts in some way, the
reading of text in a syntax-based grammar language can be very difficult:
there's punctuation, spaces, and possibly brackets.

    . I see the semi-colon as a necessary stage, in syntax indication,
between the comma and the colon.

    . I have used spaces to denote the marking off of phrases and
clasuses in my 'wordless' syntax analysis method, ie

           U feli pa sed epi u tape.      =        _.  \!  @._   [NB this
font does not give proportional spacing].


    The cat, which was sleeping, was awakened by the dog.


     u feli   qi pa du dormi  gene ge-vigi  ex u kani         (no caps;
spaces -> structure)


     U feli; qi pa du dormi, gene ge-vigi, ex u kani.         (standard
Glosa)

               \                            \                       \

           [next bit is            [next bit is       [next bit is a
phrase]

             a clause]              a phrase]


     _.   ;\~!  !<<`  @._                                                
              (gASCII Analysed Syntax)


  . On the question of ~ke~, it is Old Glosa.  While Ron decided it was
not needed, I could not see that its absence improved Glosa: I continue
to use it where it seems apt.


Saluta,


Robin

    PS Finished before any further siezing of the computer.

> Place, explika plu-mu semani! Infra mi scribe plu-mu

Fo-boni questi! Pan de plu-ci reakti es solo mi kredi...

> kosta
> litora
> plage

kosta = longi u mega area proxi u mari alo laku
litora = uno margina intra de tera e mari
plage = sili area de litora

> grandi
> mega

mega es de metri. grandi es de digni.

> anxio
> kura
> turba

anxio es u psiko stato, de fobo. kura es u mode de akti,
skope de plu problema. turba es u psiko alo materia stato
de konfusi alo no-kalma.

> lokali
> loka

lokali es u proxi area (proxi a uno ra). loka es uno mo
punkta, alo area.

> frakti
> skizo

Posi pan-bi homo semani. Posi u skizo es holo, e u frakti
es mero?

> nova
> neo

nova es u info de nu-pa-tem ra. neo es juve alo nu-pa-tem.

> nuli
> zero

Plu-ci es homo, anti-co zero es u nume. nuli ne es nume.

> area
> zona

Mi verba lista du dice; 'zona' es u ciklo-ra, homo -zo. U
GID verba lista du plus dice; 'zona' du semani 'area'.

> kapsu
> ostraka
> lami

ostraka es u sklero extra-lami, exempla de u ova. kapsu es
uno peri-lami, exempla u os-medika-ra 'Contact'. lami
es.....hmmm....no-facili explika. Plu exempla de lami:

1. U ra de papira
2. intra-ve
3. derma
4. U...ra...de kroma-ma epi u mura

Kevin

--- Andrey Rogachov <AndreyRogachov{at}mail{dot}ru> wrote:
Itera, pan-ci reakti es solo mi kredi...

> sociali
> societa
> komuni

sociali es u mode: ami, hedo. societa es u grega, koncentra
de mo hedo alo u tende. komuni es: pan plu ra (alo pe) habe
u stimula alo tende. Tu e mi du habe u komuni lingua:
Glosa. Pan-pe eko proxi a mi du habe u komuni loka.

> generali
> norma

general es ne-exakti. normal es ne-xeno alo ne-rari.

> etio
> liabili

etio es de kredi alo emotio alo religio. liabili es de lega
alo axioma.

> flo
> nekto

nekto es u ergo, exempla u pe alo piski moti. flo es
ne-ergo, exempla u pe (in aqa) ne-moti, alo u xilo mero in
aqa.

> flama
> piro

Ja. u piro du kausa u flama. u flama du indika u piro.

> kapo
> toga

'Zorro' pa uti u kapo. 'Merlin' e 'Gandalf' pa uti u toga.
U kapo es u lami. U toga es peri soma.

> ana
> skende

ana ne uti ra. u aeroplana du ana. u baluna du ana. skende
es ana per uti u skala.

> polisi
> politika

polisi es u norma mode, alo u ne-dina lega. politika es de
krati grega. Politika-pe homo Bush alo Putin, politika
grega homo 'Republican' alo 'Communist'.

> ofero
> proposi

Hmmm. Mi sio proposi u posi solve, alo u akorda. Mi sio
ofero u premi, alo u preci.

> orto
> rekti

rekti es ne-kurva. orto es no-horizontali (es direkta
ana/kata, ne levo/dextro). U bio dendra es orto. Po u pe du
seka id, id ne es orto. Id es horizontali.

> farina
> pulve

farina es mo taxo de pulve, ge-uti de face pani.

> hetero
> varia

hmmmm. hetero es no-homo. varia es poli hetero? Tu du eko
in u hetero natio de mi. U-ci e-lista du habe plu pe de
varia natio.

> sti pote
> lase
> lice

sti pote es dona pote. lase es ne-sto. lice es u lega lase.

> fito
> herba

herba es u taxo de fito, uti pro kuka. herba exempla:
Oregano, Thyme, Parsley.

> extende
> ma-mega

extende es ma-mega longi, alo ma-mega area. 

> priva
> kripto
> sekreti

mi pa apo ab 'sekreti' de mi lista, kausa id es homo
kripto. priva es tena apo de pe (alo ra). Mi du priva u
televidi de mi fili, si mi fili ne ergo. Pove-pe gene priva
de sito.

> membra-pe
> participa

membra-pe es ma dura. mi du participa in mo kore. mi es
membra-pe de u kore grega.

> orna
> sonia

Bi fo-hetero verba, anti-co u ~fancy~ es konfusi. Orna es
kali. sonia es u puta de somni.

> figura
> forma

Mi ne ski. Posi na ne nece 'figura'.

> dia
> trans

dia es intra. trans es epi. mi dromo dia u porta. mi dromo
trans u via.

> E plus qestio: in tu verba-bibli es verba "nebula"
> (ne-bula?),
> kausa-co nece fu e verba "bula"! Qo-lo es id?

Es 'nebula', ne 'ne-bula'. U-ci 'ne' es u mali-fortuna.

Grati de plu qesti! Mi du spe; mi pa auxi.

Kevin

To: "Thomas Wood" <thwood{at}freeuk{dot}com>
Subject: [glosalist] Re: Glosa
From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2001 12:49:11 +1100
Cc: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au

At 07:19 PM 12/27/01 -0000, you wrote: 

>>>>

<excerpt><fontfamily><param>Arial</param><smaller>Hi Robin

It's years since we corresponded. I would be very interested to know your
present views re Glosa.

Best Wishes for 2002

Tom Wood

</smaller></fontfamily>  

  

</excerpt><<<<<<<<

* Hello Tom,

    It's been quite a while.

    Well, I still prefer Glosa over Esperanto, but if it was a question
of adopting a fully-set-up IAL to-morrow, I'd probably have to go along
with Esperanto.

    Hopes and expectations:-

       . I am somewhat back-pedalling on my involvement, but do answer
letters on the Glosalist, around 50% in Glosa. 

       . I feel that most Glosa-pe are "dictionarists" not
'communicators': this augers badly for the growth of Glosa.  

       . My guess is that most people, used to the shoe-horn effects of
inflections and idioms in the national languages and most Planned
Languages, find Glosa a bit raw, with the need to think in 'pure terms'
before speaking.

       . So, it is this 'concept language' element of Glosa that has
prevented its ^taking off^ among scholars and intellectuals.

       . Nowadays, when I write in Glosa, what comes out is a slightly
stilted version of translated English; however, much cognition goes into
the process - mostly unconscious now - selecting from my Glosa vocab, and
jostling the words into a suitable Glosa syntax .. which, as a result of
the operation of some "universals," comes out looking like an almost
word-for-word translation of a version of English.

       . There are about ten websites featuring Glosa, nowadays, and once
there was only mine: the newer ones are in German, Russian, French and
some in English.  So things appear to have gone beyond the critical mass
needed to make the 'Glosa movement' self-perpetuating.

       . There has been renewed discussion to standardise the "Basic
Glosa Dictionary" (~1500 words), and subsequently to release further
standards at ~2500 and ~6500 words.  This is essential if Glosa is to be
regularised, and to avoid the  inconsistencies found in the original
publications.  Ron and Wendy attempted to carry on with the existing,
inconsistent word-lists, because of the cost of changing the paper-print
runs.  However this matter, of retooling costs, does not come up with
electronic formats.

       . Wendy has recovered from losing Ron, and has started to function
again, but is financially limited.  So, although we do not want to form
schisms, the Net groupings are moving off in there own directions; Wendy
is, however, still nominal head of the Glosa moity.

       . Were I twenty years younger, and more vigorous, perhaps I would
try a lot harder: I do try to be true to Ron's original visions for the
linguistic form, and for the ethic of low-cost auxilliary language for
all; however, we cannot avoid being in the hands of the more affluent,
who come across as also beimg more 'academic' in their approach.

       . The Uganda experiment is failing somewhat because the Africans
are not accessible to the Glosa-pe on the Internet.  Hand-held aerograms
seem to have gone out of fashion; connected Glosa-pe do not see support
of non-connected Glosa communities as part of their brief.  I have had
one computer printer 'lost in the mail' while trying to get an A$80.00
Toshiba luggable over to Banobi Herbert, who runs a Mountain Gorilla
sanctury as a Tourist attraction and wealth generator in Uganda.


       . However, the sum-up says that, with war-drums beating, this is
NOT the time for world-building; and, the sort of 'globally
communicating' world, that Glosa heralds, is not in line with the Power
Brokers' idea of "Globalisation."  In short, marching out of step for too
long hurts the legs.  It is an open question whether altruists have any
hope of realising their vision of a better world - in the face of the
extreme centralisation of wealth, industrial might, and political 
power.


But we keep trying,


Robin Gaskell

Subject: [glosalist] Glosa

Robin wrote:

> I feel that most Glosa-pe are "dictionarists" not
> 'communicators': this augers badly for the growth of Glosa.

> My guess is that most people, used to the shoe-horn effects of
> inflections and idioms in the national languages and most Planned
> Languages, find Glosa a bit raw, with the need to think in 'pure terms'
> before speaking.

> So, it is this 'concept language' element of Glosa that has
> prevented its ^taking off^ among scholars and intellectuals.

I think the 'concept' part is acceptable and even fashionable.
Analytic style may be the easiest for the most people to learn;
it's used quite a bit in Chinese and even English. Its basic
grammar design is certainly workable, though some of the details
(e.g. the semicolons to mark clauses) are unnecessarily bizarre.

Maybe the problem (if there is one) is the quality of the vocabulary.
If just the internationally known (European) words were allowed,
with clear rules as to what form they should take (as in LsF),
it might actually become popular on the internet -- which is
all that matters anymore.

proxi tri penta anua retro, mi pa tenta doci engelingua a u ju-an, dubaro 
nio, ex benglalanda (25n93e).an pa sedi in u-mi doci grupo e pa feno logi no 
ra. u hetera ju-an sed ex punjabilanda (35n75e) pa dice a mi ke dubar ( plu 
nima es no veri) pa dice gujerati-lingua. mi pa ki a u bibli-do e, po ma 
cerka, pa detekti u fo paleo bibli ko plu de u-co lingua, mi pa monstra id a 
dubar qi skope ad id ko u fo vaku facia. kusdev, de punjabi-landa, e mi pa 
lento seismo plu-na kefa - no veri. 
"urdu", kusdev pa ofere. bengla-landa pa es a u-la tem, est pakistan e u 
lingua de pakistan pa es urdu. u urdu bibli pa es ma facile de detekte so mi 
pa gene sko u urdu frase. "dubar, e kja cis he?", kusdev salta ana e kata ko 
hedo " kursi he. kursi he!" - nuli signi ex dubar!. an pa no dice urdu.
( na pa dice:- "u-ci ra es qo?", "es sedi-mobile") 
versi a bibli-do!. apo longi tem, mi detekti u mega e paki bibli ko multi 
lingua in id qi mi pa sume ab. 
kusdev, dubar e mi pa sti a pagina mo e na tri pa skope u lingua epi id, na 
pa skope pagina tri e ma e ma pagina. mi pa pote logi plu de pagina e kusdev 
plu hetera, punjabi-lingua e hindi-lingua e po multi pagina, dubar pa dice ko 
hedo "bengla" e sti lekto id. an pa pote lekti id facile e tako. po u tem, an 
pa feno enigma, an pa lekto u kristi bibli e an pa es u muslim. 
retro a bibli-do, id pa es dificile te gene u bibli de bengla-lingua. anti-co 
na pa profito e plu sko de enge-lingua pro dubar pa sti. sed. dubar pa no es 
u boni gene ski pe e u-an progresi pa es fo fo lento. mo di, mo de u 
engelanda ju-an qi pa habe simpati ko u-mi auxi dubar, pa dice ke mi pa es 
disipa u-mi tem e fo-tenta. u hetera ju-an ridi e dice ke mi debi audi u 
enge-lingua de dubar epi u bus!
proxi mo penta di seqe, mi pa akuti id!
u mi moto-me ruptu e mi nece ki a e ab u-mi sko-do per uti bi bus e mo di mi 
pa sume u mo qi pa ki ab mo mero de sko-do ad hetero proxi tri kilometri 
dista e dia ad u centra de civita. mi pa sto u bus, pa gradu epi id e pa 
skende plu skala. un akro tegu pa habe tri matura-an e un amaso de ju-an de 
u-mi sko-do.
u kako foni pa posi face pe ple non-audi, il pa es plu sporta milita, plu 
misili pa vola in pan via, plu bibli, plu saka, plu papira, plu stilo, plu 
pedi-ve, plu sito etc. u fenestra pa es aperi e em ma misili pa ge-jeti dia 
id e kata epi u movimento infra. .....................     
mi pa sta ko mega mira, u solo tem ke mi pa vide ali-ra homo id, pa es in u 
filma epi telivisio - u komika de sko-do vita . mi pa ski plu singu ju-an.
veri, mi pa ski qo mi pa debi akti - sed no ko hetera pe u-la! anti-co, mo de 
plu ju-an pa torno e pa vide ke mi pa vide mu. an pa subito sto, u feno de 
fobo pa kresce epi u-an facia. subito an pa sedi, pa ze-kine e pa es ze-soni. 
an pa pulsa u-an para-pe ko u-an kubita e pa susura (alo qo plu ju-an ge-nima 
susura) a u ju-an a fronta , "pidi".
u-co an pa torno u pusi te kripto oku in u-mi loka. an pluso susura "pidi" e 
pa sedi. ab u-ci u undu pa pande de plu ju-an qi pa sedi, skope fronta e pa 
ze-soni. plu-la saka,bibli, vesti, papira, korda, sndvic, botilia qi pa pende 
ex u bus, pa fo tako  ge-trakto in versi dia plu fenestra e plu-co pa ge-bang 
klude.  plu hetera ra pa kade e ge-lose in u longi pista poste e ultra u bus.


u bus pa es qieta. a dorsa, il pa es tri matura-pe; proxi dorsa, septi alo 
okto ju-an de sud asia. u-co ju-an pa es ko civiliza e boni akti. pluso, tem 
plu hetero ju-an pa es homo plu agrio bestia. po oliga minuta, mo de [lu asia 
an pa sta. an pa skope ad plu an ami ante an, pa lati hedo-vultu e pa sti u 
longi dice ad mu. id pa es in flu enge-lingua. sed, id pa es fo mali, ple de 
multi deino mali-dice. u enge-lingua an pa feno ski pa es pan plu obsceni alo 
plu blasfema. plu-an kompani viagia-pe pa es holo silento. dubar pa dura dice 
ko kresce entusi tem plu an audi-pe pa tenta, sine sucede, sema pro u-an sto.

graduali, dubar proto  te kredi ke il  es uno-ra falsi,
e pa reali ke mo matura-pe pa ge indika (in u kripto mode), u an flu de 
mali-dice pa esce hesita e an pa torno a dorsa, an e mi pa skope alelo 

mega-fobo! silento! u-an facia pa muta kroma ab  meso-frigi polio bruno homo 
juglans ligni a u termo rubi de pluto svieteni (swienteni) ligni.  an pa 
subito sedi. an pa kripto u-an facia in plu-an manu e seqe ko plu manu inter  
plu an genu e pa meiosi ab vide. plu-an
ideo sko de enge-lingua nu pa fini


--part1_23.16d77fcc.295f6daf_boundary

Proxi tri penta anua retro, mi pa tenta doci Engelingua a u ju-an, Dubaro 
Nio, ex Benglalanda (25n93e).An pa sedi in u-mi doci grupo e pa feno logi no 
ra. U hetero ju-an sed ex Punjabilanda (35n75e) pa dice a mi ; Dubar ( plu 
nima es no veri) pa dice Gujerati-lingua. Mi pa ki a u bibli-do e, po ma 
cerka, pa detekti u fo paleo bibli ko plu de u-co lingua, mi pa monstra id a 
Dubar qi skope ad id ko u fo vaku facia. Kusdev, de Punjabi-landa, e mi pa 
lento seismo plu-na kefa - no veri. 
"Urdu", Kusdev pa ofere. Bengla-landa pa es a u-la tem, Est Pakistan e u 
lingua de Pakistan es Urdu. U Urdu bibli pa es ma facile de detekte so mi pa 
gene sko u Urdu frase. "Dubar, E kja cis he?", Kusdev salta ana e kata ko 
hedo " Kursi he. kursi he!" - nuli signi ex Dubar!. An pa no dice Urdu.
( na pa dice:- "U-ci ra es qo?", "Id es sedi-mobile") 
Versi a bibli-do!. Apo longi tem, mi detekti u mega e paki bibli ko multi 
lingua in id qi mi pa sume ab. 
Kusdev, Dubar e mi pa sti a pagina mo e na tri pa skope u lingua epi id, na 
pa skope pagina tri e ma e ma pagina. Mi pa pote logi plu de pagina e Kusdev 
plu hetero, Punjabi-lingua e Hindi-lingua e po multi pagina, Dubar pa dice ko 
hedo "Bengla" e sti lekto id. an pa pote lekti id facile e tako. Po u tem, an 
pa feno enigma, an pa lekto u Kristi Bibli e an pa es u Muslim. 
Retro a bibli-do, id pa es dificile te gene u bibli de Bengla-lingua. anti-co 
na pa profito e plu sko de Enge-lingua pro Dubar pa sti. Sed. Dubar pa no es 
u boni gene ski pe e u-an progresi pa es fo fo lento. Mo di, mo de u 
Engelanda ju-an qi pa habe simpati ko u-mi auxi Dubar, pa dice; mi pa es 
disipa u-mi tem e fo-tenta. U hetero ju-an ridi e dice; mi debi audi u 
Enge-lingua de Dubar epi u bus!
Proxi mo penta di seqe, mi pa akuti id!
U mi moto-me ruptu e mi nece ki a e ab u-mi sko-do per uti bi bus e mo di mi 
pa sume u mo qi pa ki ab mo mero de sko-do ad hetero proxi tri kilometri 
dista e dia ad u centra de civita. Mi pa sto u bus, pa gradu epi id e pa 
skende plu skala. Un akro tegu pa habe tri matura-an e un amaso de ju-an de 
u-mi sko-do.
U kako foni pa posi face pe ple non-audi, il pa es plu sporta milita, plu 
misili pa vola in pan via, plu bibli, plu saka, plu papira, plu stilo, plu 
pedi-ve, plu sito etc. U fenestra pa es aperi e ma misili pa ge-jeti dia id e 
kata epi u movimento infra. .....................     

Mi pa sta ko mega mira, u solo tem; mi pa vide ali-ra homo id, pa es in u 
filma epi telivisio - u komika de sko-do vita . Mi pa ski plu singu ju-an.
Veri, mi pa ski qo mi pa debi akti - sed no ko hetero pe u-la! Anti-co, mo de 
plu ju-an pa torno e pa vide ke mi pa vide mu. An pa subito sto, u feno de 
fobo pa kresce epi u-an facia. Subito an pa sedi, pa ze-kine e pa es ze-soni. 
An pa pulsa u-an para-pe ko u-an kubita e pa susura (alo qo plu ju-an ge-nima 
susura) a u ju-an a fronta , "Pidi".
U-co an pa torno u pusi te kripto oku in u-mi loka. An pluso susura "Pidi" e 
pa sedi. Ab u-ci u undu pa pande de plu ju-an qi pa sedi, skope fronta e pa 
ze-soni. Plu-la saka,bibli, vesti, papira, korda, sandvic, botilia qi pa 
pende ex u bus, pa fo tako  ge-trakto in versi dia plu fenestra e plu-co pa 
ge-bang klude.  Plu hetero ra pa kade e ge-lose in u longi pista poste e 
ultra u bus.


U bus pa es qieta. A dorsa, il pa es tri matura-pe; proxi dorsa, septi alo 
okto ju-an de sud asia. U-co ju-an pa es ko civiliza e boni akti. Pluso, tem 
plu hetero ju-an pa es homo plu agrio bestia. Po oliga minuta, mo de plu Asia 
an pa sta. An pa skope ad plu an ami ante an, pa lati hedo-vultu e pa sti u 
longi dice ad mu. Id pa es in flu Enge-lingua. sed, id pa es fo mali, ple de 
multi deino mali-dice. U Enge-lingua an pa feno ski pa es pan plu obsceni alo 
plu blasfema. Plu-an kompani viagia-pe pa es holo silento. Dubar pa dura dice 
ko kresce entusi tem plu an audi-pe pa tenta, sine sucede, sema pro u-an sto.

Gaduali, Dubar proto  te kredi ke il  es uno-ra falsi,
e pa reali; mo matura-pe pa ge indika (in u kripto mode), u an flu de 
mali-dice pa esce hesita e an pa torno a dorsa, an e mi pa skope alelo 

Mega-fobo! Silento! U-an facia pa muta kroma ab  meso-frigi polio bruno homo 
Juglans ligni a u termo rubi de pluto Svieteni (Swienteni) ligni.  An pa 
subito sedi. An pa kripto u-an facia in plu-an manu e seqe ko plu manu inter  
plu an genu e pa meiosi ab vide. Plu-an
ideo sko de enge-lingua nu pa fini.

--part1_4b.1604d553.295f6db2_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

<BR>U kako foni pa posi face pe ple non-audi, il pa es plu sporta milita, plu misili pa vola in pan via, plu bibli, plu saka, plu papira, plu stilo, plu pedi-ve, plu sito etc. U fenestra pa es aperi e ma misili pa ge-jeti dia id e kata epi u movimento infra. ..................... &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
<BR>Mi pa sta ko mega mira, u solo tem; mi pa vide ali-ra homo id, pa es in u filma epi telivisio - u komika de sko-do vita . Mi pa ski plu singu ju-an.
<BR>Veri, mi pa ski qo mi pa debi akti - sed no ko hetero pe u-la! Anti-co, mo de plu ju-an pa torno e pa vide ke mi pa vide mu. An pa subito sto, u feno de fobo pa kresce epi u-an facia. Subito an pa sedi, pa ze-kine e pa es ze-soni. An pa pulsa u-an para-pe ko u-an kubita e pa susura (alo qo plu ju-an ge-nima susura) a u ju-an a fronta , "Pidi".
<BR>U-co an pa torno u pusi te kripto oku in u-mi loka. An pluso susura "Pidi" e pa sedi. Ab u-ci u undu pa pande de plu ju-an qi pa sedi, skope fronta e pa ze-soni. Plu-la saka,bibli, vesti, papira, korda, sandvic, botilia qi pa pende ex u bus, pa fo tako &nbsp;ge-trakto in versi dia plu fenestra e plu-co pa ge-bang klude. &nbsp;Plu hetero ra pa kade e ge-lose in u longi pista poste e ultra u bus.
<BR>
<BR>
<BR>U bus pa es qieta. A dorsa, il pa es tri matura-pe; proxi dorsa, septi alo okto ju-an de sud asia. U-co ju-an pa es ko civiliza e boni akti. Pluso, tem plu hetero ju-an pa es homo plu agrio bestia. Po oliga minuta, mo de plu Asia an pa sta. An pa skope ad plu an ami ante an, pa lati hedo-vultu e pa sti u longi dice ad mu. Id pa es in flu Enge-lingua. sed, id pa es fo mali, ple de multi deino mali-dice. U Enge-lingua an pa feno ski pa es pan plu obsceni alo plu blasfema. Plu-an kompani viagia-pe pa es holo silento. Dubar pa dura dice ko kresce entusi tem plu an audi-pe pa tenta, sine sucede, sema pro u-an sto.
<BR>
<BR>Gaduali, Dubar proto &nbsp;te kredi ke il &nbsp;es uno-ra falsi,
<BR>e pa reali; mo matura-pe pa ge indika (in u kripto mode), u an flu de mali-dice pa esce hesita e an pa torno a dorsa, an e mi pa skope alelo 
<BR>
<BR>Mega-fobo! Silento! U-an facia pa muta kroma ab &nbsp;meso-frigi polio bruno homo Juglans ligni a u termo rubi de pluto Svieteni (Swienteni) ligni. &nbsp;An pa subito sedi. An pa kripto u-an facia in plu-an manu e seqe ko plu manu inter &nbsp;plu an genu e pa meiosi ab vide. Plu-an
<BR>ideo sko de enge-lingua nu pa fini.</FONT></HTML>


--part1_4b.1604d553.295f6db2_boundary

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Glosa
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2001 19:26:24 -0800

I scribbled:

>> Maybe the problem (if there is one) is the quality of the vocabulary.
>> If just the internationally known (European) words were allowed,
>> with clear rules as to what form they should take (as in LsF),
>> it might actually become popular on the internet -- which is
>> all that matters anymore.

Alex replied:

> But present vocabulary of Glosa "gives meaning to any scientific term". It's
> very useful, is not it?

I think that, since the time of Hogben's original Interglossa idea,
Greek scientific roots have become less internationally recognizable
and more idiosyncratic (non-systematic, opaque, iconic) in actual use.
I've examined many lists of Greek "combining forms" like BIO-, HYDRO-,
-GRAPHY, -TOMY, etc, and there just aren't enough of them to make an
operational language. Glosa needed to add Latin roots to complete its
vocabulary, and they are very recognizable to the largest percentage
of interested people, whereas Greek is not (especially after phonetic
adjustments), and usually conflicts with better-known Latin roots.

So, why not eliminate the troublesome Greek and instead define a few
easy principles to allow anyone to derive the vocabulary as needed?
This was done in Peano's Interlingua, again in Occidental/Interlingue,
and yet again in Gode's Interlingua. For example, from my pocket Italian
dictionary it's obvious that English FAVOR = Italian FAVORE, nicely
Glosa-like and international; but checking the official G vocab:

FAVO       favor
GEFAVO     favorite
FAVORI     favorable
FAVORITA   favorite

One can easily see the difficulty here, and a possible solution.

the Greek, then I would vote for it to move in the
direction of "a priori", rather than Latin/Romance.

Kevin

Subject: [glosalist] Glosa
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2001 21:11:34 -0800

>> So, why not eliminate the troublesome Greek and instead
>> define a few easy principles to allow anyone to derive
>> the vocabulary as needed?

> I've said it before, and I'll say it again. The world has
> plenty of Euroclones. If Glosa is going to move away from
> the Greek, then I would vote for it to move in the
> direction of "a priori", rather than Latin/Romance.

That's been done too, even more times, and it's not a bad idea.
But it requires a "Grand Datuval", an artist or committee
to create it. Whereas, the so-called "international vocabulary"
is public domain, available to anyone. The trick I had in mind
was to publish only the principles and then let the people
who wish to participate put them into practice. In fact,
it is already "legal" Glosa to use those Latinate words,
whether or not they are listed among the Glosa 6000.

From: Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com

--part1_23.16e2349c.29605530_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"

U frasi mo in PGN 86 es "U developo de
 energi-ma celu teknologi nu-du tako avanti in
 Islanda."

 Mi fo amo id kausa mi pote facile translati id.
 Mi pote facile detekti u akti-verba kausa il es u 
 akti-verba-intro-verba - "nu-du"
 Id monstra a mi u sti de akti-verba grupo e pluso 
 u sto de nima-verba grupo. U-co es, mi puta, fo fo 
 gravi. Id pluso monstra u tem e dura.
 
 u avanti akti tem de grafo de frasi, id pa sti pre e
 fini u avanti sine sto.

 Pe puta qo de u-ci skema?
 NA nu-du habe "pa", "fu", "nu", "du". Mo pe prefere
 "nu" ex "du". Si na uti "nu-du" versa "du", ma pe fu   posi amo id. "Pa", 
"nu" e "fu" monstra u tem, ko mu
 na posi habe "du" = mo dura tem, "no-du" = mo
 brevi tem e "plu-kron" =  plu ditere itera tem.
 
 pa-du   pa-no-du   pa-plu-kron
 nu-du   nu-no-du   nu-plu-kron
 fu-du   fu-no-du   fu-plu-kron

 Mi nu-du eko proxi Skarbro(53.3n0.4u).
 Mi pa-du eko in Nantuic(53.1n2.5u).
 Mi fu-du posi eko in Skarbro.
 Mi pa-plu-kron visita Cester(53.5n2.8u).
 Mi nu-plu-kron visita Jork(53.9n1.1u).
 Mi fu-plu-kron posi visita Hul(53.8n0.2u).
 Mi pa-no-du ki dia Malton(54.2n0.8u).
 Mi nu-no-du kade u-ci grafo.

 Mi nu-du amo "du" kausa id es brevi sed "nu-du"
 klu "nu"  sed plu kron "du" es no gru de qi mi volu dice  so mi fu-du posi 
uti "nu-du".
 sid

U frasi mo in PGN 86 es "U developo de energi-ma celu teknologi nu-du tako 
avanti in Islanda."
Na nu-du habe u sti de akti-verba-grupo, na nu-du nece detekti u kefa-verba. 
U-ci, id es u verba ante plu verba "in Islanda". Id es "avanti". "Tako" nu-du 
auxi u semani de "avanti" e "in Island" pluso nu-du auxi "avanti". Il no es u 
"objekti" verba-grupo, u grupo ante "nu-du es u "subjekti" grupo e u verba 
ante plu verba "de energi ....." es u subjekti kefa verba. Pan u-co, mi nu-du 
facile de logi.
Na nu-du habe:- 
intro de subjekti - (no auxi verba) - kefa verba - "de" plus auxi grupo - 
intro de akti-grupo - auxi - kefa - "in" plus auxi - no objekti
sid

--part1_46.202a275a.2961a358_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
